story: The Royal couple are set to embark on a 16-day tour of Australia, New Zealand, Tonga and Fiji, arriving in Sydney on Monday October 15 ahead of the 2018 Sydney Invictus Games in support of wounded servicemen and women.The couple&rsquos imminent visit to Fiji has nevertheless caused concern among political commentators, who have warned it could interfere in the country&rsquos general election, which will take place within 20 days of the couple&rsquos visit.Robin Nair, Fiji&rsquos former foreign affairs permanent secretary, told ABC: &ldquoThe perception is, of course, that the Fijian government will take full advantage of the visit.&ldquoFijians love the Royals, and the government knows that there will be great euphoria and joy created by the visit.                Meghan Markle&rsquos ex marries heiress RICHER than Prince Harry                Will Meghan Markle and Prince Harry MISS Princess Eugenie&rsquos wedding? The former official lambasted the British High Commission in the country&rsquos capital Suva for not delaying the visit.He said: &ldquoI would have thought the British High Commission in Suva would have advised the Commonwealth office in London about the forthcoming elections and the environment in which the elections are taking place.&ldquoIt&rsquos not the right timing.Mr Nair&rsquos concerns were echoed by Shailendra G Raju, a government critic and aide to two former prime ministers, who also called on the visit to be &ldquopostponed to a mutually convenient and more appropriate time.Meghan and Harry's visit to Fiji has been criticised due to its proximity to the country's elections (Image: )Meghan Markle and Prince Harry are expected to meet Fiji's Prime Minister Voreqe Bainimarama (Image: )Meghan and Harry will spend two days on Fiji during their tour of Oceania (Image: )Mr Nair and Mr Raju&rsquos concerns were nevertheless rejected by the British High Commission, which insisted that the Royal couple&rsquos visit will remain apolitical.A spokesman for the High Commission said: &ldquoTheir programme will be non-political and support bilateral relations between the two countries.&ldquoGiven that Their Royal Highnesses are visiting Australia, New Zealand, and Tonga next month, it makes sense for a visit to Fiji to take place at the same time.Associate Professor Giselle Bastin from Flinders University in Australia also noted that members of the British Royal Family typically meet with leaders from varying political parties while undertaking Royal tours.                Royal charmer: Prince Harry should have special DIPLOMATIC ROLE                Royal SCANDAL: King George V RUTHLESSLY knifed Tsar Nicholas in backMeghan and Harry will attend the 2018 Invictus Games in Sydney to start their tour (Image: )Meghan and Harry will visit Melbourne in the lead-up to state elections in Victoria (Image: )She told ABC: &ldquoThey meet the Premier of the day but there&rsquos usually the leader of the opposition party hovering in the background somewhere, so they make sure they meet or confront both sides.&ldquoIt will be built into their itinerary that they are at least exposed to people from the various political persuasions.The Duke and Duchess&rsquo visit to Melbourne will also be in the immediate lead-up to state elections in Victoria, which are taking place on November 24.

title: Royal wedding Princess Eugenie wedding cake designer
story: Sophie Cabot is unveiled as the designer behind Princess Eugenie's wedding cake (Image: PRESS ASSOCIATION &amp )Sophie Cabot, who is based in Fulham in West London, has been creating detailed sugar flowers and foliage in the last few months to decorate the five tiers of the cake.Ms Cabot, 33, said: &ldquoWith such a big cake, you need to start well in advance - especially with all the sugar work, so it was important to get going quite early.&ldquoThere are a lot of eggs involved and a lot of butter obviously, just for the sheer a number of people who hope to have a piece of cake.&ldquoIt&rsquos a lot of ingredients, it&rsquos a huge scale, it&rsquos a bit different to me.                Princess Eugenie wedding: What will Sarah Ferguson wear?                Princess Eugenie vs Princess Beatrice style: How do outfits differ?&ldquoI&rsquom used to baking on a much smaller scale - it&rsquos a challenge.The red velvet and chocolate cake contains 400 eggs, 53 packs of unsalted butter, 15kg of self-raising flour and 20kg of sugar.There will be three tiers of red velvet and two of chocolate sponge cake covered with buttercream, white icing and decorated with autumnal-themed sugar work.There will also be vanilla essence, vanilla bean paste and red food colouring.Sophie Cabot has been creating the sugar work since July (Image: )Ms Cabot was invited by the office of Eugenie&rsquos father, the Duke of York, to meet the couple and discuss their wedding cake in early July, after she made decorated bespoke biscuits to one of Prince Andrew's events.After meeting several times, she began on the sugar work, creating sugar ivy, acorns, white flowers and maple leaves.On her first meeting with Princess Eugenie and her fianc&eacute Jack Brooksbank, she brought cake samples with her.She said: &ldquoThe couple were very relaxed, very comfortable. I got the feeling the cake was something they were very excited about.&ldquoIt was fun meeting as well because I don&rsquot think it&rsquos every day you have a meeting about cake and you get to try cake.                Princess Eugenie wedding: What time will the royal wedding be on TV?                Will Meghan Markle and Prince Harry MISS Princess Eugenie&rsquos wedding? Sophie Cabot has started baking in Buckingham Palace ahead of the wedding tomorrow (Image: )Ms Cabot began baking yesterday in Buckingham Palace&rsquos kitchens for the big day on Friday.On the responsibility of cooking for royalty, she said: &ldquoOf course I was nervous, but at the same time really, really excited.She added: &ldquoThe couple were very excited about having red velvet, during the tastings red velvet and chocolate came out top.&ldquoIt&rsquos a lovely thing to have at this time of year as well - it&rsquos a nice rich cake.&ldquoNot one cake is ever the same and this was extra because of the time of year and they wanted to keep it so seasonal - it was a real joy.

story: A shocking study reveals Banksy has been voted more popular than Her Majesty The Queen (Image: MyArtBroker  Getty)Contemporary Art marketplace MyArtBroker polled over 1,400 members of the British public to measure the popularity of the anonymous England-based street artist.According to the study, revealed exclusively by Express, Bansky was recognised by the British as a national treasure and was voted more popular than the monarch.When Britons were asked who they think represents British society the best, 53 percent said Bansky, 42 percent said the Royal Family and only 5 percent said the Church of England.A total of 67 percent of people also said Bansky is a cultural export like the Royal Family and 89 percent of respondents want museums such as The National Gallery and the Museum of Modern Art to preserve and show his artwork.                Sir Winston Churchill was DEEPLY suspicious of the young Prince Philip                Royal news: How the Queen Mother and Prince Philip went to WAR Ian Syer of MyArtBroker commented on the research, saying: &ldquoNobody had properly asked the British public how they felt about Banksy, so we thought it would be a good idea to try to understand why Banksy is so popular.&ldquoNot only does Banksy capture the hearts and minds of all generations, the art produced is also considered to be complex and emotive yet simple to digest and appreciate.Banksy is an artist who has courted an incredible amount of controversy in the past.He recently played what could be one of the most audacious stunts in art history last Sunday when The Girl With Ballon template was ripped moments after it sold for more than a million at Sotheby&rsquos auction house in London.Love Is In The Air (Flower Thrower) is one of Banksy&rsquos most famous images (Image: MyArtBroker)He later explained in a video that he built the shredding machine into his iconic artwork years ago with the intention of self-destructing if it was sold at auction.Sotheby's Senior Director Alex Branczik reacted to the self-destruction of the canvas saying: It appears we just got Banksy-ed.The auction house told the Financial Times: We have talked with the successful purchaser who was surprised by the story.We are in discussion about the next step.                Banksy EU mural could raise &pound1million at auction                Brussels&rsquo hopes dashed as finance boss backs UK to remain business hubThe Girl With Ballon template was ripped moments after it sold for more than a million  (Image: PA)Banksy, thought to be from Bristol, has never revealed his true identity but there are countless rumours about who he really is.According to the study conducted MyArtBroker, 52 percent of people think Banksy is a collective of iniduals, all using his trademark tag on their work.Another 20 percent of people think Banksy is an artist called Robin Gunningham and 13 percent believe he is the artist Robert Del Naja.

title: Brexit news Jacon Rees Mogg Nicola Sturgeon Scotland independence second referendum latest
story: Nicola Sturgeon suggested Brexit made Scotland's independence from the United Kingdom more likely than ever as she spurred campaigners to do more to convince voters to leave the union.But Jacob Rees-Mogg pointed out a major flaw in her programme, pointing out her decision to run on a pro-independence manifesto at the 2017 General Election had backfired as the SNP lost 19 seats in Parliament.Asked whether Brexit could bring about the break up of the UK, Mr Rees-Mogg exclusively told Express: It&rsquos very unlikely because polls come and go but at the general election last year the SNP did extremely badly whilst Nicola Sturgeon was calling for a second referendum.She was saying &lsquobecause of Brexit we should have a second referendum,&rsquo and the Scots said no.                Sturgeon belittles Boris and Rees-Mogg as Prime Minister contender                Nicola Sturgeon's independence dream SAVAGED by George Galloway Mr Rees-Mogg insisted the evidence did not support calls for a new independence referendum for Scotland despite Ms Sturgeon's repeated pledge to hold a fresh vote to counteract the possible impact of Brexit on the nation.The North Somerset MP added: The SNP lost a number of their seats. I&nbspthink the evidence is not there to support this view.Ms Sturgeon announced before the start of her party&rsquos conference the SNP would not oppose a second Brexit referendum.She set out her plan to torpedo Theresa May's Chequers proposals and pledged the SNP would dilute the final deal or force the UK into a second referendum.Brexit news: Mr Rees-Mogg said Scottish independence is  (Image: ITV&bullEXPRESS.CO.UK)The First Minister added that if Scotland voted to remain in any new Brexit referendum, it should not be forced to leave with rest of UK.She continued: If that was the choice, no doubt calls for a second referendum would grow in those circumstances.We would not stand in the way of a second referendum, a so-called people&rsquos vote. SNP MPs would undoubtedly vote for that proposition.&ldquoWe would, of course, want to talk to people about how we ensure that Scotland does not end up in the same position all over again, where we voted to remain in the EU but find ourselves facing exit completely against our will.Ms Sturgeon added that independence was the end goal of a new Brexit referendum, saying: &ldquoI think we are on a journey that ends with independence.I think Brexit brings issues around this sharply into focus.

story: Addressing Theresa May during Prime Minister's Questions in Parliament on Wednesday, the Tory MP claimed the Prime Minister&nbsphas a formidable task ahead of herself when MPs will have a meaningful vote on her Brexit&nbspdeal at the end of the negotiations.Mr Clarke claimed that considering the unlikely support of Remainer&nbspLabour backbenchers and Remainer&nbspTory MPs, the vote will reveal that hard-liners on the Labour frontbench and right-wing nationalists in the Conservative Party are a minority.He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos obvious that the biggest task facing the Prime Minister this winter is firstly to obtain a compromised agreement with the other 27 European Governments on the terms of our withdrawal.&ldquoAnd then, to win the approval of this House, a majority in this House for that same agreement or something like it in a meaningful vote on the terms of our departure. but will also remember that, having given the decision as to whether we stay in the European Union or not to the British people, the British people having voted to leave, it is our duty to ensure that title: Brexit news Theresa May UK EU customs union ITV Peston
story: The astonishing claim was made on ITV Peston, the current affairs show, during an interview with former Brexit Secretary David Davis.Mr Peston said: &ldquoI have it from very good sources that last night Olly Robbins and his opposite number who works for Michel Barnier agreed to an outline of a deal which would keep the UK in the customs union for the period that a so-called backstop would have to operate.Olly Robbins is Theresa May&rsquos top Brexit advisor and is seen as the architect of her controversial Chequers plan.A backstop deal would come into effect if the UK and EU can&rsquot reach a full agreement finalising their future relations.                Spain in Brexit PANIC as tourist boss warns of no deal DISASTER                Brexit DILEMMA: May faces unionist REVOLT if she agrees to EU demandsUnless it is time limited it could theoretically see the UK stuck in the customs union indefinitely.Mr Davis, who resigned from the Government in July in protest at Theresa May&rsquos Chequers deal, made it clear on the programme such an agreement is unacceptable.He said: &ldquoNo I don&rsquot approve it in the terms you&rsquore talking about because there&rsquos no backstop to the backstop.&ldquoThere&rsquos no limit to the backstop, it only ceases when the EU agrees to it.&ldquoNo I don&rsquot approve it because there&rsquos no backstop to the backstop (Image: ITV PESTON)&ldquoThere&rsquos no limit to the backstop, it only ceases when the EU agrees to it (Image: )&ldquoWhy should we ever agree?The European customs union is a free trade area which also maintains common tariffs on non-members.As such, duties are not paid on trade between members, but are charged at a common rate to other countries.                Brexit uncertainty has mixed affect on housing market across the UK&ldquoWhy should we ever agree? (Image: )All trade agreements are made by the European Commission, essentially the Government of the European Union.Members states are consequently unable to make their own trade deals.Should the UK stay in the customs union it would see the European Commission negotiate trade deals on behalf of the UK, despite the UK losing its European Commission representation after Brexit.&ldquoIn the referendum both sides said &lsquoLeave&rsquo meant leaving the customs union and single market (Image: )Yesterday former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson claimed staying in the customs union would turn the UK into a &ldquopermanent EU colony.He added: &ldquoThis is far from take back control.&ldquoIn the referendum both sides said &lsquoLeave&rsquo meant leaving the customs union and single market.

title: Brexit news Daniel Hannan second eu referendum people s vote campaign labour
story: Mr Hannan, Conservative MEP for the South East, made the dramatic claim during an interview with&nbspExpress.Speaking of a second referendum he said: &ldquoI think there is a huge risk, it would be very clear what had happened.&ldquoThe country would have voted, more people would have voted for Brexit than have ever voted for anything, and their political elites would have overturned the result.&ldquoThat, quite apart from it being a bad outcome on Europe, would be catastrophic for the legitimacy and authority of our system.                &lsquoWe can&rsquot give the EU &pound39billion for NOTHING&rsquo warns David Davis The self-styled &lsquoPeople&rsquos Vote&rsquo campaign, which is backed by some Labour, Liberal Democrat and Conservative MPs, is campaigning for a second referendum on whatever deal Theresa May negotiates.The Labour Party has said it could back such a referendum if it can&rsquot bring down the Government and force a general election.Sir Keir Starmer, Labour&rsquos shadow Brexit Secretary, went further telling his party&rsquos conference last month &ldquonobody is ruling out remain as an option in a second vote.However, Mr Hannan explained to&nbspExpress&nbspa second vote could destabilise the UK.That would be catastrophic for the legitimacy and authority of our system (Image: EU PARLIAMENT)&ldquoBritain has until now been a country with a very high level of trust in politics (Image: )He argued: &ldquoBritain has until now been a country with a very high level of trust in politics.&ldquoI know that may sound funny but what I mean is people don&rsquot question the outcome of elections, we&rsquove never had a dictatorship and we&rsquove never had a revolution.&ldquoPeople agree to the rules and stick to them in a way that is not true of every country.Mr Hannan admitted he worries a second referendum would finish these conventions.He noted many of those &ldquowho were loudest in insisting that there would only be one vote, the Nick Clegg&rsquos and the John Major&rsquos, are the same people who are now considering a second referendum.                May&rsquos Brexit negotiations LAMBASTED by pro-EU ex-ambassador&ldquoIf they now turn around and went back on that commitment I think it would be a crisis of democracy (Image: )He said: &ldquoIf they now turn around and went back on that commitment I think it would be a crisis of democracy.Many of the key People&rsquos Vote campaign supporters, who include Liberal Democrat leader Vince Cable, Labour MP David Lammy and Tory MP Anna Soubry, were prominent &lsquoRemain&rsquo backers in 2016.The same was true of celebrity backers like actor Tony Robinson and ex-footballer Gary Lineker.Mr Hannan went on to discuss why, in his view, some politicians are unable to accept the referendum defeat.He asserted: &ldquoI think it was the psychological shock of not getting their way on something.&ldquoI think it was the psychological shock of not getting their way on something (Image: )&ldquoThey are accustomed to politics having happened within certain parameters and in June 2016 those parameters were blown away.&ldquoDuring the campaign Remainers decided the Leave case was reactionary, small-minded, anti-immigration and so on.&ldquoBy polling day I think they&rsquod come to believe their own propaganda.Daniel Hannan has been a fervent Eurosceptic campaigner for decades making the case for Brexit via books, articles and public debates.He was one of the founders of Vote Leave, the successful pro-Brexit campaign which won the June 2016 referendum.

title: Brexit news Conservative MPs second EU referendum Theresa May
story: According to the claims, made by The Daily Mail, the group are planning to coordinate voting and agree a name by the end of the month.This means they will be fully prepared for the Parliamentary vote on any Brexit deal agreed by Theresa May.They allegedly plan to vote against the deal, in a bid to force a second referendum.Exactly how many Tory MPs back this move is expected to depend on the final deal agreed by Theresa May.                Theresa May in CRISIS: Tory MP submits NO CONFIDENCE letter The group will act as a direct rival to the European Research Group, an association of Tory MPs pushing for what they deem a clean Brexit.A number of Conservative MPs, including Domonic Grieve, Anna Soubry, Justine Greening, Dr Philip Lee and Heidi Allen have publicly called for a second vote.Several, including Ms Soubry, are supporters of the cross-party &lsquoPeople&rsquos Vote&rsquo campaign which shares their objective.Justine Greening, formerly Education Minister and the first Tory MP to demand a second vote, is seen as a potential leader for the group.They allegedly plan to vote against any Brexit deal in a bid to force a second referendum (Image:  )The organisers are already claiming to have 30 MPs onboard  (Image: )However, the organisers are already claiming to have 30 supporters.At the end of last month Mr Grieve, the former Attorney General, called for a &ldquopolite rebellion of Tory MPs against Brexit.Writing in The Daily  he said: &ldquoI believe the time has come for a polite rebellion by pragmatic Conservatives.&ldquoIncluding myself, it is now clear that there is a significant group of Conservative MPs who think that a People&rsquos Vote - a vote on the final form Brexit will take, is absolutely indispensable.&ldquoThe only possible response must be to return to the British electorate and ask them what they want.                &lsquoWe can&rsquot give the EU &pound39billion for NOTHING&rsquo warns David Davis I think some others are on the cusp (Image: )Dr Lee, who resigned from the Government in June over its handling of Brexit, claimed many more Conservative MPs privately share his position.He told a fringe event outside the Tory Party Conference: &ldquoI know of three ministers who do.&ldquoI&rsquove had direct conversations with them. It is a difficult environment for them to come out.&ldquoBut I think some others are on the cusp.Theresa May has publicly ruled out a second referendum saying it would be a &ldquogross betrayal of democracy.

title: Brexit news UK EU Theresa May European Union Chequers latest news
story: Prime Minister Theresa May is sticking with her controversial Chequers Brexit blueprint despite criticism from within her own party, and from EU leaders.Earlier this week, former Brexit Minister Steve Baker warned Mrs May that up to 40 Tory MPs were prepared to vote down a Chequers based deal in Parliament.The DUP, who are propping up the Prime Minister&rsquos Government has also warned they would revolt if the EU&rsquos backstop is accepted and Northern Ireland is treated differently from the rest of the UK.Alan Sked, the co-founder of Ukip and founder of Clean Brexit, has claimed that no deal is rapidly becoming Mrs May&rsquos only option.                Tony Blair warns Brexit pain will go on for &lsquoLONG TIME&rsquo                 Thirty Conservative MPs gang together to DEMAND another Brexit voteProfessor Sked told RT: &ldquoThe trouble is the five percent still to be sorted is the very important bit.&ldquoI mean, they can&rsquot agree on tariffs, if May were to try to keep us in the single market or the customs union, that would be against everything she has said so far, it would break her own red lines and I presume about seven cabinet ministers would resign. Northern Ireland is still impossible to fix.When asked whether Theresa May still had time to alter her Chequers proposal, Mr Sked claimed the Prime Minister was going to come under &ldquohuge pressure from within her own cabinet.He added: &ldquoThey will say, &lsquolook Chequers really is dead, you can&rsquot go on talking about it as if it is alive&rsquo.&ldquoThe plan B that everybody seems to be wanting is the Canada-plus free trade agreement.&ldquoShe has been saying quite adamantly recently that it doesn&rsquot work, she doesn&rsquot believe in it. It doesn&rsquot solve the Northern Ireland problem.&ldquoNow, if she doesn&rsquot accept the Canada-deal, she could go for the Norway-model, but that would mean keeping us in the single market.&ldquoIf she doesn&rsquot want to do any of these and she is told that Chequers really is dead by Brussels, then it becomes more and more like no deal.Mr Sked added: &ldquoNo deal is still perfectly possible, we are running out of time.Brexit news: Alan Sked no deal is rapidly becoming May's only option (Image: &bullRT)Mrs May has repeatedly said the two remaining Brexit options for the UK are either Chequers or no deal.Speaking on the Today programme on Monday Mr Baker warned Mrs May about the about of Tory MPs who would vote down Chequers.He said: &ldquoI did a concrete canvas of colleagues when it was amendments to legislation and came up with the number nearly 80.&ldquoOf course, the Government are going to whip this vote extremely hard but what I would say is, whips would be doing incredibly well if they were to halve the numbers.&ldquoMy estimate is that there are at least 40 colleagues who are not going to accept a half-in, half-out Chequers deal. Or indeed a backstop that leaves us in the internal market and customs union come what may.

story: The Met Office has issued yellow warnings for Northern Ireland, western parts of Scotland, Wales and northern parts of England.Forecasters predict Storm Callum will bring over month's worth of rainfall, with a risk of storm surges along coastlines.The Met Office said: The zone of heavy rain affecting England and Wales on Friday is expected to slowly move northwards on Saturday, with the focus of heaviest rainfall slowly moving away from south Wales but increasingly into parts of Scotland.The rain is expected to be accompanied by strong winds, which may increase autumnal leaf fall and potential for blocked drainsculverts, heightening the potential for flooding. The decisions you &amp your family make over the coming hours could be the difference between life &amp death.Mandatory evacuations are in place across the coast of Florida ahead of Hurricane Michael's arrival.Weather forecasters say 12 inches (10 to 30cm) of rain could be dumped in some areas, with flash flooding possible.In a terrifying warning yesterday, Governor Scott warned &ldquono one would survive a deadly storm surge measuring 14 feet inches (4.3 metres).Here are the latest updates on Hurricane Michael (all times in BST, which is six hours behind CDT). We can rebuild your home, but we cannot rebuild your life.The storm will bring torrential rain, heavy winds and dangerous storm surges to many areas of Florida and the northeastern Gulf Coast on Wednesday.Michael is currently 50 miles south of the western tip of Cuba.5.14pm update: Michael develops into Category 1 hurricaneTropical Storm Michael developed into a hurricane on Monday as it continues to strengthen.Michael is a Category 1 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 75mph and could make landfall as a Category 3 hurricane on the five-step Saffir-Simpson scale.The hurricane is forecast to hit Florida on Wednesday before then moving northeast on Wednesday and Thursday along the Atlantic Coast and batter the Carolinas.Michael has already battered parts of Mexico and Cuba with powerful winds and drenching rains on Sunday and into early Monday.

title: Hurricane Michael 2018 weather path Florida surfing evacuation category 4 NOAA update
story: The&nbspHurricane&nbspescalated into an extremely dangerous category 4 hurricane before it made landfall on the US Gulf Coast today.But this shocking footage - from a UK news crew - shows daredevil surfers on the beach as howling winds rage around them, despite Florida Governor Rick Scott&rsquos terrifying warning that &ldquono one would survive deadly storm surges of 14ft which could devastate the area.Despite rapidly deteriorating conditions, the clip shows at least one surfer in the churning ocean as white water crashes around them.Life-threatening flooding, winds, storm surge and rain is lashing Florida as Hurricane Michael rages north.&nbsp                BREAKING UK WEATHER NEWS: Hurricane Michael to smash into BRITAIN                  Oil workers FLEE rigs as 145mph Hurricane Michael scythes towards USThe monster storm is packing 150 mph winds and in a series of urgent tweets, Governor Rick Scott urged residents to leave the area or immediately seek shelter.Mr Scott said: &ldquoThis is the worst storm that the FL Panhandle has seen in over a century. I cannot stress enough, no matter where you are in the Panhandle, it is time to find shelter.In a separate earlier chilling tweet, he said: Families under mandatory evacuation in the Panhandle and Big Bend need to move inland RIGHT NOW. The decisions you &amp your family make over the coming hours could be the difference between life &amp death.Hurricane Michael: Surfers brave churning conditions as the monster storm approaches (Image: Sky News)Mandatory evacuations are in place across the coast of Florida.Weather forecasters say 12 inches (10 to 30cm) of rain could be dumped in some areas, with flash flooding and storm surges likely.It is the strongest hurricane to come ashore along the Florida Panhandle in the last 150 years of recorded statistics, although no hurricane this strong has ever been recorded in the region.                Hurricane Michael 200 MILE WIND SPREAD: Florida, Georgia and CarolinasIn fact, Florida's entire Gulf Coast north of Punta Gorda has never recorded a Category 4 or higher hurricane landfall.And because the reliable record keeping of tropical cyclone data within the North Atlantic Ocean began in 1851, this could mean Michael will be the strongest hurricane to make landfall in the area ever.Only three major hurricanes Category 3 have struck the Panhandle since 1950: Eloise in 1975, Opal in 1995 and Dennis in 2005.This afternoon, a NOAA spokesman noted the unprecedented scale of the storm.He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos important to not focus just on the core of the storm.&ldquoThis is a huge storm, we are looking at a 200-mile wind spread from the centre so tropical-storm-force winds will be pulling out into portions of Alabama, even into portions of central Florida.&ldquoThis is going to be a devastating storm, possibly historical.

title: Hurricane Michael 2018 weather winds Panama City Florida latest update hurricanes 2018
story: Hurricane Michael is raging over Florida at Category 4 force with devastating winds of over 145mph.The shock footage shows as sheets of rain drive across a Panama City road and palm trees bend and shake under the pressure of the huge winds.Fears are growing that Hurricane Michael could swell to a potentially deadly Category 5 force - the strongest a hurricane can be of the Saffir-Simpson scale.Scott Pecoriello, from meteorological data analytics firm Weather Optics, warned Michael could possibly near Category 5 strength.He tweeted: A sign of extreme winds and further intensification. Sustained winds of 145 mph will destroy anything in its path.                 Hurricane Michael BOMBARDS Florida with 155mph windsNational Hurricane Center (NHC) Director Ken Graham said Michael was a &ldquotextbook case of a hurricane growing more powerful as it bore down on shore.Michael would maintain hurricane-force winds as it swept over Florida and Georgia and tropical storm-force winds when it hit the Carolinas, he added.Brett Rathbun, a meteorologist with AccuWeather, said: There doesn&rsquot seem to be any opportunity for this storm to weaken at all, and it may strengthen.Florida governor Rick Scott said: Hurricane Michael is forecast to be the most destructive hurricane to hit the Florida Panhandle in a century.Hurricane Michael: Wind speeds could reach over 14mph as Hurricane Michael hits (Image: Hurricane Zone)Category 5 storms exceed 157mph and are the most powerful on the Saffir-Simpson scale of hurricane intensity.&nbspMichael has propelled in power over recent days, reaching Category 2 on Tuesday and Category 4 on Wednesday.Deadly storm surges of up to 14ft are set to sweep across the US Gulf Coast.If Michael reaches Category 5 it would be only the fourth time a storm of such ferocity has lashed the US.The three previous Category 5 storms to strike were Andrew in 1992, Camille in 1969 and an unnamed storm in 1935.Category 5 storms can pulverise homes and buildings and cause power outages that last weeks.The NHC warns Category 5 hurricanes can wreak &ldquocatastrophic damage.

story: Michael was a Category 4 hurricane at landfall, with sustained winds of 155 miles per hour (249 km per hour).The NHC has described Michael as &ldquopotentially catastrophic as the intense Category 4 hurricane is packing top sustained winds of 145mph as it churned towards the Florida Panhandle on Wednesday.An NOAA spokesman said the hurricane had the potential to be &ldquohistorical in its impact on the US.He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos important to not focus just on the core of the storm. I didn't expect all this.Panama City, I don't know if there will be much left.Only a couple of hours after Michael came ashore, floodwaters already were more than 7-12 feet (2.3 meters) deep near Apalachicola, said Ken Graham, director of the National Hurricane Center.In a Facebook Live post, Mr Graham said Michael would sustain hurricane-strength winds as it pushed inland to the Alabama-Georgia border.People in coastal parts of 20 Florida counties had been told to head to safer locations but by Wednesday morning were told it was too late to flee.Much of the affected area is rural and known for small tourist cities, beaches and wildlife reserves, as well as the state capital, Tallahassee, home to about 190,000 people.The NHC has described Michael as &ldquopotentially catastrophic (Image: REUTERS)Only a couple of hours after Michael came ashore, floodwaters already were more than 7-12 feet (Image: )On Wednesday morning people were told it was too late to flee (Image: )Even before Michael made full landfall, it was whipping trees with its winds and flooding the town of Port St. Joe.Port St. Joe Mayor Bo Patterson said: &ldquoIt feels like you don't know when the next tree is going to fall on top of you because its blowing so ferociously.You just don't know when the next one is going down. It's very, very scary. We have trees being uprooted, heavy, heavy rain.Mr Patterson said about 2,500 of the town's 3,500 people were still there, including about 100 in a beachside area who ignored a mandatory evacuation order.Michael grew from a tropical storm to a Category 4 hurricane in about 40 hours (Image: ) (Image: )He added: &ldquoThis happened so quickly, we weren't exactly prepared.Michael grew from a tropical storm to a Category 4 hurricane in about 40 hours.Meteorologist with weather site Weather Underground, Bob Henson, said: Satellite images of Michael's evolution on Tuesday night were, in a word, jaw-dropping. title: Dow Jones stock market index shares points Nasdaq 100 Index Boeing china
story: The Dow Jones Industrial Average sunk as much as 836 points last night, with tech stock falling to its worst losses in seven years and the Nasdaq 100 Index plummeting more than four percent.As of just before 8am GMT, the Dow Jones average futures were down by 189 points.Computer companies led the S&ampP 500 to a fifth-day straight loss, the longest slump since President Donald Trump was elected,&nbspas Wall Street endured its sharpest one-day fall in months.Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Microsoft all fell more than 4 percent each as tech stock crashed.                European markets dented as US-China trade war tariffs take effect                 US v China: Trump's &lsquoAmerica first&rsquo policy could put USA LASTUS stocks plunge amid fears of Donald Trump sparking trade war with China (Image: Getty)The S&ampP 500 closed down 94 points with the broad market index heading for its worst day since June.Stock in all 30 blue-chip index companies fell, with Boeing and Caterpillar dropping at least 3.8 per cent.French luxury goods maker LVMH warned enforced Chinese customs rules are keeping trade tensions high, with concerns over US tariffs on&nbspUS tariffs on steel, aluminium and Chinese goods.Sameer Samana, a global quantitative and technical strategist for Wells Fargo Investment Institute, told Bloomberg: The biggest thing going on in markets is you&rsquore seeing an unwind.You had stocks doing really well, rates for the most part were very well-behaved.&nbsp                China trade: New tariffs imposed TODAY - China issues threat to TrumpFear stalks Wall Street as US shares slump in biggest fall for months (Image: Getty)Sameer Samana, global strategist at Wells Fargo Investment InstituteWhen you&rsquove got these risk-off moments, especially when you&rsquore later in the cycle, there is some concern on the part of investors where it&rsquos like, &lsquoIs this the beginning of the end'?Shares in the US energy sectors were hit hard as investors reacted to shutdowns sparked by Hurricane Michael in Florida and the Gulf of Mexico.Energy giants stopped production in the Gulf as the deadly storm raged towards the US.Oil firms Hess Corp and Marathon Oil fell around 7 per cent as Chevron dropped 3 per cent ahead of the third-quarter earnings season.Oliver Pursche, vice chairman and chief market strategist at Bruderman Asset Management, in New York, said: &ldquoThe big concern isn't really what third quarter earnings numbers are, but really what the outlook for the fourth quarter and first quarters are.US markets tumble on Wednesday ahead of third-quarter earnings season (Image: Getty)Dow falls more than 800 points as concern mounts over China trade war (Image: Getty)The Federal Reserve is raising interest rates which makes it more expensive for companies to borrow and harms share prices.The rout suggests businesses are not able to sustain the runaway growth that&rsquos marked 2018 so far.Investors are nervous a trade war would slash profits.Rising bond yields are raising the cost of borrowing to add to market fears.President Trump described the Fed as having &ldquogone crazy after walking off Air Force One in Erie, Pennsylvania for a rally.He said: I think the Fed is making a mistake. They are so tight. I think the Fed has gone crazy.Actually, it's a correction that we've been waiting for for a long time, but I really disagree with what the Fed is doing.

title: Earthquake Papua New Guinea Rabaul New Britain island magnitude 7 tremor quake
story: A massive magnitude 7 earthquake struck Papua New Guinea on Thursday morning (Image: USGS)The epicentre of the earthquake was located around 125 miles south-west of the town of Rabaul, at a depth of around 40km, according to the United States Geological Survey (USGS).The quake struck just before 7am local time on Thursday (10pm BST).There are currently no reports of damage or injuries.Constable Roy Michael commented on the earthquake from Rabaul, saying: &ldquoWe felt the earthquake a bit, but it was not too strong.                Planets to align and trigger major quake in days - Earthquake forecastHe reported there was no damage in the town, but noted officers had not yet been able to access villages closer to the epicentre.The USGS said there was a &ldquolow likelihood of casualties and damage.However, it added: &ldquoRecent earthquakes in this area have caused secondary hazard such as tsunamis, landslides and liquefaction that might have contributed to loses.The Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre reported that waves of less than 0.3 metres could be witnessed along Papua New Guinea&rsquos coastline and the neighbouring Solomon Islands.A 7.5 magnitude earthquake struck Indonesia on September 28, triggering a devastating tsunami (Image: )However, Australia&rsquos Tsunami Warning Centre stated there was no risk to its coastline.David Walsh, an oceanographer at the Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre, said any tsunami triggered by the earthquake would only be witnessed in areas directly around the epicentre.The earthquake was initially recorded as magnitude 7.3, but was later downgraded to magnitude 7.The initial shock was followed by two further tremors shortly afterwards, which were magnitude 5 or greater.Papua New Guinea is located along the Pacific Ring of Fire, the most seismically active region in the world, where 90 percent of the world&rsquos earthquakes occur.                Haiti earthquake: Haiti rocked AGAIN by strong quakeAt least 2,000 people were killed after the earthquake and tsunami hit Palu and the surrounding area (Image: )The country was struck by a magnitude 7.5 earthquake in February, which killed at least 100 people.A magnitude 6.6 earthquake struck in March, but no casualties or damage were reported.Neighbouring Indonesia was struck by a 7.5 magnitude earthquake 48 miles from the provincial capital of Palu on September 28.The earthquake caused a severe tsunami to strike Palu, which led to the deaths of at least 2,000 people.It was the deadliest earthquake to strike the country since the 2006 Yogyakarta earthquake, and the deadliest worldwide in 2018.

title: Conor McGregor news Khabib Nurmagomedov Vladimir Putin UFC

UFC news: Conor McGregor strategy for Khabib, Nate Diaz out of UFC 230                Khabib Nurmagemdov sparks strong response from Vladimir PutinPutin told the boxer and his father: &ldquoIf we are attacked from the outside, not only you, we could all jump in such a way...there could be hell to pay.&ldquoBut it&rsquos better not to reach that stage.Whilst Nurmagomedov was declared the winner, retaining his lightweight title, he was escorted out by the police before the belt ceremony could take place.He was later given his belt in private, but his fee is being held back pending an investigation.The pair during the fight (Image: )Mr Nurmagomedov said Putin called him after the fight.He said: &ldquoMcGregor took a picture with PutinBut Putin called me and told me he is proud of me and he said congratulations.Mr Nurmagomedov apologised for his actions after the fight, explaining McGregor&rsquos insults in the build-up to the event had tested his patience and the provocation on the day pushed him over the edge. He talked about my religion, my country, my father. He came to Brooklyn, he broke bus and nearly killed two people.&ldquoSo why do people still talk about me jumping over the cage? I have shown respect.The fighter returned to his hometown of Dagestan on Monday and met thousands of fans at the Anzhi Arena in the regional capital, Makhachkala.Conor McGregor and Khabib Nurmagomedov fighting (Image: )Meanwhile, Floyd Mayweather has suggested both McGregor and Nurmagomedov will get large fines for their actions.He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos going to be a huge fine I&rsquom pretty sure because with my fight against Zab Judah, there was a crazy melee in the ring and a huge penalty - a huge fine.&ldquoIf I&rsquom not mistaken, seven figures.

title: ladybird invasion sti uk what to do
story: Thousands of people have reported swarms of the alien bugs besieging their homes.The Harlequin ladybird, also known as the Halloween Ladybug, carries a fungal STI that infects other insects, has an unpleasant stink and stains furniture.They eat other ladybirds and have even  been known to bite people.The invasion comes after seven schools in East London were shut due to an infestation of poisonous  widow spiders.Experts say the hot summer has boosted Harlequin bug numbers.They fly in from Asia and North America on mild autumn winds.Since first being spotted in Britain  years ago, the Harlequin is now the second most common species.It has sparked fears for native seven-spot and two-spot ladybirds.The latter’s numbers have halved since .Swarms of the foreign bugs have been reported  in Birmingham, Manchester, Norfolk, Loughborough and Gloucester.Man United defender Phil Jones and  former team-mate Jonny Evans, now with Leicester City, have both had to call in exterminators.Jonny’s we Helen tweeted: “They’re invading my house! Driving me mad!”Berwyn Evans, of Rentokil, said: “The unusually hot summer created perfect conditions for ladybirds to thrive.They seek buildings in large numbers to hibernate in over colder months.”Brits have taken to social media to share footage of the Harlequin iety of ladybirds swarm around doors and windows.Professor Helen Roy at the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, who organises the UK Ladybird Survey, told BBC: Its quite a wildle spectacle to see.She said that the reports had first started in the north of England as the weather started to turn.It comes after the Met Office last month confirmed the sky-high average temperatures of .C from June to August had made the summer a record-breaking scorcher.Experts said it was most likely the ladybirds spotted around homes were the invasive Harlequin.Reports of the red and black beetles have spread across the UK, with one woman in London writing: Attack of the Ladybirds update: its officially out of hand, I’ve lost control of the room.Pest controllers have said the Harlequin ladybirds are not harmful to humans eventhey do bite you.They can be a nuisance in your home as they usually dwell in clusters and can give off a strong-smelling, staining yellow liquid.But they can be hard to remove from your home.One option is to trying vacuuming them up, this is best to do when they appear to be sleeping as this gives you a better chance of catching them before they fly away andthey disperse then they will form a cluster in a new area and then risk staining another part of your home.It may be dficult to seal up any entrances are the insects are small but blocking up as many as possible may reduce the number getting in.You can hopefully clean up the yellow stains by wiping the surfaces with white vinegar.Another added they had the same problem in Warwick, West Midlands, saying: Warwick seems to be being taken over by ladybirds. They are everywhere!!A third also reported: Hundreds of #adybirds crawling all over the greenstone walls in Shaftesbury today.Harlequin ladybirds, scientic name Harmonia axyridis, are ladybirds that are not native to Britain.Experts have previously said the ladybirds reach Britain by hitching a lt on the warm southerly winds.The foreign creepy-crawlies are said to pose a threat to the domestic species because they carry a sexually-transmitted disease, called Laboulbeniales fungal disease.They are sometimes called the “Halloween ladybird” in the US because of the time of the year they flock.But there are actually , dferent species of ladybirds across the globe, with  dfernet types in the UK.The Harlequin ladybird is one of the newest insects to the block, appearing in Britain in .The beetles were introduced into mainland Europe from Asia, with it hoped they would help to control plant pests.Thriving here, they have even outcompeted some native ladybird species - even known to eat other ladybird larvae.To recognise the Harlequin ladybird from other British species, there are some telltale signs including:- Harlequin ladybirds are generally large, measuring about -mm- Their wing colour can be pale yellow-orange, orange-red, red or black highly iable- The pattern on their backs generally have zero to  orange-red or black spots* According to the Harlequin Ladybird SurveyThe deluge normally comes around this time of year, with a woman filming the insects pelting her countryside home as they sought shelter.Margaret, who lives just outside of Ickleton, Cambridgeshire, said the three-day pelting was like something out of Hitchcocks The Birds.Margaret said: I was lucky I noticed it was happening as they just came out of nowhere and started hitting the window and streaming in.It was a struggle to close the window as I didnt want to squash any of them and by then they were already all over the window frame.Its not the first time the loveliness of ladybirds have swarmed homes.Residents in the town of Lipova, in western Romania, were forced to seal up their homes after the beetles descended in .Locals said they were so many it was like a living carpet, and that they had to shovel them out.

title: jean claude juncker everything wrong with eu
story: He is everything that’s wrong with the European project — and why it’s so vital that we leave.In his latest rant, he demanded “respect” and delivered a warning that “Press freedom has its limits”. Why Alas, Luxembourg’s finest is annoyed that the media keep reporting on the persistent rumours that he is half-cut most of the time.He must be to think, as he does, that the UK would have voted Remainonly HE had been involved in the referendum. Fat chance. He’d have doubled the Leave vote.The trials and tribulations of Brexit might have made some wonderit’s all worth the hassle. So it’s good of Jean-Claude, a puffed-up political pygmy, to remind us why we’re better off out.Brexiteers need to keep their eyes on the prize. Attention-seeking bores like Andrew Adonis and Alastair Campbell, plus shadowy campaign outfits, are trying their hardest to undermine Brexit.Nobody should think this battle is won. Nobody should be complacent about political battles still to come.And nobody who believes in a prosperous, independent nation should allow the perfect to be the enemy of the good when it comes to Britain’s departure, and walk into the Remainers’ “people’s vote” trap.We leave in less than six months. And when we do, we’ll raise a glass. Maybe Jean-Claude will join us.THE Universal Credit system IS a good idea – but the roll-out must be done properly.The Tories’ benefit changes in the last Government, making it more rewarding to be in work, are a big part of the ­reason employment is at a record high. UC is the final part of that puzzle.But reports that some working families could lose signicant amounts of cash overnight are deeply worrying.Our benefits regime needs to be firm.But it must also be fair.BOB Geldof warns Britain will be a ­“cultural jail” after Brexit.Quite why the power to strike our own trade deals will affect our ability to play guitar isn’t yet clear.In fact, when it comes to music, it’s Britain’s institutions that are more­ ­dangerous. The BBC has decided in its infinite wisdom to publish its entire archive of classical music to compete with streaming services and record labels. Why  Just because it can It’s a decision that sums up the big-state, God-complex thinking that seeps right through the BBC.Lord Hall promised to change Auntie’s tune – but he’s still hitting the wrong notesOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: house prices mortgages young people
story: All they are trying to do is the right thing. But this is the reality of trying to save up for a house.They work hard each month. They’d love to put something aside to save up for a home.But to live where there are good jobs, they have to spend so much on high rents that there’s nothing left over.So they can never save enough to break out of the cycle. No wonder they are frustrated.New figures show how bad things have got. The Institute for Fiscal Studies says four out of ten people in the  to -year-old age bracket couldn’t afford the mortgage on even the cheapest house in their area, eventhey had a deposit.The gap between prices and normal people’s earnings is just too big, because since  house prices in Britain have gone up more than in any other developed country.Expensive housing has meant that the proportion of young people on middle incomes who own their own home has collapsed: down from nearly two thirds  years ago, to just over a quarter today.We have to turn this round and restore home ownership.Many people feel they can’t get on and start a family until they have a nest of their own. Their lives are on hold.Politically it’s vital too. If young people don’t feel they’ve got a chance to get on in le, they are more likely to gamble and vote for extreme, disastrous politicians like Jeremy Corbyn.Even younger people who are earning decent wages feel squeezed, because they face a combination of high house prices and chunky repayments on their student loans.The Prime Minister is acutely aware of this. That’s why she’s set up a review of student fees, and moved to make housing her Number  priority other than Brexit.Hence her announcement of massive funding to build more affordable housing for people on lower incomes. But there’s much more to do.Building more homes for people to buy is a big part of the answer. Since  we have built only half as many houses as France each year, and so house prices have gone up twice as fast.Some people say building more means we must tear up the planning system and concrete over the countryside.But we know that approach won’t work. When Gordon Brown was PM we tried setting each area massive housing targets. All those targets built was resentment. We need a smarter approach to tackle the reasons people often oppose new housing.We build in the wrong places. Instead of tacking on new estates to existing towns and villages without enough new school places or parking places, let’s get back into the business of building planned new cities and towns.Let’s build upwards in our city centres with taller buildings, rather than just sprawling cities outwards.What drives people mad is seeing developers make massive windfall profits when they get planning permission, but then not sharing those benefits with local residents.Imagine instead,new houses being built next door always paid for people in neighbouring streets to get cheap homes for their children to buy. People would feel much better about development.Restoring the dream of home ownership isn’t just about building more houses though.We need to think about the balance of rented properties and home ownership. Over the last ten years we’ve built many new homes each year, but the number of homeowners fell. How come The reason is that the number of properties being snapped up by buy-to-let landlords has grown faster than we have built new ones.Don’t get me wrong. Landlords, who have themselves worked hard, weren’t doing anything wrong.Butwe want to get home ownership growing again we need to encourage savers to put their money into shares and into growing businesses rather than just bidding up the price of houses. The think tank Onward proposed this week that we should offer a tax break to landlords who sell their homes to their tenants.This “Chance to Buy” would be a bit like the Right to Buy Margaret Thatcher introduced for council tenants. It could be paid for by tax changes which would discourage people from buying up new buy-to-let properties.So fewer landlords, more homeowners.Young people just want the same chances previous generations enjoyed. So let’s build more by building smarter, and give a new generation the chance to buy a home.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: arlene foster was right to stick it to michel barnier but why did she have to
story: But why did she have to It is surely already obvious to him, and our Government, that the Tories will be sunk by any Brexit proposal iding Northern Ireland from the mainland.Barnier just keeps trying it on.Downing Street indulge him. But the DUP, on whom they rely, won’t be bounced into it.And Ms Foster’s preferred solution to the absurdly over-hyped Irish border “problem” is right too: using the customs technology even Barnier admits would work where.Our Government must hold firm to its commitment to opt for No Deal over the bad ones Brussels aims to force us into.The Treasury is finally preparing for radical cuts in red tape to boost our economy in that event.Germany’s firms are starting to panic about the potential collapse of their exports to the UK.Do not flinch, Theresa. Once the EU realise we aren’t bluffing they will make a deal . . . and the border issue will be fixed in no time.CORBYN’S Labour is a cesspit of hypocrisy.It makes political capital out of those needing food banks and payday lenders, or working on zero-hours ­contracts, while apparently exploiting them itself.Some Labour staff claim to be so badly paid in their insecure jobs that that’s exactly what they are reduced to.Labour has always been the “Do as I say, not as I do” party. It’s just worse now than ever.Its senior MPs rail against public schools, but send their kids to them.Its supporters consider themselves “erse”, “inclusive” and morally superior, then heap ­racist abuse on the black Tory candidate for London Mayor.Labour laughably insists it “does not tolerate racism of any kind”. What a transparent lie. It DOES tolerate it: its Jew-hatred goes to the very top.Indeed, without hate, Corbyn’s mob would have nothing to sustain them at all.WHY are our justice and benefit systems, and a local council, bending over backwards to appease a convicted terrorist This vile woman has turned down seven council houses and even a £, deposit from taxpayers to buy her own. She has been put up in BBs for months at huge public expense.She still has the gall to whine about her human rights. And she is still allowed to remain anonymous.Given that we cannot deport her, and have a duty to house her children, she should be given this choice:The next flat, wherever it comes up.Or winter in a shop doorway — and her sons taken into care.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: university professor reveals the must have items for an end of the world survival kit and it includes a condom and lip balm
story: A detailed study also found around one in six have considered putting together a survival kit.Among the most common items we would rush to shove into a bag before escaping an invasion of the walking dead are food, water, weapons - and condoms.A first aid kit and tampons also made the list of must-have items along with water bottles, torches and matches.The bad news is, despite being in the advanced stages of preparation, close to one in ten believe they may only be able to live for a week in a post-apocalyptic world.Most believe it will all kick off in New York City, with London second on the list.The research was commissioned by streaming service NOW TV to celebrate theof The Walking Dead, with Season  available to watch now with a NOW TV Entertainment Pass.NOW TV also partnered with zombie expert Professor Lewis Dartnell, who put together a list of tips on how to survive an attack - and even created escape routes for residents of London and Manchester.According to Prof. Dartnell’s guide your first focus should be getting out of populated areas, not head to the loft which was the first choice of one in three who took part in the research.Dartnell said: “Not only will they become the densest concentrations of zombies, but modern urbanized areas simply won’t be habitable once the technological bubble that supports them disappears: no electricity, running water or gas.“Very large numbers of people would succumb almost immediately in the packed cities. The ‘average’ survival time would be a matter of days.Leave your house behind and head for isolation and make your first destination a camping shop for warm clothing, waterproofs and some sturdy hiking boots.Rely on a car GPS device instead of smart phone maps – you’ll soon be losing phone signal when power grids go down.Dartnell, who is a professor of science communication at the University of Westminster, and wrote The Knowledge: How to Rebuild our World from Scratch, added: Chapstick, Vaseline and hairspray are all great for helping get a fire started in dficult conditionsWith regard to weapons I suggest relying on your own ingenuity and resourcefulness, fashioning what you need from metal pipes or nails.”The study of , Brits also found the average adult believes they could evade a zombie bite for just over nine weeks,  hours and  minutes.Even NOW TV’s The Walking Dead could double up as a survival tool, as  per cent said they would scour Zombie TV shows for tips on how to stay alive.Make your first destination a camping shop for warm clothing, waterproofs and hiking boots. You’ll be spending a lot of time outdoors, and when you’re running away you don’t want to slip and break an ankle.Buy iodine tablets to pury water once the taps run dry. There’s no point in surviving a zombie attackyou’re just going to die from a waterborne disease.Rely on a car GPS device instead of smart phone maps to find minor roads.  You’ll lose phone signal when power grids go down.A plastic bottle must become your new best friend. If it’s summer, disinfecting drinking water by simply leaving it in the sun for a day can become a regular part of your routine An unraveled tampon makes an ideal dressing to stop a wound bleeding, and it’s perfect kindling for starting a fire.A condom can hold over a gallon of water. Don’t let it rupture in your bag.Chapstick, Vaseline and hairspray - all great for helping get a fire started in dficult conditions.Once the refined fuels have disappeared, cars can actually be run using wood as fuel. The process is called ‘gasication’ and was common in WWII. Leave your house behind and head for isolation.Get out of the city. Not only will they have the highest concentrations of roamers, but urban areas simply won’t be habitable once technology disappears.Head into the countryside and find traditional buildings with fireplaces and wells. A seaside region near a large wood is your ideal new home, offering you access to a wide range of natural resources.Ideally, a secluded spot with high walls or fences will help keep the swarms of walkers out when you’re settling down more permanently.Stick together - youll never survive the apocalypse as a lone wolf. Theres safety in numbers, but be careful who you pick as friends.Send scouting parties to find other pockets of survivors, or rig-up a radio transmitter.In the early stages of a zombie attack you can scavenge food from abandoned supermarkets or distribution centres. Prioritise canned food that will keep for years.If you forget your tin opener grind the top of the can in flat circles pushing down onto a paving slab. You’ll quickly wear away the thin metal lip and get that lid off.The power grid is out: but don’t worry, you can stay connected. Scavenge a mobile generator from roadworks.When the diesel runs out, you will need renewables: scavenge solar  or small wind turbines.The best kind of rechargeable battery is a deep-cycle lead acid battery. Scavenge these from things like golf buggies. Surprisingly, a golf course is one of the most practical places to head for after an apocalypse.Always dig your DIY loos at least  meters away from your water source and downhill, for obvious reasons.Washing your hands. Soap can be made from scratch by soaking water through the ashes of burned seaweed to extract soda, and then reacting this with slaked limeto make caustic soda. Boil this with lard, or any other animal fat or plant oil, to make soap.If you injure yourself, attend to the wound immediately. You can disinfect with alcohol and then close the wound with superglue.Stream season  of The Walking Dead now on NOW TV with a contract-free Entertainment Pass. The show s Mondays at pm on FOX.

title: mh370 search cambodia jungle flight path latest
story: British video producer Ian Wilson believes he has spotted the doomed plane, which vanished on March , , by spending hours searching online.Images from Google Maps show the outline of a large plane in a remote part of southern Cambodia  – which could simply be an aircraft flying directly below the satellite which photographed it.But in the latest twist to the saga, Google Earth’sdate and imagery date for the picture have been listed as dferent years in recent weeks, reports The Daily Star.This has led to speculation the supposed wreckage has been snapped several times in the past by the tech giant’s satellites - ruling out the theory that Wilsons picture shows a plane in flight.While the current imagery date is listed as March , last week it was reportedly published as December .It has also been claimed the outline of the plane was spotted in May, , using Google Maps – more than two months after the jet vanished.Wilson believes this adds further credence to his theory and says he plans to visit the site with his brother in the next fortnight– in a bid to capture the £million finder’s fee.He told the Star: “After much discussion last night, we’re just organising final vaccinations and the hiring of guides.”However, aviation expert Yijun Yu puts the imagery date mystery down to either a system glitch or that Google hasn’t updated its pictures for the spot.Despite this, the academic believes the US company should clary the situation.He said: “If they cached the image since , it is either the satellite they use never updated the datasets for four years, or there is a system glitch.Other sources from China suggest that the image cannot be confirmed from another satellite.In September, a Chinese satellite firm Space View investigated Wilson claim and zoomed in on the location in the South East Asian country.However, the company claims there was no sign of any plane, least of all the Malaysian Airlines aircraft which went missing en route to Beijing from Kuala LumpurIn a tweet, Space View wrote: “Stakeholders and bystanders plead Space View to shoot at the site.So we found out three images, shot in ,  and  from our archive.Sorry, no plane found there.

title: mum humiliated age uk staff surrey charity shop
story: Hairdresser Vicki Jamieson, , was in an Age UK shop in Surrey with her two toddler twins when her boy Teddy left a puddle of urine on the floor.The busy mum tried to keep an eye on her twins and clean up the mess while staff watched and tutted, she claims.She said she left the shop on September  at around pm feeling humiliated and had to change her boy’s clothes in the street near a block of flats even though there were changing rooms in the Frimley High Street shop.Vicki told Surrey Live: “I was disappointed. The staff were no help whatsoever.My son thought he’d done something badly wrong, but he’d only just been potty trained.“Teddy was stood there wet and they were complaining about having to bleach the floor.I had wee on my trousers and on my hands, and I cleaned it all up with baby wipes.I saw a shop worker look over, they tutted, shook their head and shrugged their shoulders.“There was a changing room but I just wanted to get out of the shop. I had to change Teddy outside a block of flats where people could see.“There were three staff members and about eight customers. That’s quite embarrassing. If that was me, I would’ve offered to help, or offered a clean pair of trousers.”Steve Wooldridge, head of retail operations at Age UK, said: We want our Age UK shops to be friendly and welcoming places for all our customers, including young families, so we’re sorry this mum and her youngster did not have a good experience on this occasion. We’ll aim to do better next time.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: ageing celeb mums blamed
story: Experts said the Janet Jackson Effect has made old age pregnancies seem normal.But they warned older couples are failing to consider the risks to the mother and the trauma it inflicts on the child.Kids can fear coming home in case they find their parents dead and face the burden of looking after a pensioner, it is claimed.And they feel embarrassed when their mum or dad is mistaken for a grandparent.Psychologists said the “rosy pregnancies” portrayed by celebrities was making more women consider IVF in their fties.And this is likely to extend into their sixties, the worlds largest fertility conference heard.Singer Jackson had a baby two years ago at the age of  and actress Brigitte Nin gave birth this year aged .The number of Brits having babies aged + has increased ten fold from two in  to  in .Dr Julia Woodward, from Duke Fertility Center, in North Carolina, said: “A lot of media reporting on older pregnancies is in an incredibly positive way .There is no mention of donor eggs, premature delivery or complications.It is a rosy Janet Jackson pregnancy that gets celebrated.Young women are being taught that you can wait to get pregnant without consequence but this is the wrong data.”Dr Julianne Zweel, from the University of Wisconsin, said: “The drive to be a mother is so strong they don’t think about the problems their child will face until after the child is born.“Increasingly we are seeing women in their sixties approaching clinics to have children.”The pair told the annual meeting of the American Society for Reproductive Medicine, in Denver, US, that some couples fail to realise women are not fertile forever.There were  babies born to women aged between  and  in England in , rising to  in And among women aged  to , there were  babies born in  and  in , figures from the Office for National Statistics show.In ,  year-old Elizabeth Adeney from Suffolk became the UK’s oldest mum when she gave birth to son Jolyon.Prof Geeta Nargund, medical director of Create Fertility, in the UK, said: “I think the number of women in their fties doing this will rise even further and it can cost the NHS hundreds of thousands of pounds to deal with pregnancy and neonatal complications such as miscarriages, preeclampsia, multiple births and stillbirth in these women.The older fathers linked to these women also have children with a greater risk of autism and psychiatric dficulties.Children and teenagers need their parents to look after them, not the other way around.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fat people face most prejudice
story: The World Obesity Federation report said  per cent of of adults in the UK believed people were more likely to suffer discrimination for being overweight - more than any other category.And almost half suffered stigma and discrimination due to their weight that put them off looking for help from their GP or hospital.Johanna Ralston, chief executive of the World Obesity Federation called for better education for medical students and healthcare workers.She blasted: “People are being blamed for obesity, but decades of public health research show that obesity is complex and there are multiple causes.“Despite this, society at large continues to treat people with obesity unfairly. Stigmatising obesity undermines people’s health and makes it harder to seek support.”The Federation also called on social media companies to clamp down on weight abuse online after a snapshot poll found many social media users were using discriminatory language on sites.The research showed the impact was far reaching and damaged people’s career prospects and could lead to social isolation.Based on an academic study, the report highlighted the common the use of negative images used by media when reporting on obesity.Looking at online media in  countries, outlets in South Africa, Hong Kong and Italy were found to be the most stigmatising, but authors said all the countries examined showed some bias.The report also highlights words and phrases to avoid for the obese including “fatty”, “chubster”, “flabby”, “supersized” and “mammoth”.It said instead people should use the terms “iniduals with a high BMI” and “people living with obesity”.Ms Ralston added: “This World Obesity Day we’re calling on the media to reshape the narrative around obesity and for social media companies to clamp down on weight abuse online.“Changing the narrative around diseases and conditions can transform public perceptions and improve quality of le and outcomes for patients.“As obesity rates continue to rise, we’re also appealing to the medical education authorities and providers to improve specialist education in medical schools, as people with obesity are often dismissed by their healthcare professional because of their weight without being properly diagnosed.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: amelia wood life saver

Amelia giving her organs gives them a second chance.A total of four patients have since received the gt of le after Amelia gave her organs for transplant following her death.Hayley travelled to Leeds, West Yorks., to meet Daniel and his parents.She added: It was like going to a friend’s house. title: ed sheeran elton john miss eugenie wedding

title: hurricane michael could swamp florida with toxic red tide algal bloom that releases fume like tear gas
story: The catastrophic storm made landfall in Florida this evening, battering the coast with mph winds.Those winds have already torn apart homes in the Panhandle, destroyed a half-finished building and ripped off metal roofs.Michael could drive sea water levels as high as ft above normal in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said.This means it could bring the red tide, a type of alage which kills fish and releases harmful toxins, inland with it, Bloomberg reports.Scientists have said the surge could bring the algae, whose effects have been likened to tear gas, past the beaches and into neighbourhoods.Professor Larry Brand of the Department of Marine Biology and Ecology in Miami said: A storm surge or king tide could bring red tide up onto land.The toxin would get into the air and people would be breathing it.Red tide contains an organism called Karenia Brevis which triggers attacks in those who suffer from asthma.But even those who do not can be struck down with coughing fits, choking and stinging eyes.Buildings along the coast have already destroyed by the catastrophic storm, one of the most powerful to ever hit the US.Michael made landfall near Mexico Beach, a tourist town along the Panhandle, a -mile stretch of white-sand beach resorts, fishing towns and military bases.The hurricane swamped streets, bent trees, stripped away branches and sent building debris flying across the beachfront.The window to evacuate has come to a close, said Federal Emergency Management Agency administrator Brock Long.It began unexpectedly from a weekend tropical depression, becoming a furious Category  by early Wednesday, up from a Category  less than a day earlier.The storm has the potential to drive sea water levels as high as ft above normal in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said.It comes just hours after Florida governor Rick Scott warned locals it was too late to flee and he was scared to death people had ignored evacuation orders.

title: britain hidden debt world ranking
story: A major report by the IMF reassessed  major nations’ net worth, balancing how much each owns to each owes.Only Portugal fared worse than the UK, as it emerges the Government now has eye-watering liabilities of more than £trillion – which is more than % of our entire annual GDP.The international financial watchdog last night warned that this leaves the UK dangerously exposed to the next economic downturn.The IMF looked at every state’s assets, from land to energy resources, as well as what they are on the hook for, from pensions to stakes in banks and regular borrowing.Even previously troubled states like El Salvador, Brazil and Albania have less liabilities than Britain.Norway has the healthiest outlook because of its massive oil and gas reserves, followed closely by Russia.Britain’s new debt hole has largely been created by the financial crisis, which hit us harder than most other countries.The Labour and then Coalition governments sold off a lot of what they owned to give a short term boost to public finances.The findings in the IMF’s annual Fiscal Monitor are a major blow to Philip Hammond just a few weeks before he delivers his Budget on October .But yesterday’s monthly GDP figures gave the Chancellor a small boost, confirming the summer’s growth from extra retail sales has been maintained.The economy grew by .% in the three months to August. But in a darker cloud, the Office of National Statistics also found growth has since ground to a halt.A Treasury Spokesperson said: “Our debt is starting to fall, so we can spend less on debt repayments and invest more in public services, while keeping taxes as low as possible.“The economy continues to grow with retail, food and drink all performing well during the summer.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: big firms ethnic minorities
story: The Prime Minister has signed up some of the UK’s biggest organisations including the Armed Forces, NHS and banks in a bid to eradicate ethnicity pay discrimination after a damning probe revealed a massive pay gap.The pledge comes a year after a damning race disparity audit revealed shocking discrimination in the workplace - title: westminster palace refurb cost 2021
story: A draft bill to set up organisations to oversee the project could be introduced by the end of October, Leader of the House Andrea Leadsom told the Commons’ Finance Committee.But she said that it would take another three years for the full scope of the project to be finalised and put before MPs.The Grade  listed palace in the heart of London is set to close in the middle of the s as it undergoes a massive restoration programme, estimated currently to take at least six years.Mrs Leadsom told the committee: “Once the bodies are set up in statute there is then a process to get to the outline business case that both houses would be voting on.“That is likely to take about three years for that full business case to be set out.It is only at that point we will have proper costings and proper timings.Tom Healey, director of the restoration and renewal project, who joined Mrs Leadsom for questions from MPs agreed with her time estimate, saying: “We think to get to the stage where we have a concept design with an associated outline business case is about three years’ work.“We started that work already, we started as soon as we got the decision in principle so we think three years from, roughly speaking, the middle of this year, so mid-.”In January MPs supported a “full and timely decant” of both Houses of Parliament during the multibillion-pound restoration programme.Ms Leadsom hopes the Elizabeth Tower will remain open to the public while the refurbishments are going onMrs Leadsom said that the first bill, to set up delivery bodies and establish their powers and relationships, was almost ready to go, adding: “I am fully committed to doing everything I can to get that draft bill introduced this month.”She also told the committee that it was hoped that the
