title: brexit arelene foster theresa may
story: The Ulster Unionists threatened the explosive move after being left livid by the latest turn in Brussels negotiations.With just six days to go until an EU summit to finalise a deal, they fear Theresa May is on the verge of betraying them by enforcing new checks on trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.Any government’s failure to pass its annual financial blueprint in the Commons has traditionally been seen as a confidence vote in it.But as a war of words escalated, Downing Street swtly hit back to insist the PM would not be forced to quitthe DUP carried out a threat under recent rule changes in the Fixed Terms Parliament Act.No sources also insisted the move would be a clear breach of the Tory-DUP confidence and supply agreement – meaning Ulster would also have to pay back its £bn bonus from the government.And in an alarming show of force last night, the DUP’s  MPs abstained in a routine vote on the government’s Agriculture Bill.DUP Leader Arlene Foster issued another blunt warning to Mrs May from Brussels yesterday after a second day of talks with EU negotiators.Ms Foster said: “We’ve been telling people about our red line, we’ve been talking them through it.“The PM has made a lot of her Unionist credentials over the years since she moved into Downing Street.“So what’s important is for us to say to her very clearly that any impediment on the two way access in the UK single market would not be good for the union and would not be good for the economy of Northern Ireland.”As tensions also continued to arise ahead of next week’s EU showdown on the Tory benches, Mrs May also stunned her backbench Brexiteers by making her first open appeal to Labour MPs to vote through any Brexit deal she can forge.The PM’s plea is a bid to bypass as many as  Tory hardliners who have vowed to vote down any deal based around her softer Brexit blueprint.She told the Commons: “When we come back with a deal, I would hope everybody across this whole house would put the national interest first”.Senior Cabinet ministers have been summoned to No at pm this afternoon for an update from Mrs May on the tense negotiations. But No aides played down hopes of any break through, with one telling The Sun: “We’re a way off yet”.Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson also issued a fresh attack on the PM to warn that the Government’s “backstop” proposals for Northern Ireland would make the UK “a permanent EU colony”.Labour MPs also dismissed claims that  of them will defy their own party whip top vote for the PM’s deal, saying Mrs May would struggler to even persuade over  of them.Mr Corbyn’s spokesman said: “It’s quite clear that the Prime minister is in a very dficult position because she spent most of the last two years negotiating with her own party and not with the European Union and the prospects of a signicant rebellion among her own MPs is pretty clear. So it’s not surprising that she’s trying to find support where and we’ve made very clear what kind of package we would support and what we won’t.”The EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier last night said a Brexit deal is “within reach”, raising hopes of a breakthrough at next Wednesday’s crucial summit and boosting the pound.Amid expectations of a compromise on the Irish border, he hit back at Arlene Foster’s claim the EU’s backstop would devastate Northern Ireland’s economy.But he warned some checks between Northern Ireland and mainland Britain will increase tenfoldthe UK doesn’t stay in the customs union.Speaking to business leaders in Brussels the Frenchman said there “must be checks on goods travelling between the EU and UK that don’t exist today”.He said all live animals and animal derived food will have to be checked compared to just % now, which was “a signicant change in terms of scale”.Under his backstop plan other goods would be subject to “scanning barcodes on ferries or in transit ports” helped by Max Fac style trusted trader schemes.Mr Barnier said: “There must be checks on goods travelling between the EU and the UK – checks that do not exist today.“We’re still open to the idea of a customs union with the UK which would eliminate an important part of customs checks.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chip shops refuse to serve obese man
story: Posters featuring Darren McClintocks photo have been put up in fast food outlets around his home town warning Do Not Serve This Man.Darren, , better known as Dibsy, has teamed up with trainer Mike Hind to turn his le around after a le or death health scare.And, although he will still be allowed treats, he hopes the leaflets will help him keep his vow to ditch fast food.The leaflets distributed around Middlesborough read: Save Dibsy, Obesity Is Killing Him. Do Not Serve This Man.Dibsy has to book two seats on a planehe wants to go abroad and says his weight means he can’t learn to drive. He also has to order clothes that are specially sized - at an extra cost.He added: “I have struggled with my weight all my le, I have tried all sorts. There have been points where I have got down. I have let myself down massively.“I have been given this one chance, I’m going to make the most of it, I’m going to seize every opportunity I have got.”Mike said: The next six or seven weeks is going to get dficult for Dibsy.What I want Dibsy to do is come to me for support and advice - hes used to turning to takeaways.Each year Mike takes on a client for free in a bid to turn their le around and receives around a thousand applications but was drawn to Dibsy when he saw him with his mum at his gyms diner.His mum burst out crying and said no parent would want to bury her child, Mike said.It was then he decided to take on the challenge to help Dibsy lose weight.Mike was crowned the UKs top personal trainer last year.

title: mrs mcmafia unmasked harrods zamira hajiyeva
story: She lost a court bid this week to stop her being named as the first person probed under the UK’s new “McMafia” laws.Husband Jahangir Hajiyev is serving  years in jail for stealing more than £million in his role as chairman of Azerbaijan’s state bank.He earned £, a year but has an estimated £million fortune — which the family claim came from shrewd business deals.Mrs Hajiyeva, , fled the ex-Soviet state and remains on its Most Wanted list, while living in a £million home minutes from Harrods. She denies doing anything illegal.But her lavish lestyle is the subject of an Unexplained Wealth Order— a new power that allows the National Crime Agency to force foreigners to reveal the source of their wealth. She is appealing against the order.The NCA says she used  credit cards all linked to her husband’s bank in her ten-year Harrods spree.She spent £, on a piece of Cartier jewellery and three Boucheron items worth £,.She splurged £, on luxury men’s goods and £, on wine.Records show she also owns two parking spaces under the store at an estimated cost of £, a year.The NCA also alleges she used fraudulent funds to buy the couple’s nearby home in Knightsbridge, West London, for £.million in .It was secured with a £million deposit and the mortgage cleared in five years. The NCA said it had been bought in an “unusual and secretive manner” through shell companies.Mrs Hajiyeva may have the home confiscatedthe NCA is successful.Mrs Hajiyeva says the purchase of the property “was my husband’s responsibility”, and she has “no knowledge of any of the payments”.A neighbour said: “I’ve seen her walking her little dog around, but we don’t really talk to the neighbours. It’s why you buy a house in the area, and part of its charm.”A second offshore company, of which Mrs Hajiyeva is a benefactor, owns Mill Ride Golf  Country Club in Ascot, worth nearly £million.General manager Robin Greenwood told The Sun: “We have dealings with the parent company, but have never dealt with her. We don’t know anything about this.”A company linked to her husband owns a £million Gulfsteam jet.Europe’s business leaders named Mr Hajiyev as Best Banker in a Crisis for his role in leading Azerbaijan through the  crash. He resigned in , and was later convicted of fraud and jailed for  years of hard labour. Courts there also ordered him to pay back £million. He has since been on hunger strike and claims his trial was politically motivated. His we was arrested in her absence on charges of misappropriation of state funds.In court documents, the NCA said there was “reliable evidence which suggests that Mr Hajiyev was a state employee in Azerbaijan between  to . It is very unlikely that such a position would have generated sufficient income to fund the acquisition of theproperty.”In immigration papers sent to the Home Office ten years ago, the couple said that they had access to at least £million and were handed indefinite investment visas.Court documents also reveal Mrs Hajiyev was handed £million by her husband for a Tier  investment visa, and around £, a month to maintain her lestyle.She told the High Court in a witness statement: “My husband was in  a man of substantial means. He was very well-off when we married in  and has accumulated capital and wealth since the early s.” Mrs Hajiyeva is appealing against the UWO. Barrister James Lewis is fighting her case at a cost of £ an hour.Authorities are able to freeze and recover propertyiniduals can’t explain how they acquired assets worth more than £,.The National Crime Agency, HMRC, the Financial Conduct Authority, Serious Fraud Office, and Crown Prosecution Service can all apply for UWOs.They can also be applied to politicians outside the European Economic Area entrusted with a prominent public position.Solicitor Thomas Garner, also part of the legal team, said: “The decision of the High Court upholding the grant of a UWO does not and should not be taken to imply any wrongdoing, whether on her part or that of her husband.”Duncan Hames, of Transparency International UK, said: “We are delighted that this first case is progressing in court, underlining the effectiveness of UWOs. They should now be used more widely to pursue more of the £.billion worth of suspicious wealth we have identied across the UK.”Donald Toon, from the NCA, said it was “determined to ensure the UK is not seen as a soft target for the investment of illicit finance”.He added: “Where we cannot determine a legitimate source for the funds used to purchase assets and prime property, it is absolutely right that we ask probing questions to uncover their origin.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gutless knight sir craig mackey

title: brexit theresa may conservative labour
story: We understand her desperation to avoid no-deal.It would be damaging for both sides, which is why German and Spanish businesses are panicking.But to challenge the DUP to like her deal or lump it, when they are openly threatening to defeat the Budget, looks reckless.Eventhey don’t, she still needs their votes to govern post-Brexit.And can the Prime Minister really trust the supposedly sensible wing of the Labour Party to make up the numbers on the final deal The worst of it, though, is agreeing to stay in the EU’s Customs Union “temporarily” but with no firm exit date.It is simply dishonest to spend two years talking up our golden opportunities to embrace global free trade and new industriesyou know that, in ­reality, we could be trapped forever in a deal that snuffs them out.We MUST be out of the Customs Union by the next election.Our future and the Government’s survival depend on it.NOTHING is more toxic to a party’s fortunes than betraying promises to voters.Brown did it. Clegg too. Theresa May doesn’t seem to have learned the lesson.Announcing that “austerity is over” looks hasty. Corbyn will throw it back at her whenever ANY spending is cut.The same goes for the PM’s manesto pledges to cut tax on “businesses and working families”.Chancellor Philip Hammond plainly intends the opposite to fund her NHS splurge.The Tories claim “we will always be a party of low tax”. How, with the overall burden already at a -year high FOR all the gloom, it could be worse. We could be victims of John McDonnell’s socialist fantasy, as the children dying of hunger in Venezuela are.Inflation there has hit ten million per cent. Yes, you read that right.The squalor and misery are almost unimaginable. Yet just four years ago the Shadow Chancellor rejoiced that the once-rich South American country was now experiencing “socialism in action”.The warning signs of collapse were already there. Essentials were running out. Renationalisations, price controls, the trampling on the rule of law and lack of private investment saw to that.McDonnell ignored it all. And he won’t care one bitwe suffer such horrors too. His lelong dream is to unleash the same lunatic experiment here.Voters, and Labour’s own more moderate MPs, must never give him that chance.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: election bomb plot washington dc
story: Paul Rosenfeld, , was charged Wednesday with building an a bomb after reportedly being caught with  stone worth of explosives in his New York home.Police say he planned to detonate it on the National Mall in Washington.He wanted to draw attention to a political system called sortition, in which public officials are chosen randomly rather than elected.The FBI raided Rosenfelds home on Tuesday and found a al bomb in his basement that consisted of black powder inside a plywood box.Agents also found empty canisters of black powder often used in firearms and artillery.It was not immediately clear whether Rosenfeld had an attorney.The FBI said in court filings that Rosenfeld, after being pulled over on Tuesday, confessed to ordering large quantities of black powder over the internet and having the substance delivered to a location in New Jersey.Rosenfeld took the black powder to New York, constructed smaller explosive devices and conducted test detonations, according to the criminal complaint.William Sweeney Jr, the assistant director of the FBIs New York field office, said in a statement that Rosenfeld intended to detonate a large explosive to kill himself and draw attention to his radical beliefs.Had he been successful, Rosenfelds alleged plot could have claimed the lives of innocent bystanders and caused untold destruction, Sweeney said in the statement.Fortunately, his plans were thwarted by the quick action of a concerned citizen and the diligent work of a host of our law enforcement partners and the FBIs Joint Terrorism Task Force.Rosenfeld had an initial court appearance before a magistrate at a federal courthouse in White Plains on Wednesday afternoon.

title: echo of the past the rise of germanys far right
story: Hes right. The mood, especially in the East, is turning. A backlash against Germanys immigration policy and a pick-up in migrant-related crime. Its very far from being just the neo-Nazis. The populist Alternative for Germany party or AfD has made huge gains off the back of its anti-migrant messaging. It is now the largest opposition party in the parliament with a loud and heckling voice to match. It is hoovering up voters disenchanted with the centrist parties and it is emboldening the extremist fringe.The pot boiled over in August in the city of Chemnitz. A German citizen was fatally stabbed in a fight with two asylum seekers. Straight away the far right rallied, but in the days that followed thousands of concerned citizens came out too - angry that they should feel unsafe on their streets and angry at what they called the lying press for refusing to hear their point of view. "Im not a Nazi but..." was a common refrain from people who felt that simply voicing their concerns on migration would see them labelled as such. The mainstream media was accused of backing Mrs Merkel and being on the side of refugees. "Luegenpresse"echoed through the streets, a term coined by Hitlers propaganda minister Joseph Goebbels. Not a huge leap from there to Donald Trumps "enemy of the people".The AfD has capitalised on this kind of sentiment, stirring the pot through social media to embellish the migrant threat and playing on the notion of victimhood to further its cause. The gist of it being that the German people are both the victims of an influx of asylum seekers who threaten to destroy the very notion of the homeland and the victims of a mainstream media which seeks to besmirch their good name. Talk of rapes, the threat to German wives and daughters, "kne migration", catch on especially in the former East where contact with foreigners under socialism was few and far between. In Chemnitz the AfD held a memorial procession for the German victims of migrant-related crime. The partys leader in Thuringia, Bjoern Hoecke, was up front. He was strongly criticised for the company he was keeping, marching alongside the anti-Islam Pegida group with neo-Nazi and skinheads among the crowds."With a procession of , people attending you cant fully control whos walking along and who isnt," he said.

title: food complete rat droppings maggots
story: NewsWhat Brexit trade deal with Trump could look like - food with rat droppings, maggots and mouldUS producers are allowed one maggot per mm of orange juice and  insect fragments in a g jar of peanut butter, according to a reportShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMould growing on bread"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Noddles infested with rat hair, insects in chocolates and orange juice complete with maggots - these are just some of the fears of what a post- Brexit trade deal with the US could bring.Producers in the States stick to a Defects Levels Handbook which sets out the maximum number of foreign bodies that can be in food products on the market, according to reports. This reportedly outlines that a -gram jar of paprika can have  rodent hairs in it. Up to  insect fragments are acceptable in a g jar of peanut butter. And for each pound of ginger, mg of mammalian excretawould reportedly pass the test. US producers are also allowed one maggot per mm of orange juice, Business Insider reports.You could also find two maggots g of tomato juice or tomato pizza paste. The US law also reportedly allows  insect fragments per g of chocolate and up to  for g of nutmeg. Three percent of canned peaches and  percent of currants can be infested or eaten into by worms in the US, the report states.  The US Food Defeat Handbook says mould is an acceptable feature of a wide iety of food - including certain percentages of olives and cranberry sauce, Business Insider adds. This is in contrast with EU regulations, which give no allowable limits of foreign bodies in food products. Clearly, The Tories have some very unpleasant surprises for UK dinner tablesthey have their way with a fast-track trade deal with the United States, Bill Esterson, Labour MP and Shadow Trade Minister, told Business Insider.Caroline Lucas, ex-leader of the Green party and supporter of the Peoples Vote campaign, added: No-one voted for a Brexit that waters down the safety and hygiene of our food — but thats what the government is pursuing.But Liam Fox, UK Trade Secretary, has denied Britain will compromise its food standards post Brexit.

title: theresa under mounting pressure halt
story: NewsTheresa May under pressure to halt Universal Credit - as ex-serviceman receives £ to live on for a monthThe Prime Minister faced angry MPs amid fears the flagship welfare reform will hammer some of the poorest people in the UK from JulyShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsPrime Minister Theresa May leaves number  Downing Street for Prime Ministers Questions today "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPressure was mounting on Theresa May tonight to halt the rollout of Universal Credit. The Prime Minister faced angry MPs amid fears the flagship welfare reform will hammer some of the poorest people in the UK from July. She insisted the overhaul would “encourage people into work” and vowing to plough on, she added: “It will be done initially on a small-scale basis to ensure we get that right.” Labour MPs backed the Mirror’s Stop the Universal Credit Cruelty campaign, while Jeremy Corbyn said Mrs May’s boast about ending austerity was a “great big Conservative con”.  After Prime Minster’s Questions, Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell blasted the “absolutely clueless” Tory chief. He said: “I don’t think she has any understanding of what is going on in communities. She just dismissed people’s concerns out of hand.” The Mirror has campaigned with former PM Gordon Brown and our petition demanding a halt to the rollout had been signed by , tonight.  We believe there are three options: shyredesign UC axe it in favour of the old systemunfixable or introduce a new system. Fuelling hopes Labour would axe UC, Mr McDonnell said: “It’s a nightmare. Large numbers are having to go to foodbanks. It’s causing extreme hardship for many people.” We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. Meanwhile, Work and Pensions Committee chair Frank Field said the Government response to calls to help victims of domestic abuse claiming UC was “totally inadequate”. The benefit is paid in one lump sum per household and activists say it allows violent partners to control victims. Ministers introduced a split payment option but it is feared victims will be too afraid to use it.Labour Party chairman Ian Lavery has warned the PM that Universal Credit will cause a spike in suicides.Case study: pound for a monthBrian Lister, , LincolnshireAn ex-serviceman was threatened with eviction after receiving just pound to live on for a month. Brian Lister, , served in the RAF for  years.  But he fell behind on his rent after his payments were heavily reduced because he took an advance loan to cope with Universal Credit delays and did some part time agency work. He told the Mirror: During May I was given just pound to live on, when I was supposed to receive a payment of more than pound. I have been told this is because I had been working at the time, but I received these wages a month before my Universal Credit payment, and had spent the money paying my rent and bills.”

title: tories slip out study admitting
story: NewsTories slip out study admitting theres no evidence benefit sanctions workIt showed that cutting someones benefits as a punishment for alleged failures to comply with Jobcentre Plus rules does not encourage claimants to apply for additional workShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsJob Centre "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tories have been accused of slipping out a study admitting that theres no evidence benefit sanctions work. The report showed that cutting someones benefits as a punishment for alleged failures to comply with Jobcentre Plus rules does not encourage claimants to apply for additional work. It went on to say that in some cases docking the money “damages the relationship between the work coach and the claimant”. The findings, which cast doubt on the effectiveness of a key element of Universal Credit, were published quietly on  September with no ministerial announcement. Frank Field, chair of the Work and Pensions Committee, accused ministers of trying to bury the findings.  “Rather than set out a bold plan to help low-paid workers earn more money – with more direct support being offered as opposed to terrying the le out of them with the threat of sanctions – the DWP has decided to sneak out this report without giving the House of Commons an opportunity to debate its contents or the actions that are required on the back of it,” he said. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. He told the Independent: “Under universal credit, sanctions are being used for the first time ever against low-paid workers as a means of pushing them to increase their hours or move jobs. “This report shows these sanctions have been largely ineffective and that this new element of the benefits system needs to be put right quickly.”  A DWP spokesperson told the Independent: “The ‘in work progression trials’ helped encourage claimants to increase their hours, seek out progression opportunities and take part in job-related training. “The trials delivered positive results for many of the lowest paid people who claim universal credit and we are now considering the findings.”

title: autistic boy five strapped chair
story: NewsAutistic boy, five, strapped into chair by ankles and waist at school while other kids were allowed to play freelyThe schoolboy who attends a special school in Northern Ireland, was tethered like an animal, according to his mumShareByJilly Beattie:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe five-year-old strapped into a chair by his ankles and waist at school "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA five-year-old with autism was strapped to a chair at his waist and ankles at school, the Mirror can reveal.Photos sent to his parents as part of a class report revealed the boy, who attends a special school in Northern Ireland, had been confined to the chair with straps at his waist and legs despite having no special physical needs. Meanwhile, other pupils were able to sit and play freely. The Mirror is not naming the family to protect the child’s identity. When his parents discovered  months ago what had occurred, they asked for an apology and an assurance the action would never be repeated. But no apology was forthcoming and they contacted Social Services and their son’s psychiatrist advised them their claims were a “child protection matter”.  Social services made a complaint to the PSNI and wrote to the child’s psychiatrist stating: “We fear [the child] suffered wilful or neglectful failure to prevent injury and suffering, and confinement defined as physical abuse under Social Services procedure.” His parents made an official complaint citing negligence and breach of duty by the school, the Education Authority and the Department of Education but say they have been left in limbo.An internal Education memo, seen by the Mirror, states on June  the parents’ complaints should be registered with Internal Audit as a “potential whistleblowing case”. The mum said: “Our son was tethered like an animal. He’s a placid boy, all his assessments show that. He is physically fit and active with some challenging behaviour but there’s never been a need to restrain him. “Those chairs are made for children who need to be elevated and angled to the right position, not our son. “We didn’t realise what had been going on until he actually managed to show us himself. Our son is autistic and non-verbal, but until this he’d always been happy, cheerful and easy company. “Quite suddenly his personality changed and for the best part of a year we were going rapidly downhill. He was tortured, demented. I was really concerned that he was going out of his mind. “He was so distressed and agitated, having panic attacks, suffering night terrors and he was acting very strangely, a totally dferent little boy to the one we knew and he couldn’t tell us why.  “He started staying in the chair at the dinner table and got very distressedwe tried to get him out of it. His psychiatrist has since told us she believes he’d been conditioned to sitting in a chair. “We’d no idea he was restrained in a chair in school and we hadn’t given our permission for that. But we were told by other parents they’d seen our son being wheeled in the chair but when we asked the school, they denied it.”His dad added: “We took our son out of school and I home schooled him and for weeks he was still distressed but he started to heal. “His smile came back, his anxiety lted, his distress lessened and he was able to go back to school with dferent teachers who have been brilliant. “We are battling for his dignity and his rights that we believe were violated by the very people who should have protected them.”  Human rights lawyer Kevin Winters has agreed to take on the case. He said: “This child has suffered emotionally and the concern is that that emotional suffering will have impacted on his education and to that end, his human rights are engaged.” A National Association of Head Teachers spokesperson, representing the school’s prinicpal, said: “There is an ongoing investigation into these allegations. Our member is complying fully with the investigation.” An Education Authority spokesman said in order to protect the confidentiality of the child, it cannot comment. The Department of Education and the PSNI were also contacted for comment. A PSNI spokesman said: “The matter has been reported and is being investigated.”

title: cadburys owners paid no corporation
story: NewsCadbury’s US owners paid ZERO corporation tax in UK despite making £million profitEXCLUSIVE: Mondelez UK Ltd – the biggest British offshoot of the US owner of chocolate giant Cadbury – managed to offset its profits to help wipe out the potential £million tax billShareCommentsByGraham HiscottHead of BusinessAlex Clarke:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe entrance to the Cadbury factory in Bournville, Birmingham "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThey make Heroes but when it comes to tax it’s all about zeros... The business that sells and distributes Cadbury products in Britain paid no corporation tax here last year even though its profits rocketed by more than % to poundmillion. Mondelez UK Ltd – the biggest British offshoot of the US owner of chocolate giant Cadbury – managed to offset its profits to help wipe out the potential poundmillion tax bill. And while the public purse missed out, the company channelled a idend of nearly poundmillion offshore to its immediate parent company, headquartered in low-tax Switzerland. Mondelez UK Ltd is one of a network of  British subsidiary companies of the US parent. An investigation by the Mirror can reveal these offshoots paid pound.million combined in corporation tax last year on profits of pound.billion.  Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said: “This is outrageous. Time and time again we’ve warned the Government this type of behaviour is unacceptable. “We have told them they urgently need to tighten the rules on tax avoidance. “This will do nothing but anger people who are going out to work every day, paying their taxes through PAYE. “The Government has to act now to crack down on tax avoidance.” Alex Cobham, chief executive of the Tax Justice Network, called what Mondelez was doing “a piece of financial engineering that is very sad given Cadbury’s long history of working to generate value in the communities where they work”.  He added: “Mondelez are stripping value out, by siphoning off taxable profits from the UK through large intra-group idend payments. It is a problem with international tax rules.” He called on Chancellor Philip Hammond to use this month’s Budget to enact powers which the Treasury already has to force multinationals to produce country by country accounts. These would show the total profit made for all their companies in each market and the tax paid. Our revelations will compound criticism of Chicago-based Mondelez International, which when it was known as Kraft, was controversially allowed to buy Cadbury for pound.billion in .  In , shortly before it was bought by Kraft, Cadbury paid poundmillion in corporation tax. Things changed after Kraft won control of the business. Around  jobs were lost when Kraft axed Cadbury’s Somerdale factory in Keynsham, near Bristol. Production was moved to Poland instead. Then it axed hundreds of jobs at Bournville in Birmingham. Mondelez has also been criticised for decisions such as reducing the size of tubs of Heroes, and dumping the Fairtrade cocoa certication in favour of its own scheme.  Accounts for Mondelez UK, which sells other brands as well as Cadbury products, show its turnover rose from pound.billion to pound.billion. Its profits leapt from poundmillion to nearly poundmillion. The surge was mainly due to poundmillion of idends from two subsidiaries, coming from a coffee business in the Netherlands and the sale of its Terry’s chocolate business. This cash offset its profits and helped cut the corporation tax – which is payable on profits – to zero. The practice is not uncommon, but experts say the tax would usually have been paid by the two subsidiaries. Yet accounts for the two showed one paid no tax and the other just pound,. The accounts for Mondelez UK even showed a tax credit of pound,.  A spokesman insisted: “This is an accounting item and is not a tax or cash credit.” Mondelez added: “In common with all global businesses, we pay corporation tax based on the laws of the countries in which we operate. “We comply with all applicable tax legislation in the UK, as directed by HMRC and the Government. We [pay] tax in more than  countries, and on a global basis pay hundreds of millions of dollars in corporate income tax annually. We are a signicant contributor to the UK economy, through direct spending on employees and suppliers, and the recirculation of that expenditure in the economy. “We are investing in our business here and since  are proud to have invested over poundmillion in UK-based manufacturing and RD supporting our , employees in the UK.” Mondelez International also owns Kenco, Bassett’s and Oreo.Campaign group Tax Justice UK is demanding changes, such as raising corporation tax from % to %, to rake in over poundbillion for the NHS.We must nail the myth that we are all avoiders nowCOMMENT By Paul Monaghan Of the Fair Tax Mark Another day, another set of impenetrable figures. This time it’s Mondelez UK and connected company Cadbury UK, which has just reported a seventh year of zero corporation tax payments. These tax avoidance stories create an impression that everyone is “at it”. A myth has been spun telling us thatwe buy duty-free, invest in an ISA or top up our pension we are tax avoiders – so should back off criticising the likes of Amazon and Facebook. Wrong. No tax is being avoided as no tax is due. Those who say we should feel guilty are likely seeking to de-stigmatise the immorality of tax avoidance. In recent years, HMRC has begun to clamp down on avoidance – which it describes as “bending the rules to gain an advantage Parliament never intended” – and evasion, which is illegal. It is estimated the cost to the UK is poundbillion a year – , nurses. Campaigners want multinationals to be forced by governments to produce country-by-country reports of income, profit and taxes. Thankfully a growing movement of firms here – Lush, Timpson, SSE, and the Co-op included – are backing the Fair Tax Mark. In  a group of MPs forced an amendment to a bill requiring large corporations to report country-by-country. It’s time to enact those powers and for the UK to take the lead on tax transparency. From slums to global success Cadbury dates to , when Quaker John Cadbury opened a grocer’s shop in Bull Street, Birmingham. Among other things it sold cocoa and drinking chocolate – seen as an alternative to alcohol, which Quakers deemed bad for society. The firm began manufacturing in , and by  it was selling  types of drinking chocolate. The business passed to sons Richard and George who, at the end of the s, moved the chocolate factory out of the Birmingham slums and into what became the leafy suburb of Bournville.  They added a village green and cricket pavilion. Cadbury milk chocolate bars followed in , then Bournvillle dark chocolate in , then a host of others. In  came the company’s Glass And A Half symbol for Dairy Milk. Cadbury merged with Schweppes in , but split in . In , Cadbury was bought by Kraft, despite opposition. Kraft boss Irene Rosenfeld, who masterminded the deal, pocketed a poundmillion pay and perks deal the previous year. Takeover action leaves bad taste The anger sparked by the sale of Cadbury to US-based giant Kraft prompted an investigation in Parliament. And when Kraft broke a promise to keep open the Cadbury factory near Bristol the deal was only just sealed. In , it was slammed for scrapping an annual Christmas gt box to retired staff to cut costs and for shaving g off each Dairy Milk bar but nothing off the price. In , Kraft ended a Christmas tradition by stopping making its iconic chocolate coins. It triggered furore in  by changing the recipe for its best-selling Cadbury Creme Egg. The shell of Cadbury Dairy Milk was dropped in favour of what critics complained was an inferior version. Earlier this year Cadbury chocolate bars were banned from NHS buildings in a row over prices. The firm which supplies hundreds of hospitals refused to stock brands such as Dairy Milk, Wispa and Crunchie.

story: NewsEugenie Royal Wedding: George and Charlottes starring roles revealed - and Robbie Williams daughter is bridesmaidGroom Jack Brooksbank has asked his brother, Thomas Brooksbank, to be his best man, while Eugenies older sister Princess Beatrice will be her maid of honourShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe cute kids have a strict dress code as part of their royal obligations "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrinces George and Princess Charlotte have been given starring roles at Princess Eugenies wedding to Jack Brooksbank . story: NewsEugenie royal wedding: Princess visits Salvation Army safe house two days before £million ceremonyEugenie has visited two of the charitys safe houses and given her support to a campaign to raise public awareness of modern slaveryShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  OCT NewsEugenie at the Salvation Army "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrincess Eugenie visited a Salvation Army safe house this evening in one of her final appearances before her poundmillion Windsor royal wedding. Eugenie has visited two of the charitys safe houses and given her support to a campaign to raise public awareness of modern slavery. She was pictured signing her name on a tree mural in one of the safe houses, before meeting with volunteers. Two survivors of modern slavery will be among the guests invited into the grounds of Windsor Castle for the royal wedding - which is costing tax payers in the region of pound.million for policing and security around Windsor. The two women from England and Nigeria, who prefer to remain anonymous, will join other Salvation Army volunteers in the Lower Ward of the Queens Berkshire residence.  Around , members of the public have been given balloted invites to the area in front of the chapel, as have charity representatives, children from Eugenies old schools, and Royal Household staff. Also there will be lelong Salvation Army member Norree Webb. The -year-old volunteers as a first responder within the SAs anti-trafficking and modern slavery unit, which holds the government contract for offering specialist support to all adult victims of modern slavery in England and Wales. Mrs Webb is often one of the first people to come into contact with a victim of slavery. She said: I feel genuinely privileged to receive this invitation, particularly for performing a role about which I am so passionate. It is extremely rewarding to be a small part of the amazing team which makes a dference to the lives of people who have often undergone such horrendous experiences.  Eugenie is an honorary patron of the Teenage Cancer Trust, and the charity will also be represented among those invited into the castle grounds. Myrna Whiteson and Dr Adrian Whiteson, presidents of the trust, said they were thrilled to be included. We have had the pleasure of watching the princess grow up and blossom into the beautul bride we know she will be today, they said in a statement. The princess has been a warm and dedicated patron of this charity, always sensitive to the needs of young people with cancer and eager to help and support them.  Others invited include Kelly Scally, from Stoke on Trent, who is a cancer clinical liaison nurse specialist for teenagers and young adults at Royal Stoke University Hospital Christine Lowe, from Leigh, who carries out the same role at Lancashire Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust and Anna Davies, from Bridgend, who is a Teenage Cancer Trust youth support co-ordinator at the University Hospital of Wales. The trust is the only UK charity that provides specialised nursing and emotional support to young people aged - with cancer.

title: grandad who saw cage toddler
story: NewsGrandad who saw cage where toddler died while tied up sleeping face down said it belonged in hellSean Coyle visited his daughter Lauren Coyles home to find -month-old Ella-May unresponsive and clammy in the bed at her flat in Preston, Lancashire.ShareByPat HurstAbigail OLeary:,  OCT NewsEllie-May Minshull-Coyle died after being forcibly restrained face down by ligatures on her bed, jurors heard "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA granddad who saw a cage where his toddler granddaughter died after allegedly being tied up sleeping face down said it belonged in hell. Sean Coyle visited his daughter Lauren Coyles home to find -month-old Ella-May Minshull-Coyle unresponsive and clammy in the bed at her flat in Preston, Lancashire. Ellie-May was allegedly bound by her legs and across her chest and forced to sleep face down in the bed converted into a monstrous cage, a jury at Liverpool Crown Court has heard. A post-mortem examination found that Ellie-May, described as otherwise healthy, fit and full of le, died due to forcible restraint by ligatures in a face down position complicated by hyperthermia. The bed Ellie-May slept in, a purple Frozen bed based on the Disney childrens film, was allegedly turned into a prison by the childs stepfather Reece Hitchcott, , with the help of their lodger Connor Kirby, .  It is alleged Ellie-Mays mother, stepfather and lodger, living with the child in the two-bedroom flat at Ward Street in Lostock Hall, all knew what was going on. All three deny manslaughter on March  last year. A week before Ellie-Mays death, her grandfather Mr Coyle told the court he and his we Louise visited the flat and Hitchcott showed them the bed. Mr Coyle described it as: Some kind of thing, something that should be in hell, some kind of frame. It had some kind of sheeting over it. There was a gap at one end so you could push it against the wall, so it became a prison for her.  Well the first thing I thought was, What the hell is this  He said Hitchcott told him it was to assist the child as she had struggled getting into a sleeping pattern. Mr Coyle said his we told the stepfather to take it down as it was dangerous and the child may smother herself. At around .am on March  last year, Mr Coyle visited the flat again after his daughter had messaged him to say she had been up all night with Ellie-May. Mr Coyle told the court he said wheres princess  as he entered but when he got to the bedroom he saw Hitchcott crouched down beside the bed. The witness continued: She did not look right, there was something definitely wrong with her. He said Ellie-Mays eyes rolled back in her head and she looked clammy and he ran to ring for an ambulance before commencing mouth-to-mouth and CPR.  The child was pronounced dead later that day in hospital. She was allegedly tied to the mattress of her bed with tight ligatures across her chest and legs and a duvet placed over her. Her bed had been pushed against a wall and the open sides enclosed by the slatted sides of a cot lashed together with ligatures and electrical flex and tied to the bed frame, the court heard. Sheets and bedding were placed over the sides to prevent her seeing outside, no lights were working inside her bedroom and a mattress and sheet were also covering the window, the court was told.

The bugs, known as Harlequin Ladybirds, are said to be seeking cosy hibernation spots - targeting homes across the country as many of us turn our heating on in time for autumn. Flying in from Asia and North America, the tiny insects have black instead of red wings and are spreading rapidly across England and Wales. British heptathlete and GB Olympian Kelly Sotherton tweeted a horrying video of hundreds of ladybirds crawling around her window and across the ceiling. She said: Get home and welcomed by swarms of ladybirds in every window #ladybirdinvasion.  Twitter user DoubleIn compared the scene to that of a Biblical plague. Many people have been turning to social media to show the extent of the invasion in their area - with some getting plastered in the little bugs while out dog walking. Shakira Phillips was staying in a Premier Inn in East Sussex when she spotted the bugs gathered in the corner of a window.  While Laura Jayne sent theimages of her covered in the ladybirds after taking her dogs for a walk in Bramcote Park, Ilkeston. Laura Barnes also revealed how the bugs had invaded her home and gathered around her front door and behind furnitire. Jake Outrim also spotted the creepy crawlies scampering across his window. Experts say the foreign invaders actually pose a threat to the domestic species because they carry a sexually-transmitted disease called Laboulbeniales fungal disease. Steve McGrail, director of pest control company Pro Kill Environment, said Harlequin Ladybirds are not harmful to humans but recommended sealing windows to make sure they do not get in homes.  He said: “They are a non-indigenious species. They are coming inside in large numbers. “They usually cluster around window frames and they cluster together to gather heat and hibernate in winter months.” Scientists say a fungus the creatures carry, which is passed on through mating, will infect our native species which are already under threat from habitat loss. While they do not yet knowthe fungus is harmful, the UK Ladybird Survey says it is possible the disease affects the lespan or the number of eggs a female can produce over her lespan.

story: NewsKate Middleton dazzles in £, tweed dress at opening of Victoria and Albert Museums photography centreThe Duchess of Cambridge teamed the Erdem frock with velvet Jimmy Choo heels and statement earringsShareCommentsByAmber HicksElaine McCahill:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror am celebrity-news video kate-middleton-arrives-va-museum-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKate Middleton looked elegant in tweed as she made her first visit as Royal Patron of the VA to open the museums new Photography Centre this evening. The -year-old opted for a pound, Erdem off-the-shoulder burgundy, black and white boucleacute-tweed midi dress encrusted with crystal and faux pearl embellishments. She paired it with wine-hued velvet Jimmy Choo heels and had faux crystal and peal floral Erdem earrings on. The dress was inspired by the Queens love of jazz and Erdem designed it around what Her Majesty might have worn to Harlems Cotton Club.  The Duchess of Cambridge ed to royal duties last week following the birth of Prince Louis in April. Her first official event was a visit to wildle garden in London last week and yesterday she attended the first Global Ministerial Mental Health Summit with Prince William. Kate was revealed as the first Royal Patron of the museum in March. Kensington Palace said her patronage furthers Kate’s “interest in the visual arts, photography and design.” And the duchess, who studied art history at university, showed her expertise in the field during her visit tonight, according to Martin Barnes, the museums senior curator of the exhibition. She is a really knowledgeable student in art history, so she understood about the technology behind the photos, he said. I really got a sense of her knowledge and interest in how it is relevant today but how its history informs its present.  Kate toured the opening display at the Photography Centre entitled Collecting Photography: From Daguerreotype to Digital. The display explores photography from the medium’s invention in the th century to the present day. The new Photography Centre more than doubles the space currently devoted to it in the museum. Prints, negatives, camera equipment, photographic publications and original documents will be displayed together to tell a broader story of international photography. Paul McCartneys photographer daughter Mary McCartney has donated  of her own photos and the former Beatles frontman donated  works by her late we, Linda. Drawn from the VA’s collection of over , photographs, the display showcases contemporary photography alongside seminal prints by pioneers William Henry Fox Talbot, Julia Margaret Cameron and Roger Fenton.  During her tour of the exhibition, The Duchess met curators who have worked on the project, before unveiling a plaque to mark the official opening of the Centre. A frequently changing selection of new acquisitions, a ‘Light Wall’ for displaying the most cutting-edge photographic imagery, and a ‘Dark Tent’ projection area complete the new space. Kate is a keen photographer herself and some of her photos of her children have been released as official portraits. The art history graduate became a Patron of the National Portrait Gallery in  and last year became an Honorary Member of the Royal Photographic Society.

title: mum vowed never fat bridesmaid
story: NewsMum vowed never to be fat bridesmaid again after seeing this wedding photo - and just look at her nowHelen Wood, , from Blackburn, Lancashire, weighed  stone lb and said she "stuck out like a sore thumb" in every pictureShareCommentsByRosa McMahonSophie Halle-Richards:,  OCT NewsHelen as maid of honour at her best friends wedding "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAmazing photos show the transformation of an obese maid of honour who went on to shed  STONE after seeing her horric photo in her bridesmaid dress. Helen Wood, , was devastated when the  had to be added to the pale green satin gown just weeks before her best friends big day.Manchester Evening News reports that the business support officer, who works in the city, had to have the dress altered from a size  to  to ensure it fit her.Previously weighing  stone lb, the mum-of-two from Blackburn, said she stuck out like a sore thumb in every picture. When she saw the photos, Helen vowed never again to be a fat bridesmaid and slimmed down to an incredible size , now weighing just  stone.  It was horrendously embarrassing for me, watching my best friend get married and feeling like the fat bridesmaid, Helen said. “I stood out like a sore thumb in all the pictures, and when I actually saw the images taken I cried and cried.” Despite previously shting eight stone in  thanks to diet and exercise, Helen relapsed after meeting her husband, Matt and having two children. Admitting that she squeezed into size  clothes at her biggest, she recalled: “Matt was working in Manchester when we met, so I would stay over a lot and we’d go out for dinners, have drinks and le became really comfortable. “I’d lost the weight before by cutting out the rubbish and exercising every day, but I gave all that up when I met Matt and we fell in love.” Skipping breakfast, Helen would snack on crisps, before having a cheese and ham sandwich with a chocolate bar for pudding at lunch and a double portioned pasta meal, slathered in creamy tomato sauce for dinner. But her real downfall was her nightly ritual of a family-size bar of chocolate with a cup of tea in bed. Gorging on , calories a day and never exercising, after giving birth to Jack in  she made no effort to sht the “baby weight. Then, after having Emilie in July , Helen soared to a hefty size . But with her best friend, Kelly, , due to marry that October and with a size  dress bought for the occasion, Helen panicked.  “I was so touched when my childhood friend Kelly asked me to be her maid of honour, and with just three months to go until the big day, I was determined to get into the gown, but deep down knew I wouldn’t,” she said. “With a new baby and a toddler, I struggled to find the time to concentrate on my weight so, before I knew it, the wedding was weeks away and I was still fat.” Knowing the dress would never fit, she visited a tailor, asking her to make it bigger by adding  into the sides, so she could wear it. She said: “I looked dferent to everyone  and really stood out. Another bridesmaid was pregnant at the time and I actually looked bigger than she did. “The dress wasn’t the same as everyone ’s because of the alterations and I felt larger than I ever had. “I made Matt delete all the photos he took of me and cried my eyes out.” Vowing to change, it took Helen seven months to summon the courage to contact the weight loss company, Cambridge Weight Plan. “My mum suggested I gave it a go, as they offer one to-one support and create a personalised plan,” she said.  “I couldn’t face going to slimming classes and being with lots of people I didn’t know.” In her first two weeks, Helen lost lb by eating and drinking only the Cambridge Weight Plan products, before slowly incorporating exercise into her regime, too. Now,  months on, she has even become a Cambridge Weight Plan consultant and has never felt better. “I’ve got a split-picture on my phone background - one photo is of me now and one is me at my largest. When I showed my little boy, he didn’t know who the larger woman was,” she smiled.

story: NewsParents who named baby after Adolf Hitler posed in KKK robes with newbornAdam Thomas, , and his partner Claudia Patatas, , are alleged members of prescribed group National Action gave their child the middle name AdolfShareByRichard Vernalls:,  OCT NewsAdam Thomas is accused of being part of terror group National Action which was banned in "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn alleged far-right terrorist posed for a photo cradling his new-born baby, wearing the hooded white robes of the Ku Klux Klan , a court heard. Adam Thomas, , and his partner Claudia Patatas, , gave their child the middle name Adolf, which the prosecution has alleged was in honour of the infamous Nazi leader Hitler. On Wednesday, a court also heard how Patatas had allegedly sent a WhatsApp message reading all Jews must be put to death, while Thomas bemoaned the fact he had a fat P**i as a work colleague. Jurors were also shown another image, said to be of Thomas in a Klansmens robe and brandishing a machete in front of a Confederate flag.  The flag was shown hanging over a sofa, on which were two scatter cushions each bearing the Swastika. The couple also allegedly had a poster stuck to their fridge reading Britain is ours - the rest must go. The Crown have further claimed the couple were pictured at home with another man, a convicted racist and vehement Nazi, who was holding a Swastika flag and performing a Hitler-style salute over their baby. Thomas and Patatas, both of Banbury, Oxfordshire, are on trial at Birmingham Crown Court accused of being members of the far-right terrorist group National Action, banned in December . Co-defendant Daniel Bogunovic, , of Leicester, is also in the dock facing the same membership charge. Thomas is facing a separate charge of having a terrorist document, the Anarchy Cookbook, which contained bomb-making instructions. Barnaby Jameson QC, prosecuting, showed jurors a series of photographs said to be of Thomas in KKK robes, including one with the child. He said: The suggestion is that is Mr Thomas and his child, whose middle name is Adolf.  Turning to an image of a hooded man with a machete, Mr Jameson added: There is a strong inference, and youll appreciate this when you look inside the Thomas and Patatas house, that that was taken inside their home, and that the person in the robes was Thomas. It emerged in court that counter-terrorism officers from Prevent had visited the couples home in October last year due to concerns Ms Patatas may be involved in the extreme right wing. However, an online chat message allegedly sent by Thomas showed he was unfazed. He said: I have my flags up, lol - and f**k social services, they have no basis of claim of anything. In a message from work that Thomas is said to have sent to Patatas, bemoaning his colleagues in September , he said: A fat half bred n****r who is typical of the Birmingham type of mongrel, a fat p**i and a black as hell Rastafarian. What Ive found is that all non-whites are intolerable but the ones who have lived here most of their lives are even worse. A danger to le warning for wind has been extended and new warnings for rain are in place over Friday and Saturday.The weather is likely to be so severe the Met Office has named it Storm Callum to encourage people to take the warnings seriously.The Atlantic storm threatens to disrupt travel for commuters and holidaymakers, cut power, flood roads and put lives at risk due to flying debris and falling trees. title: woman left third breast under
story: NewsMum left with “third breast” under ARMPIT after botched boob reductionWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES: Ferrell Johnson went under the kne to have her large E cup breasts removed, but now regrets having the surgery doneShareCommentsByErin Cardf:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsFerrell, pictured with her son Joe when he was a child "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA devastated mum has been left with a third breast under her armpit after botched surgery to reduce the size of her boobs. Ferrell Johnson had believed the operation would give her a new lease of le after years of suffering back pain. But the estate agent, , says she now needs her son to follow her around to check the third breast isnt showing. Ferrell, from Marysville, Calornia, went under the kne in March  to have her large E cup boobs reduced. But, instead of the smaller bosom she was hoping for, Ferrell, who has been left with fat necrosis - a lump of dead and damaged tissue - said: I’ve been left in a mess. She added: I have a fat necrosis in my right breast, and a third breast- made up of fat and tissue - under my arm. “The first time I saw the lump in the mirror, I cried and cried. I’ve always been a go-getter, so it isn’t in my nature to feel this way.  “This has caused so many emotional issues. I’m constantly so conscious of what I wear and how I move, as the breast can fall out of the side of my top. I’m horried at the thought of being seen in public like that.” Now Ferrell, whose procedure was covered by her medical insurance, faces complete reconstructive surgeryshe wants to correct her breasts. Always busty, she recalled reaching a D cup by the time she was  - with her bust continuing to grow when she gained weight over the years, which led to her experiencing back problems. She had long-planned to have reduction surgery – but the idea was put on the back-burner following the tragic death of her son Cortneywho took his own le in , when he was .  “He was always so well loved, really charismatic and bright,” she said. “After he passed, I could barely do anything. I struggled so much with my grief. “My operation was supposed to be a way of me regaining my confidence and getting back out there – I can’t believe this is how things turned out.” Meeting with a surgeon early last year, Ferrell hoped to go back down to a D cup - though ended up being taken to a B cup - and was not worried about what she thought was a routine operation. She added: “I went under general anaesthetic for the procedure in March , so by the time I woke up, the damage was already done.” Required to wear surgical bras and bandages, it took about two weeks for Ferrell to see what had actually happened - although she felt discomfort under her right arm, which she thought was just her body recovering. “I was incredibly careful about keeping the area clean. I had a nurse friend help me out, and she wore surgical gloves to take my dressings off,” she said. “The first time I properly saw myself, I was home alone and caught sight of a lump in the mirror. I took a proper look and just burst into tears. It looked literally like a third breast.”  Next, Ferrell began noticing a worrying fatty discharge, which she believes was coming from her breasts. She continued: “I was excreting lumps out of my nipple. At first, they looked like long, thin worms, and I thought, ‘Oh my god, what is that ’ “Then one day, a marble-sized piece of tissue fell away. “Panicking, I raced to the emergency room of a nearby hospital, where they told me it looked like I’d had botched surgery. “I was put on antibiotics, but I have been left with some fatty lumps that need removing. There’s one piece of dead tissue in particular, measuring cm by cm, that causes severe pain.” Ferrell believes her problems were caused by her skin being pulled too tight during her breast reduction surgery. Now, her le turned upside down by what has happened, she is desperate to find another medic who can help reverse the damage. Meanwhile, her confidence has plummeted and she is now living as a virtual recluse. She said: “I struggle to go anywhere without my son Joe, . He’s had to take on an awful lot. I ask him to walk behind me to check that the lump under my arm isn’t showing. “It is softening and pushing back a little, but it’s still a third breast under my arm.  “Unfortunately, as it was elective surgery – something I chose to do – I’m not in a position where I can take legal action, but really, all I want is to fix this. “I can’t believe I’m now having to consider a full reconstruction, including implants, so I can look normal again. My insurance company have said they would help cover it but I need to lose a little weight before I can have the surgery and Im nervous to have another operation. Desperate, Ferrell has even written to reality show Botched, asking for help but, for now, all she can do is wait. She hopes that by sharing her story, she will encourage others to be cautious when selecting their own surgeons. “I have nothing against people having surgery, but you must be thorough with finding your doctor. If they evade questions or don’t make you feel  per cent comfortable, then avoid them,” she said. “Also, think very carefully and ensure you’re positive surgery is a move you want to make. “The past few years have been an awful lot to deal with, but I want my story out there to help other women.”

story: NewsNetflix addict sent for counselling after spending EIGHT HOURS a day binge watchingThe unnamed -year-old has been receiving counselling at a special facilityShareCommentsByAloysius FernandesAmber Hicks:,  OCT NewsNetflix "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A man has been diagnosed with a Netflix addiction after spending eight hours a day over the past six months binge watching shows.The unnamed -year-old closed himself off from reality to escape into the action on the screen in front of him, according to local media. story: Community groups in Carnoustie will get the chance to decide how to spend a £, legacy fund from the th Open Championship.The world’s oldest golf tournament came to Angus in July.It attracted , spectators – a record for the historic course – and is estimated to have generated about £ million for the area.Now Angus Council and The RA are inviting local groups and residents to a meeting next week where they can find out how to apply for a share of the £, Open Legacy Fund.Johnnie Cole-Hamilton, of the RA, said: “We are pleased to be working with Angus Council to identy local projects that can benefit from the proceeds of staging The Open.“We look forward to welcoming groups to the event.”Arliss Rhind, chairman of Carnoustie Community Council, said: “We want to ensure that everyone in the town is given their chance to pitch their suggestions for what the money could be spent on.“It’s too early to give any specic details but it is important that everyone gets an opportunity to put forward their ideas.”Laura Tierney, of Food is Free Carnoustie, said: “Our group grows food which is provided free of charge to people in the town.“Extra funding would be very welcome to help us and we will definitely be finding outwe can apply.”Wendy Murray, of East Haven Together, said: “We are currently working on a sustainability project at East Haven centred around coastal erosion caused by high visitor numbers.“We’re not surewe qualy for funding but East Haven is still part of the local community and we will be attending the meeting to get all the relevant information.”Carnoustie councillor Brian Boyd said: “It is fantastic that this money is coming to Carnoustie.“Anyone who has any suggestions is very welcome to come to the meeting.”The meeting will be held at Carnoustie High School on Tuesday at pm.

title: dundee community digs deep to help popular pooch mr chang
story: Almost £, has been raised for a popular pooch left stricken by a serious spinal injury.Pekingese Mr Chang narrowly avoided being paralysed after suffering a slipped disc.Owner Michelle Boyack was forced to fork out £, so he could have surgery at the Albavet Veterinary Hospital in Kirkcaldy.But she’s received a cash boost from big-hearted locals in Lochee who have dipped into their pockets to help the dog.Michelle, , held a fundraiser along with friends and family at Club  on St Salvador Street, raising more than £, in the process.And the money is still rolling in, with almost £ raised from customers at her dog grooming business, Short Bark and Tails, on Lochee’s High Street – as well as from complete strangers.A delighted Michelle said: “I honestly can’t believe the response I’ve had and all the people coming forward.“It’s really been a big help.“The fundraiser was brilliant. We raised a lot of money considering it was mostly my friends and family.“The most amazing thing is the total strangers who have been coming in to give the odd £ and clients adding £ or £ to their bill to put towards it. It just shows the strength of the community here in Lochee and the support I’ve had from all my friends and family in such a short space of time.”Mr Chang was first injured in February but suffered a relapse in August.Michelle added: “I’ve got bairns coming in and asking to see him.“He’s not in the shop just now because he’s got to be careful not to injure himself again.“He’s just desperate to get out to play but we’ve got to be really careful. title: dundee couple practise their dance moves for strictly ahead of wedding next year
story: Strictly Come Prancing – Dundee’s answer to the BBC TV hit show – is already shaping up to be the most talked-about charity event of the year.A dozen local couples will battle it out at a glitzy dance-off at the Apex Hotel in November in front of a  of judges headed by celebrity style guru Gok Wan. Funds from the event will go to children’s charity Help for Kids.Today, Sarah Williamson speaks to another two of the couples taking part.Emma Dewar and Greg Simpson have been an item for  years, moved in together this year and are gearing up for their wedding in .And they are getting their dancing practise in early by taking part in Strictly Come Prancing.Emma, , and Greg, , got involved in the competition through her friend Hannah who works for Help for Kids.Emma said: “Hannah thought it would be a good idea.“I am definitely more excited than my partner is, he is quite nervous.“He doesn’t like being the centre of attention.”Emma said they will be doing the Charleston, adding: “It’s quite fast, and we are doing it to the Will.i.am song Bang Bang.“We are practising every night in the house and it’s a wee bit nerve–wracking now it is coming closer, but it is all good fun.“It’s for a good cause, especially when it’s for kids in Dundee and Perth.”Greg said the event was well out of his comfort zone.He joked that when he found out he was taking part, Emma “had to get the smelling salts out to get me off the ground”.He added: “I like dancing and DJ music, but this is just something new that I have never done before so it is kind of scary.“If I’ve got a few drinks in me I don’t mind being the centre of attention.”Greg said their performance “has got a wee dancy beat in it so that is making us feel a bit easier”.After their second rehearsal, Greg added: “It’s going not too bad.“We’ve got our whole routine.“The nerves are going away now.“It’s scary when you go into something new but the more we do it the better we are.“I am going to try to have fun and not look at the  people sitting around the dance floor.”The final couple who are ready to take to the stage as part of the Strictly Come Prancing competition are Johnny and Hannah.Strangers before the competition, Johnny Togneri, from Edinburgh, and Hannah Maria Clark, who lives in Dryburgh, will compete against  other couples to raise cash for a good cause.Johnny, , a property manager and presenter on Wave FM, said: “Hannah’s been keeping me right.“I’m not going to lie, I’m a pretty awful dancer and it’s a bit of a learning curve, but it is good fun.”He said the couple are staying away from a slow song and favour a faster upbeat number.He added: “It’s coming along really well.“I just thought it was going to be a good laugh.“It’s something completely out of character for me.“However, it’s a good bit of fun and that’s what it’s about as well as raising money for charity.“It’s something out of my comfort zone so I thought – just go for it.“I don’t have much of a competitive side. I’m quite nervous now.“I’m excited to take part, so there’s excitement mixed with nerves.”Hannah, , said: “I thought it would be a good event to get involved with.“I used to do cheerleading when I was younger so I’ve got a bit of a dance background.“Johnny is so funny, he is such a laugh.“We went for more of a comedy routine, it’s quite fast.“I am totally looking forward to it. I think I like being the centre of attention.“I have also got a bit of a charity background as well as I used to work with the Archie Foundation.“We know what we are doing and we reckon it’s going to be really good fun.”

title: dundee fans group writes to top officials over referee steven mcleans links to kilmarnock
story: Angry Dundee fans have written to two top refereeing officials over whistler Steven McLean being put in charge of Saturday’s controversial clash with Kilmarnock despite having strong family connections with the Ayrshire club.McLean blundered by awarding the second-half penalty that saw Killie take the three points from the Dens Park clash.And supporters with long memories are unhappy he was handling the proceedings despite his father, Stewart, making over  appearances for the Rugby Parkers between  and .To add to the conspiracy theories, for  years he was a team-mate of Paul Clarke – brother of their current boss Steve.The pair even appeared on the same sticker in an edition of the annual Panini football album.All that’s prompted the Dundee Supporters’ Association to write to SFA head of referees’ committee chairman Willie Young and their head of refereeing, John Fleming, to question the sense behind having McLean taking games involving Kilmarnock.“Several of our members have contacted me to express their concerns over this and we think it’s only right to pass them on to the authorities,” said DSA chairman Kenny Ross.“And I do think there is reason to question the validity of this appointment when the referee so clearly has family connections to Kilmarnock.“If nothing  it puts him in a dficult position when you get a decision like Saturday’s.“I know that Steven McLean’s brother Brian played for Dundee United, Ross County and a few other clubs and he was not allowed to take charge of games involving teams he was at.“You think the same common sense approach could have been applied to his dad’s old team.”The fans also pointed out should the Killie player who ed to win the kick, Jordan Jones, be handed a two-game ban, that in itself could damage Dundee.The games he would miss would be against St Mirren and Hamilton, the two sides immediately above the Dark Blues at the foot of the Premiership.SFA chief executive Ian Maxwell was copied in when the letter was e-mailed and has promised a response will be given.

title: pictures 127 years of boys brigade marches in dundee
story: Thousands of youngsters have passed through the Boys’ Brigade in Dundee since it started in the city  years ago.The movement, which has the motto Sure and Steadfast, is celebrating the th anniversary of its founding in Glasgow by Sir William Smith in .The stCompany started just eight years later, in , at St Paul’s Church, Nethergate.Today there are  companies in the Dundee and Angus Battalion, with more than  officers and  members.Companies include the th th Dundee in Lochee – the oldest in the battalion – the th Dundee in Whitfield, the th Dundee in East Hilltown and Dens Road, the th Dundee in Victoria Street, the nd Dundee in Downfield and Kirkton, the th Dundee in Broughty Ferry and the th Dundee in Menzieshill.Also included in the battalion are the rd th and the th in Arbroath, the st Carnoustie, nd Forfar, st Kirriemuir and the st Monieth.At its peak in the s, there were  companies operating in Dundee with , boys attending. There were about , boys enrolled across Great Britain in .Dundee BB Battalion development officer Roddy Taylor said: “The th th in Lochee is our largest company, with around  boys.“We range from that to smaller ones which are run with about eight boys each in the junior and company sections.”There are also three pipe bands in the Dundee and Angus Battalion – in Lochee, Broughty Ferry and Monieth – and a fledging band in the th Dundee.Roddy added: “The boys don’t always stay all the way through their teens, some will come and go, but quite a number stay on or they bring pals, which is the best form of recruitment.“We have got  boys enrolled on the senior Queen’s Badge at the moment, which is an increase.“The Boys’ Brigade is still relevant today. It gives the boys a sense of belonging and inclusion in the community. They learn skills, we run courses and activities for sport and some of the older lads take part in the Duke of Edinburgh award.“Some say that because we are a youth organisation with Christian ethics we are a bit old fashioned, but we are still thriving and the boys enjoy it.“We welcome all young people, no matter their ability, and have always been very inclusive.”The main challenge for the battalion is attracting leaders who are willing to give up time to volunteer.Roddy added: “I just think that people’s lives are so busy these days. Unless they have youngsters who have joined, it’s not something that many people think about doing.”The captain of the th Dundee Company, Allan Fordyce, finds membership “rewarding.”When he took over two years ago, the unit had roughly  members – now it has .He said: “It’s rewarding seeing the kids being educated and getting them out on dferent activities.”Also celebrating is the st Monfieth Company, which will hold a church parade on October .Andrew McArtney, officer in charge, said: “The boys are going to play an active part in the service.”
