title: merkel-allies-brace-for-big-setback-in-german-state-election
story: This weekendrsquos state election in Baia has been casting a long shadow over German politics for the past year mdash and the aftershocks could cause more turbulence for Chancellor Angela Merkelrsquos struggling national government.Polls suggest Baiarsquos centre-right Christian Social Union party , which has run the region for  years, is heading for its worst performance since the s on Sunday.It appears to be losing voters on both the right and left despite enviable prosperity and unemployment at a rock bottom .%.The CSU, which is socially conservative and has taken a hard line on migration, exists only in Baia and is an important but often awkward sister to Mrs Merkelrsquos Christian Democratic Union .The two parties govern Germany in an infighting-prone coalition with the centre-left Social Democrats.Though the CSU is unlikely to lose power in Baia altogether, a result like the one pollsters are forecasting would be humiliating.Speculation is re that party leader Horst Seehofer, Germanyrsquos interior minister, could be forced out.ldquoThe CSU has lost its cohesive power in Baia mdash it was able to win over voters from the right to the centre-left, said Manfred Guellner, the head of the Forsa polling agency.ldquoNow, because of its confrontational course with its sister party, with the chancellor, it has driven away the liberal centre.On the other side, the far-right Alternative for Germany is appealing to voters looking for an uncompromising anti-migration and law-and-order stance.About . million people are eligible to vote in the election for the state legislature in Munich.For decades, the CSU attracted voters from across the spectrum, standing for a combination of modernity and tradition encapsulated by the slogan ldquoLaptops and Lederhosen.It has held an absolute majority in the state legislature for all but five of the last  years and prides itself on punching above its weight in national politics.Lately, that tradition has been evident largely in battles over migration between Mr Seehofer and Mrs Merkel.Mr Seehofer joined Mrs Merkelrsquos Cabinet in March after giving up his job as Baiarsquos governor to younger rival Markus Soeder following a long-running CSU power struggle.ldquoI can only say that voters donrsquot appreciate it, and we can see that in the polls, when we argue with each other and they donrsquot even understand what about, Mrs Merkel said last weekend as she reviewed the year since Germanyrsquos last national election.In that vote, all three governing parties lost signicant support and Alternative for Germany entered the national parliament.The CSU, with its eyes firmly on the Baian election, doubled down on tough talk about migration.That has ided Mrs Merkel and Mr Seehofer since , when he assailed her decision to leave Germanyrsquos borders open as refugees and others crossed the Balkans.Mr Seehofer triggered the most serious crisis yet in Mrs Merkelrsquos fourth-term government, when the pair sparred in June over whether to turn back small numbers of asylum-seekers at the German-Austrian border.The argument briefly threatened to bring down the administration and end his partyrsquos alliance with Mrs Merkelrsquos.He played a starring role in a second crisis last month, doggedly backing the head of Germanyrsquos domestic intelligence agency amid demands that he be removed for appearing to downplay recent far-right violence against migrants.Mrs Merkelrsquos governing coalition needed two attempts to reach a compromise.Mr Seehoferrsquos tactics have started annoying even conservatives who support his positions.Speculation is re that party leader Horst Seehofer, Germanyrsquos interior minister, could be forced out Volker Bouffier, a conservative seeking re-election as governor of neighbouring Hesse state in an October  election, remarked recently the -year-old CSU leader has performed ldquooutstanding services, but he has a tendency to make lone, surprising decisions.Mr Soeder, the new governor, has switched from even tougher talk on migration than Mr Seehofer to trying to project an inclusive image as Baian leader.Polls suggest the switch has not been convincing.They put support for the CSU as low as % mdash down from .% in , in an election held at the height of Mrs Merkelrsquos popularity when Mr Seehofer regained the absolute majority it lost five years earlier.Alternative for Germany did not field candidates then, but looks set to win % or more this time.The Greens are running second, with support of up to %, and the Social Democrats mdash struggling badly in national polls mdash could lose nearly half of the .% they won five years ago.Such a result would leave the CSU seeking either an ideologically dficult coalition with the left-leaning Greens or an alliance with one or more of the pro-business Free Democrats, the centre-right Free Voters and the Social Democrats.A four-way coalition without the CSU might be mathematically possible, but is unlikely.Mr Soeder has blamed ldquopolitics in Berlin for poor ratings in Baia with Mr Seehofer already insisting he will stay in his job after the election.And Mrs Merkel, her authority already weakened by the government infighting and the ouster of a close ally as her partyrsquos parliamentary leader, will be hoping poor election results in Baia and Hesse do not create new problems before a party convention in December where her leadership is due for renewal.The government must ldquobetter present its actions, she said Saturday, adding: ldquoI want to make my contribution to that..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Merkel allies brace for big setback in German state election

title: letter the value of eu citizens
story: At the same time as the recent report from the Migration Advisory Committee outlined the impact of immigration on the UK, Oxford Economics published an assessment that highlighted the value of EU citizens to the British economy.It noted that when it comes to the public finances, European migrants contribute substantially more than they cost, easing the tax burden on other taxpayers.Taxes will therefore have to riseBrexit brings strict curbs on EU workers, because they pay far more to the public purse than British-born residents and also those from outwith the EU.Migrants from the EU contribute £, more to the exchequer each year in net terms than the average adult.Over their letimes, they pay in £, more than they take out in public services and benefits # while the average UK citizen’s net letime contribution is zero.Non-European migrants will make a positive net contribution of £, to £,This is because most EU migrants arrive fully educated, and many leave before the costs of retirement start to weigh on the public finances.In total, the net benefit from the class of  was expected to be £.bn, with £.bn coming from EU migrants and the remaining £.bn from migrants from the rest of the world.It is all well and good wanting to curb immigration from the EU, but people living in the UK must be made aware of the clear impact this will have on the British economy.Alex Orr,Flat , Leamington Terrace,Edinburgh.

title: scotland cyclist fuelled by tasty skipness scallops
story: A horsewoman who swapped four hooves for a two wheels in a , mile charity challenge scoffed scallops during a Kintyre rest day.Louise Cruickshank made a slight detour to visit her Torrisdale based mum, Rhona Elder, and, with riding partner Stuart Irvine, topped up her distance on a  mile trip to Skipness Seafood Cabin.Last Saturday Louise#s cycling dreams came true as well when she pedalled and panted on a uphill stretch of the A, near Furnace, alongside her hero, round the world record holder Mark Beaumont.Mr Beaumont has supported her charity efforts to raise money for Kayleigh#s Wee Stars formed to remember Kayleigh Cordiner who passed away from a terminal brain tumour in June .Louise is also raising money for CLAN Cancer Support a charity providing emotional title: cruel crossbar strike may have cost the match
story: Castlemilk SAFL Premier Division OneThis was a massive disappointment for the home side, as Castlemilk came from behind in the final ten minutes to snatch the points.It was a furiously fought match at Kinloch Park # a game that the Pupils had led from the th minute of the first half.The visitors had the lion’s share of possession in the first period, but the local favourites created the chances in a half played at a frantic pace between two sides of immeasurably contrasting styles.The home side started the game extremely slowly and were under the cosh from a side playing the ball quickly to feet nevertheless, the Pupils defence coped well.With the exception of a one-on one which Alastair Ferguson managed to ert to safety, the visitors never looked like turning their fine possession play into goals.It was no surprise when the first real chance of the match came the way of the home side, a breakout led by Lee Allan who played the ball to the strong running Martin McCallum.Bursting forward, McCallum swept the ball across goal only to see Ryan McConnachie’s header go agonisingly over the top.The breakthrough was only delayed, as Martin McCallum stepped forward in the next attack to drive the ball home from an edge of the box free kick.Controversy reigned for a moment when Sary Rahma seemed to have his legs taken from behind, the quick-silver striker first to his feet only to be grounded by a despairing lunge from the visiting goalkeeper.The decision favoured the last line of defence, but there was a huge sigh of relief from the visitors as the referee waved play onThe second half was very similar to the first  minutes, but the home side began to turn the screw in the final quarter.The Pupils looked good for all three points when a thumping Gary Grumoli header crashed off the underside of the crossbar.A second goal was needed to put this game to bed, and when Sary Rhama was unceremoniously taken out inside the box a penalty looked the likely outcome.You could say it was the ‘stonewall’ iety, but the whistle never came and the play raged on.Ironically, from the very next move Castlemilk were awarded a free kick on the edge of the box, resulting in a smart run to space and perfectly executed header to bring the scores level.With time running out, a visitors corner on the attacking right, was a case of déjà vu when the ball beat everyone to be headed goal-wards with just enough momentum to cross the line for an away win.With seconds remaining, the Pupils poured forward to try and retrieve a point, but lost a third when central midfielder Grant ran free, for the first time in the match, to put the game beyond doubt.Campbeltown Pupils are scheduled to play Kinross from Perthshire in the Scottish Cup tomorrow. Please see social media or match posters for information.Gary Grumoli celebrated this strike a moment too early it hit the crossbar and bounced out. _cpupils Gary Grumoli#s header failed to cross the line. _cpupils_

title: letter tackling bowmore rugby
story: During the past few days I have been answering emails and phone calls from concerned constituents about the recent building work in Bowmore.It has seen a footpath being built over one side of Bowmore#s rugby pitch.I had a meeting with the Islay rugby team and heard directly about their concerns.I have also contacted Argyll and Bute Council#s planning department numerous times, and, on September , I spoke with James Macintyre of Macleod Construction and made my views very clear on this matter.The potential new G pitch and footpath are much needed and more than welcome.That said there have clearly been large failings in the consultation process and this must not happen in future.In order to find the best way forward MacLeods will need to move rugby posts to new positions, using new sleeves and with an Islay Rugby presence during the operation.Leveling off of the west side of the pitch must be carried out using good soil with a view to extending the level pitch by several meters.Material for a ryelock fence should be provided by MacLeods and or others, and permissions given for construction of a standard fence.This fence should run between the timber fence at the rear of the housing estate and the timber fence at the car park, in a line running along the pitch side edge of the new path across the rugby pitch.This should make the extended area as near dog-free as possible and solve the serious fouling problem which unfortunately continues to exist.Regardless of how many of my fellow Ileachs feel, about where this pathway has been built and the lack of proper communication, the hard working front line workers, of Macleods are only following orders and any hostility directed towards them is unhelpful and unfair.If these changes and additions to the building works are made all parties will be happy and Islay will have a terric rugby pitch.Bowmore locals will have a new foot path and Islay can hopefully look forward to the prospect of a wonderful new G pitch in the future.Despite the upset caused by this issue it has been great to hear from so many of my constituents.Councillor Alastair Redman,Portnahaven,Islay.

title: an orchestral night to remember
story: The BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra brought its week’s residency inThe cleverly-constructed programme, based around the conceptFrom the sonorous opening chords in the brass and lower strings, evoking the dark, brooding forests of the composer’s homeland, it was clear that the audience was in for a treat.Conductor Rory Macdonald paced this piece just right and made the hymn-like central section positively sing.Helen Grime’s ‘Snow’ was more challenging, as modern music can be, yet here, too, Macdonald’s clear direction helped the audience get to the heart of a dficult piece.Its long, mid-register, melodic line overlaid with sharp, staccato notes from woodwind and pizzicato strings, depicting brilliantly the brittle cold of a snowy, winter landscape.Britten’s ‘Four Sea Interludes,’ a suite of entr’actes from his opera ‘PeterIn ‘Dawn’ the lower brass provided a sombre bass line suggestive of the sea’s swell, against which tinkling arpeggios from flutes, piccolo and violins hinted at sunlight sparkling on water.The melodic bustle of ‘Sunday Morning’ and the gentle chorale of ‘Moonlight’ led to the thunderous tympani and roaring brass of ‘Storm’.This was music full of images that an audience living by the sea could readily bring to mind.The finest music of the evening was undoubtedly found in the second-halfIn this short, deceptively simple piece, the harp held the music together and defined its mood, its plangent, descending chords soaring above a simple, six-note theme on the violas, beautully played.This rarely-performed masterpiece ended with glorious, restrained ensemble playing from the brass, building to a powerful coda. A somewhat melancholic piece, but rich in orchestral colour, this was a rare treat.Mussorgsky’s great orchestral warhorse ‘Pictures at an Exhibition’ brought the night to a magnicent climax and the audience to its feet.Orchestrated by Ravel, this was originally a piano work, depicting ten pictures from an exhibition of sketches and water colours by a friend of the composer.Linked by the ‘Promenade’ theme which opens the piecethe subjects of the pictures could be vividly imagined.Every orchestra section shone in this piece, but the woodwind deserveIt was a wonderful concert by one of the country’s finest orchestras at the top of its form, under the baton of an outstanding young conductor, all held together with warmth and humour by the genial Jamie MacDougall, this was a night that Campbeltown will long remember.Conductor Rory MacDonald#s arms are a blur in full flow during rehearsal. _cBBCSSO_Rory_MacDonald

title: sisters-set-to-raise-four-figure-sum
story: Musselburgh resident Veronica Noone, , took part in the September  event along with her sister Trisha Francis, , from Manchester, in aid of the charity Crohnrsquos  Colitis UK after family members were diagnosed with the conditions.They joined about , runners for the .-mile half marathon which stretched from Newcastle-upon-Tyne to South Shields.The siblings, who are originally from Tyneside, crossed the finishing line in two hours  minutes.Sir Mo Farah sealed a record-breaking fth victory by winning the elite menrsquos race in  minutes and  seconds.Among the celebrities taking part were singer Olly Murs, news presenter Sophie Raworth and model Nell McAndrew.Veronica, who has lived in Musselburgh for  years, and also serves as vice-chairwoman of Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association, said: ldquoWe got on great and have so far raised pound, but there is still more coming in.Veronica has also raised pound by offering work colleagues at Scottish Enterprise the chance to repaint parts of a le-size cow model from Cow Parade Edinburgh in exchange for donations.Its paint had been washed off following the event in , but the now repainted brightly coloured cow stays on a balcony at Scottish Enterprisersquos Edinburgh office.A pound contribution was given to Veronicarsquos cause from the staff charity fund.Crohnrsquos disease and ulcerative colitis are the two main forms of inflammatory bowel disease, affecting more than , people in the UK.To donate, go to justgiving fundraising veronica-noone

title: bid-brewing-for-coffee-shop-and-drive-through-takeaway
story: The Motor Fuel Group has applied to East Lothian Council for planning consent for the outlet on land to the west of the existing Shell petrol filling station on Edinburgh Road. Tony Thomas, agent for the company, said: ldquoIt is an underused, scruffy site, frequently littered with uncollected dog mess.ldquoWe would like to use the site to introduce a modern, attractive drive-through takeaway coffee franchise with linked landscape and access proposals. This includes the creation of an attractive landscaped garden in the north east corner of the site looking to link the site to the historic Fisherrow Harbour.He added that the drive-through would offer people the chance to take away hot and cold drinks and hot and cold snacks, and there would be seating for customers in the coffee shop.A planning design and access statement, submitted on behalf of the company, stated: ldquoThe restaurant will be designed with on-site and drive-through facilities for vehicles, cycles and pedestrian access, with internal and external areas to enjoy refreshment for the passing traveller, as well as for the local community in the Fisherrow Harbour locality.Also planned is parking, new service lanes and a new landscape plan for the site.The statement added: ldquoIn terms of local economic benefit it is expected that the project will support a number of additional local part time jobs at the site when operational and there will also be additional employees on site during construction.ldquoThe proposed drive-through coffee shop is intended to supplement the existing petrol filling stationrsquosto serve the needs of passing motorists whilst providing useful services to the residential and commercial communities in and around Musselburgh, contributing positively to the sitersquos public realm offer.ldquoThe proposed development will create a place which is welcoming and distinctive by virtue of its design. It will be safe and pleasant ensuring ease of movement for vehicles and pedestrians to enter exit the site and move around the site in a clear and legible manner.ldquoDropped kerbs will allow safe movement of pedestrians between uses on-site, while road marking and signage within the site will indicate direction of travel and facilities. The site is adaptable in that it is linked to the wider area by road and footpath links, with parking provided to suit a range of users.ldquoThe drive-through facility will be accessed via a dedicated, signposted route which runs to the rear of the building and exits back onto the main exit route from the parking area. This enables customers to continue their journey or park up in the car park before exiting the site via normal channels.The coffee shop drive-through, which will have  parking bays including two for disabled motorists, will operate  days a year between am to pm.Five cycle stands will be provided which will be located to the front of the new building in association with the retained trees in that location. There would be earth embankment and tree planting carried out, with benches provided for public amenity.

title: making-a-tapestry-for-musselburgh
story: Stitchers are invited to attend another workshop at the Old Town Hall.It follows a successful bid to attract volunteers to join the community project which is expected to take two years to complete.Andrew Crummy, the artist behind the Great Tapestry of Scotland and Battle of Prestonpans Tapestry, spoke at a recent event in the Old Town Hall as did Melissa Viguier from the School of Ancient Crafts.The Battle of Pinkie Cleugh, which took place between Wallyford, Musselburgh and Dalkeith on September , , has been described as the largest and bloodiest conflict ever fought on Scottish soil.It began after the English king Henry VIIIrsquos attempts to secure an alliance with Scotland through the marriage of his young son Edward to the infant Mary, Queen of Scots, failed.Part of a conflict known as the Rough Wooing, it is considered to be the first modern battle in the British Isles and a catastrophic defeat for Scotland.Now the Pinkie Cleugh Battlefield Group is working with Mr Crummy to make sure the last pitched battle between Scottish and English armies, in which , were killed, is not forgotten.The tapestry will be loosely based on the Marian Hangings stitched by Mary, Queen of Scots. Ms Viguier and a team of Edinburgh stitchers crafted a complete replica of the Marian hangings which can be seen at Edinburgh Castle.The Battle of Pinkie Cleugh tapestry will take the form of a series of embroideries hung on velvet which, it is hoped, will find a permanent home at The Brunton in Musselburgh.The Pinkie Cleugh Battlefield Group has already secured pound, from the Musselburgh Common Good Fund, which will pay for the first phase of the tapestry. Chief stitcher Liz Neilson and her team will lead the work.Volunteer stitchers are welcome to attend future workshops at the Old Town Hall from am to pm on October  and , November  and December .Alister Hadden, treasurer of the Pinkie Cleugh Battlefield Group, said: "We were delighted with how well attended the launch event was. It is really good to see so much work being done and we are sure the tapestry will be a huge success, and highlight this important battle."

title: pedal-power-proves-a-real-boost-to-surfing-group
story: Ebon and Ansel Parkin decided to take on a challenge, which would see them cycle from Clydebank, west of Glasgow, across the country and back to their home in Dunbar.The -mile trek, where they were joined by dad Dan, with family friend Davy Scott also lending a hand, saw the two brothers setting off at about .am.Dad Dan was impressed by their efforts, which saw them raise more than pound for The Wave Project, as they pedalled along cycle paths, canal paths and roads.He said: ldquoI certainly am proud. A lot of people have said lsquowow,  milesrsquo. If you do a lot of cycling maybe that does not seem that far but for little, short legs like Ansel, his bike is tiny and he cycled further than we did technically.The quartet set off from near the Erskine Bridge before heading east to Lenzie and on towards West Lothian.They then followed the Union Canal into Edinburgh and then onto to East Lothian, following the coast through Musselburgh and North Berwick.Finally, the tired cyclists reached their destination on Dunbarrsquos Retreat Gardens after eight hours and nine minutes in the saddle.Dunbar Grammar School pupil Ebon said: ldquoI didnrsquot want to be glued to the telly and I wanted something challenging to work hard on. Riding  miles sounded like a great idea.The idea came about at Christmas when the family were discussing potential new yearrsquos resolutions.Nine-year-old Ansel, who attends Dunbar Primary School, and big brother Ebon, , are keen surfers and had already agreed to take on the challenge before deciding to do their bit for The Wave Project.Ansel said: ldquoI wanted to set myself a challenge for this year. I thought about what I liked best. I love cycling. So, I set a target of riding  miles.The charity, which brings people together through surfing, is based at Belhaven Bay.It aims to increase youngstersrsquo confidence and feel less anxious through surfing sessions.Alison Young, coordinator of The Wave Project, thanked the duo for their help. She said: ldquoThank you so much boys, look forward to seeing you in the surf soon!

title: the-midnight-run-set-for-special-gig-in-macmerry-primary-school
story: The Midnight Run band will play at Macmerry Primary School, supported by young musicians from the school.The concert has been organised by pupils in primary  and , overseen by school chaplain, Robin Hill, and underwritten by Gladsmuir Parish Church.The band is not the first from the USA to visit the school ndash the Corn Potato String Band were a huge hit when they performed there in .Now, The Midnight Run are stopping off at the school as part of their tour of Scotland.Concert tickets ndash pound per person and under-s go free when accompanied by an adult ndash are available from the school office.Doors open at .pm, with the concert starting at pm.

title: no-point-consulting-over-moving-services-from-aldhammer-house-to-prestonpans-library
story: Eileen Morrison, customer services manager with East Lothian Council, told Prestonpans Community Council that the local authority had not held a public consultation before moving cash payment and benefits services into the townrsquos library because there was no other choice.And she challenged claims there had been complaints about the decision, saying they had only surfaced in ldquothe last couple of weeks.The transfer of some council services from its offices in the townrsquos Aldhammer House into the library, on West Loan, was announced less than  months after the local authority pledged not to merge services following a public consultation in which  per cent of those who took part objected to the move.Following that consultation, in , the council dropped its proposed merger however last month it announced it was moving a large part of the services out of Aldhammer and into the library.And it was revealed services had, in fact, been operating out of the library for several months.Ms Morrison confirmed an interview pod had been moved into the library in December.During a meeting of the community council, which objected to the merging of the services during the original consultation, Ms Morrison was asked why a second consultation had not been held before the move took place.She said: ldquoWhat was the point of a consultation  I could not staff a service at Aldhammer House.Ms Morrison told community councillors that staffing issues at the council offices meant she was unable to have two people, the minimum number required, covering the hours required there and staff the library service.And she insisted the service move would benefit the library, which is the only Carnegie Library in East Lothian, by bringing more visitors in and allowing opening hours to be extended.However community councillors insisted the town had made its view on the move clear in the first consultation.DJ Johnston-Smith said they had brought a ldquocuckoo into the nest by merging the facilities.He said: ldquoPrestonpans was very clear it did not want this to happen.ldquoWe have a clear understanding of what a library is for and you are bringing a cuckoo into the nest.ldquoI do not believe children coming in for books or students looking for a quiet place to study should be confronted by people who are sometimes desperate for help.Ms Morrison pointed to the fact that the public consultation which came out against the move only had  responses leading some community councillors to question whether it was then fair to say it represented the entire town.However community councillor John Reynolds said the interview pod placed in the library which he said was used by the welfare rights officer to conduct private interview was like ldquoThe Cube.He said: ldquoIt may be suited to a TV show but it is not suited to private interviews for people ndash you can be seen by everyone walking into the library.Ms Morrison said a privacy screen was being installed after the issue was raised but she said: ldquoThe interview pod has been there since December  and until a couple of weeks ago there were no complaints.Housing services remain in Aldhammer House and James Coutts, housing services manager, said the local authority would consult with the community about what other services they would like to see moved into the council buildingrsquos now vacant rooms.Community council chairman Brian Weddell called for a working group to be set up to look at future council services in the town.

title: giant-sponge-of-mosses-tackling-air-pollution-in-musselburgh
story: Air pollution in the centre of the Honest Toun has long been a cause for concern.Now, a giant sponge of mosses has been put in place on High Street, outside the police station, in the hope of cutting nearby pollution by close to a third.CityTree has been developed by German green technology firm Green City Solutions who say the combination of mosses in the structure can filter air pollutants - including nitrogen dioxide - from the surrounding air by up to  per cent.Derek Oliver of East Lothian Council described the structure as a "innovative approach"to tackling air quality issues.He added: "It is anticipated to raise awareness and influence behavioural change around pollution and climate change. We will seek public opinion following the pilot period.The East Lothian CityTree has been funded by the Scottish Government through the East Central Scotland Vehicle Emissions Partnership and has been installed in the designated Air Quality Management Area of Musselburgh High Street for an initial four-month pilot period.Councillor Norman Hampshire, cabinet member for environment, added: ldquoIt is particularly appropriate that we are installing this CityTree at the start of Climate Week Scotland  and it will be interesting to see what impact it will have on air pollution in Musselburgh High Street."A number of measures have been outlined in the Musselburgh Air Quality Action Plan to tackle poor air quality including introducing new technology, aiming to reduce vehicle emissions, and encouraging sustainable travel options."Whether as an inidual, business or school, we can all play a part in taking action to improve our environment and I hope the CityTree will act as a focus for future ideas.The installation powers itself via solar , and rainwater is collected and automatically redistributed using a built-in irrigation system. This provides ideal conditions for the mosses to grow in an urban environment.East Lothian is the second local authority in Scotland to have a CityTree, following Glasgow City Council.CityTree technology has also been installed in Berlin, Paris, Brussels, Hong Kong, Amsterdam, Oslo, London and Newcastle.

title: beer-exhibition-celebrating-haddingtons-history-planned
story: The event, organised by the not-for-profit community interest company Brewing Heritage Scotland, takes place in the townrsquos John Gray Centre from January  to April . Already, the Scottish Brewing Archive Association has helped contribute and gather artefacts relating to Haddingtonrsquos beer and malting history, with the support of East Lothian Council.Donations from Haddingtonrsquos pub and brewing past are welcome.The exhibition is part of the Raise Your Glass series and previous displays have taken place in Edinburgh, Musselburgh and Alloa.There will be some information displays about brewing in Scotland, in addition to more specic items relating to the town.

title: more-than-200-jobs-planned-for-service-station-at-former-raceland-site
story: Euro Garages Ltd has submitted a planning application to East Lothian Council to transform the former Raceland go-karting and paintball centre site which closed in January.Their plans for a petrol station with shop, a drive-thru coffee shop, and two drive-thru restaurants would bring as-yet-unspecied big-name fast-food outlets to the county as well as -plus jobs.A .-acre section of land, to the north of the site and running alongside the B, which links Longniddry and Pencaitland, has been set aside for a future development phase, which could include a hotel.Euro Garages Ltd are hopeful East Lothian councillors on the local authorityrsquos planning committee will rule on the proposals in January next year.Tom Jeremiah, of Euro Garages Ltd, said: ldquoDiscussions with the council have shown that employment opportunities in this area of East Lothian are limited, especially for young people who are looking for flexible work.ldquoOur plans would deliver  jobs in a range of full and part-time roles which would allow people to live and work in East Lothian, rather than having to travel to Edinburgh for employment. Our current proposals only cover half of the site and there remains an opportunity to deliver further employment-generating development in the future. However, we are still considering how best to take this forward.The plans show a service station with  fuel pumps for cars and vans, with a further three pumps for Heavy Goods Vehicles . There would also be two fast-food drive-thru restaurants, as well as a coffee shop drive-thru. It is unclear which businesses would fill the units, although Euro Garages regularly partner with Starbucks, Burger King, KFC, Subway and Greggs in the past.About  parking spaces would also be created on the site, which would include electric vehicle charging points and disabled bays.Mr Jeremiah added: ldquoThis section of the A is not well-served by roadside facilities, which is potentially dangerous for drivers who are not able to take adequate breaks to rest, relax and refuel before continuing their journey.ldquoThis location is ideal for the type of services proposed, with a large, vacant brownfield site accessed by the existing Gladsmuir Junction.ldquoAs a result, the works needed to deliver this site are more limited and we would hope to start construction by mid- and complete building within six months, should planning permission be granted.Established in , EG Group has  roadside services throughout the UK, as well as approximately , in France, Italy, Germany, Belgium, Netherlands, Luxembourg and the US.The business employs more than , people in the UK alone.Tranent Macmerry ward member Councillor Kenny McLeod, who is part of the councilrsquos planning committee, said it was ldquodisappointing to lose Raceland but felt the idea of a petrol station and other facilities was worth being considered.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray was hopeful a number of local people could find employment ndashthe scheme gets the go ahead.He said: ldquoThe closure of Raceland was disappointing for many people who had enjoyed their experience there over the years.ldquoHowever, the plans submitted for the site look as though they might help improve services for both local people and those travelling through East Lothian on the A, as well as potentially creating a large number of local jobs.ldquoObviously there is some way to go with the development of the site, but I certainly hope that the number of jobs being suggested will materialise as the plans move forward.Maureen Cuthill, chairwoman of Macmerry and Gladsmuir Community Council, felt ldquoit could only be a good thing for the area.She said: ldquoI donrsquot think it is going to encroach on Macmerry or Gladsmuir or anywhere.

title: hannah-12-wows-united-nations-geneva-conference
story: Hannah Richardson travelled with  other youngsters from the Faside area to UN offices in Geneva, working in partnership with Childrens Parliament and the Streets Ahead team.The global talk was on the UNs Day of General Discussion, held lastFriday, where the theme was Children as Human Rights Defenders.She was one of only two children from the UK to be part of Child Rights Connectsglobal advisory team - the other being Cameron Butchart, , also from Tranent.The CRCs team work closely with the UN Committee of Rights of the Child.They were also delivering hand-painted shields, that carried key messages about childrens rights on them, which went on display in the UN offices.Hannah has been working with the UN as a Childrens Advisor to the Committee for the Rights of a Child for the past six months.That included making the plans for the event in Geneva, as well as touring Scotland to educate youngsters on their human rights and finding out what rights are most important to them.This is where the artwork for the shields was created - becoming evidence for what children need and want in Scotland.The youngsters toured UN delegates around the five shields, explaining what they were and what they represented.Hannah said: "I was invited to moderate one of the discussions. It was an exciting experience but I was also really nervous."I did have to tell one or two of the speakers that their time was up and they needed to finish talking and I was really nervous to do that because I didnt want to come out sounding rude, but I think I got away with it."Why am I doing this  I want children to understand their rights and know all their rights so they can stand up for themselves."

title: cockenzie-hearing-told-substation-could-jeopardise-hundreds-of-jobs
story: Inch Cape Offshore Limitedwants to bring energy from their offshore windfarm onto land via a substation on the site of the former Cockenzie Power Station.But the local authority and community councils claim the substation should be sited at a less prominent site, where it could be hidden.They say putting the substation on the coastal site will hamper their ability to market the surrounding land which has the potential to create more than , jobs.The planning application for the substation was called in by Scottish Ministers in March this year ndash a month after East Lothian Council bought the land from ScottishPower.Housing and Planning Minister Kevin Stewart was in Cockenzie to open new affordable housing built next to the former power station site, as a public hearing was being held less than a mile away into the ICOL proposal.He called in the planning application in March this year as First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was on a state visit to China where she met representatives from ICOLrsquos parent company Red Rock.The Scottish Government appointed Reporter Allison Coard called the hearing so she could hear arguments from both side.ICOL said it believed that under current Government policy, which safeguards the site for energy use , their proposal was the ldquo best use of the land.However Ray Montgomery, who has been appointed as project manager for the Cockenzie site by the local authority, branded their claim ldquoridiculous.Mr Montgomery, who was head of infrastructure at the council, told the Reporter the land had potential for huge economic development in the area and the coastal location ICOL wanted to use was the ldquojewel in its crown.He told Ms Coard: ldquoI am concerned thatthis goes through the scale of the development is not compatible with our efforts to bring forward greater employment on that site.ldquoIt is ridiculous to suggest that a power station which employed  people and generated poundmillion a year being replaced with a substation which will employ seven people is best use of the land.A vision for the future of the site was produced on behalf of the council last year after  months of consultations with the local communities.The Cockenzie Masterplan foresees , jobs being created on the former power station site and surrounding landit is developed as it proposes.Ambitious proposals have also been put forward by Prestonpans Community Council for a cruise terminal at the coastal part of the site, while Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council want a marina developed on it.ICOL, which was represented by solicitor Robin Hutchison from international law firm Cameron McKenna Nabarro Olswang, Simon Herriott from Savills, as well as members of the windfarm team, dismissed the proposals put forward by communities for the site as ldquotheoretical.They insisted their substation was the lsquoonlyrsquo project on the table for the site, urging the Reporter not to consider either community council idea.Mr Hutchison told the Reporter: ldquoThe point to take away is that there is no evidence of alternative uses for the site.East Lothian Council and the community councils argue that an alternative site on a less prominent part of the site away from the shore would be better.The local authority argues that ldquobest use of the land would not be served by building the substation on the coastal site, which is seen as a prime attraction for marketing the enire area to future investors.ICOL has confirmed the substation, once built, would only require two employees to visit a few times a year for maintenance.A revised drawing of how it would look on the site which showed the space used reduced sparked anger from community councillor Brian Hickman, representing Cockenzie and Port Seton.He pointed out it was completely dferent to a revised drawing shown to his community council last month which promised something ldquomuch smaller when they were told the land needed would be lsquoshrunkrsquo from  hectares to  hectares.Mr Hickman told the hearing: ldquoI have lost confidence in this application because, in many respects, I do not think you know what you are doing or trying to achieve.Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, said the local community needed jobs.He said: ldquoWe do not have a lot of local employment and that is what we need. The Master Plan talks about , jobs being created. In our view, putting this substation on the foreshore will detract from the possibility to fully develop the site.The Reporter will now consider they representations before making a decision on the next stage of her investigation.Local ward Councillor Lachlan Bruce praised the community council representatives for their presentations to the Reporter.He added: ldquoI was very disappointed by the applicantrsquos dismissive views on what has been suggested for by the local communities for the site.ldquoLots of ideas have been put forward that would create jobs and opportunities on the site and they should be given all due considerations and not just knocked to the wayside so that they can build their big shed that will create no real employment opportunities for the local area.ldquoIrsquom still confident that the Reporter will find that this isnrsquot the best location of substation at Cockenzie and I can only hope that Scottish Government Ministers will make the best decision for the people of East Lothian which is for rejection of this application, I have my doubts that they will.

title: our-community-kitchen-tackling-social-isolation-in-haddington
story: Our Community Kitchen was formed earlier this year as an intergenerational project, which was developed by Dementia Friendly East Lothian.The group was awarded funds from The Big Lottery, with the project, which meets each Tuesday at Haddington Bowling Club, on the townrsquos Wemyss Place, now looking to branch out to become its own organisation.Elaine Gale, from the project, said: ldquoOur Community Kitchen has been incredibly popular since beginning at the bowling club in February this year.ldquoWe have been offered a home within the club including full use of kitchen facilities plus a large area for dining.ldquoWe have developed a wonderful relationship with the committee at the club who are supportive and committed to Our Community Kitchen sharing the space with them.The kitchen currently operates each Tuesday from .pm and plans to expand to three or four days each week from January.Donations of homemade bread, napkins and juice have been made to the group, as well as fruit, which has been turned into jam and pies.Haddingtons community council has helped out, with pound, split between plans toserve a Christmas meal and to purchase a new oven at the bowling club.The group has also been supported by Haddington and Lammermuir Area Partnership .Funding was awarded to enable the group to continue into the New Year.Craig McLachlan, the area partnership chairman, said: ldquoHaddington and Lammermuir Area Partnership are focused on addressing inequalities and poverties across our area and these ambitions are being addressed through the work of our area plan.ldquoOne of the main inequalities that we are seeking to address is around social isolation.ldquoOur area has a growing elderly population, where one in five residents is currently aged  and over and, in addition, there are many new houses being built in and around the town so we need to find ways to help these new residents become involved in, and part of, our community.ldquoOur Community Kitchen are doing excellent work to address this, and other inequalities.ldquoHaddington and Lammermuir Area Partnership are therefore delighted to give them our full support.

title: leuchie-houses-retiring-ceo-mairi-okeefe-praised-by-politicians
story: Mrs OrsquoKeefe will stand down from the helm of the national respite centre next month, south of North Berwick,  years after she took on the role.And Iain Gray MSP and his Westminster counterpart Martin Whitfield MP have both praised her work.Mr Gray, East Lothianrsquos representative at Holyrood since , told the Courier: ldquoIt has been a great pleasure to work with Mairi at Leuchie House over the last few years.ldquoFrom campaigning to save Leuchie from closure to securing signicant funding to keep it going, she has been the driving force behind the unique facilityrsquos success.ldquoMairi and her team have also helped put North Berwick and East Lothian on the map, with many hundreds of people from across Scotland and beyond remembering it fondly for the warm welcome and superb care and hospitality they enjoy at Leuchie.ldquoI know that Mairirsquos retirement as CEO will not mean the end of her involvement at Leuchie, but she will certainly be a very hard act to follow and I wish her all the very best for the future.And Mr Whitfield praised Mrs OrsquoKeefe for her ldquopassion, knowledge and commitment to Leuchiersquos success.He told the Courier: ldquoWhat she and her team have achieved in establishing Leuchie as a very well thought of independent charity is remarkable and she fully deserves all of the praise and plaudits she has received over the years. Irsquom sure Mairi will continue to be part of Leuchiersquos future and wish her and everyone  at the charity continued success in the years ahead.Mrs OrsquoKeefe will be replaced as Leuchie House chief executive by Mark Bevan, the former CEO at the Scottish Council for Development and Industry .

title: new-trustees-appointed-at-east-lothian-foodbank
story: East Lothian Foodbank, based on Tranentrsquos Civic Square, provides a minimum of three daysrsquo emergency food to people in crisis.All food donated to the charity is given to the foodbank by members of the public.Now, Joan Mann, John Boothman, Carly Pryde and Penny Morriss have joined the Foodbankrsquos board.Joan, who is one of the original Foodbank volunteers, also volunteers at the John Gray Centre, Haddington, while John Boothman is a well-known journalist who lives in Prestonpans.Meanwhile, Penny, of Dunbar, has worked in the Scottish charity sector for more than  years, and Carly has been a Scottish Welfare Fund Officer at East Lothian Council for nine years.Liz Kilpatrick, foodbank secretary, said: ldquoTrustees are volunteers too and naturally want to move on to new challenges after a while.ldquoWe feel really lucky that we have found new people with energy, great experience and local knowledge too.ldquoMost people canrsquot believe that the Foodbank has been in existence for almost six years now.ldquoAs a charity we are entering a new phase, thinking about how to develop and whether we can start to reduce the demand for our service, a demand which we have struggled to cope with since the launch of Universal Credit.The Foodbankrsquos previous chairwoman, the Rev Canon Anne Dyer, who was Rector of Haddingtonrsquos Holy Trinity Church, left recently to take up her position as the Bishop of Aberdeen and Orkney.David Raw is the interim chairman of the Foodbank.

title: cardboard-cops-could-be-used-to-halt-speeding-drivers
story: The unusual tactic would involve placing a le-sized version of a police officer, holding a pro-laser speed gun, at the side of the road.A mph vehicle speed limit was recently introduced throughout most of Dunbar and it has been suggested that cut-out police officers could be deployed to encourage motorists to slow down.The issue was discussed at the townrsquos community and police partnershipmeeting.Pippa Swan, from the townrsquos community council, was among those who felt that the idea ndash put forward by PC Gavin Ross ndash had merit.She said: ldquoI personally think that any suggestion our community police officers make has got to be taken very seriously. They know their patch better than anybody and we need to seriously consider it.ldquoI did go and do a little bit of research afterwards and they seem to be used pretty widely across Scotland, pretty successfully.If the lsquonew additionsrsquo were given the green light, East Lothian would follow in the footsteps of Edinburgh, the Scottish Borders and Dundee who already deploy the police cut-outs.Mrs Swan said: ldquoI donrsquot think they are very expensive. If it is just a reminder to people to slow down ndash it would be a good thing given speeding comes up time and again at CAPP meetings.The articial police officers ndash named Bob ndash have been used outside Berwickshire High School, in Duns, in the Scottish Borders.Andrew Mitchell, chairman of Dunsrsquo community council, felt the lsquoofficersrsquo had been beneficial to the town.He said: ldquoThey are pretty well full-size policemen facing you.ldquoAt first glimpse, it looks like real policeman with a radar gun and that is enough to make you check your speed.ldquoI think, to that extent, it does work.But he added: ldquoYou have got to keep moving them to new locations ndash they cannot stay up in anyone place as people just get used to them.ldquoObviously, they are not as effective as proper policemen but they are a reminder.Police Constable Gavin Ross, who chairs the Dunbar CAPP meetings, is to speak to senior officers to sethe cut-outs could be used in Dunbar.

title: 100th-birthday-surprise-for-man-who-eats-in-same-pub-every-day
story: PRESTONPANS resident Jozef Czech turned  last Tuesday and celebrated it in the same way he has marked almost every day for the past decade. . . with lunch at a local pub.For almost every day for the last  years, Jozef has gone to the townrsquos Prestoungrange Gothenburg for his lunch.And true to style, instead of having any of his favourite Polish treats to celebrate the milestone, he opted for his usual ham salad.His small party was attended by his usual lunch companions, we Selina, , and daughter Alex, as well as neighbours John and Margaret.Michelle Wilson, Gothenburg manager, said: ldquoHe has been coming in every day. They live five minutes away.ldquoHe pretty much has the same thing all the time ndash the soup or a salad. We got balloons and cake for himJozefrsquos daughter Alex told the Courier: ldquoWersquove been going in since it opened up, so for about  years now.ldquoWe live nearby. There used to be a cafe on the High Street we used but that shut down.ldquoMy mum said we could go down to Musselburgh as well, but with them being elderly I thought itrsquos better to not go far, and itrsquos always good to support your local.Jozef met his we Selina, who is from Ireland, in Birmingham, after he was demobbed from the Polish Army.ldquoI was stood outside a pub, waiting on my friend coming out, and she said, lsquoTherersquos a few Poles in therersquo and two men walked out, Selina recalled.ldquoI then turned to her and said, lsquoYou take the big one, Irsquoll take the little onersquo and it worked out pretty well!Jozef and Selina married two years later, in , and Jozef began working as a tool-grinder. They moved to Prestonpans in  after visiting Selinarsquos cousin who had married a man from the area.ldquoOur family say she married a Panner and I married a Pole, she added.ldquoWhen I told my friends I was moving they said, lsquoWhy are you going to Scotland ndash theyrsquore all mean rsquo I disagreed. Yoursquore not mean ndash yoursquore canny.Jozef has missed the occasional lunch day ndash the Goth is shut on Mondays and closed at Christmas and New Year.ldquoWe usually get a Christmas dinner and at New Year I just make something at home, Alex said.The Goth has changed hands in recent years but that hasnrsquot stopped the Czech family tradition.ldquoMenus change and people change but we are still happy to go, added Alex. ldquoThey like the people and the menu is ied.Jozef normally orders from the pound. pensionersrsquo menu and always accompanies his meal with a cup of tea.However, Alex was prepared to ulge a little secret.She added: ldquoOccasionally, at weekends, he will treat himself to the specials!

title: tributes-paid-to-great-guy-george-edgar
story: George Edgar, , passed away on September  and was buried on September  at Deer Park Cemetery, Dunbar.He had been a determined fundraiser for Macmillan Cancer Support, raising more than pound, since he was diagnosed with bowel cancer in .His we, Carol, led the tributes and said: ldquoHe was a loveable rogue. Honestly, he was just so happy and happy-go-lucky.ldquoHe never once let anything get him down. He was always a joker and a character.The keen sports fan was diagnosed with bowel cancer before Christmas six years ago.George, of Dunbarrsquos Rotary Court, underwent an operation to remove part of his colon and also endured gruelling chemotherapy.Unfortunately, he was later told the cancer was incurable.Despite that, George raised thousands of pounds for charity through golf, darts and football events.And his love of sport played a key part at his funeral, with those in attendance asked to wear bright colours or sporting tops.Carol, , said: ldquoHe loved golf, darts and football.George was previously involved with Dunbar Athletic Football Club and Callum White, who previously managed the side and is now the clubrsquos secretary, also paid tribute to a ldquodedicated man.He said: ldquoHe was one of those guys who was more behind the scenes and would help collect the strips, the money, and make sure everything was organised.Hannah Renton, owner of the Royal Mackintosh Hotel, where George had worked, described the dad and grandad as ldquoloved by all our staff.She said: ldquoHe was a great guy and a great head chef.ldquoHe took on the role when we opened up and only stopped because he had to stop working.ldquoHe was really hard working and would always go out of his way to do a lot.ldquoHe would still pop back in to see us.ldquoHe was a great guy and was loved by all our staff.Craig McLachlan, who owns Castle Park Golf Club near Gford, where Mr Edgar was a member, also offered kind words.A golf competition, the George Edgar Memorial Trophy, has been created.Mr McLachlan said: ldquoHe was hugely buoyant, hugely positive. He was a character who a lot of people could learn a lot from.ldquoHe raised a phenomenal amount for charity, even with working with us up here. I think in the short time we worked together for Macmillan we raised more than pound,.He will be sadly missed.And he added: ldquoI think it sums him up that earlier this year him and one of his good friends John Winters were going to be our charity representatives.ldquoWe were planning a charity weekend up here and sadly Georgersquos health overtook it.ldquoThat is an effort we will redouble next year, partly in his memory.

title: tranents-landmark-former-co-op-building-to-re-open-in-november
story: Mr Thomson, the townrsquos former postmaster, bought the former Co-op building in  with his we Susan, the current postmaster, and will install a cafe, bistro, childrenrsquos soft play, and Post Office into the building.He told the Courier: ldquoWersquore in the first phase, whichyou like is the Historic Scotland listed building part, which is going to be a brand new Post Office, convenience store, a coffee shop and bistro with about  seats inside and about  seats outside under a canopy. Thatrsquoll be opening in November.Mr Thomsonrsquos plans also include  flats for the building, which he hopes will be social housing.He said: ldquoWersquore hoping the whole thing can be finished by the start of May . The flats are going to be for social housing, preferably with East Lothian Council or East Lothian Housing Association, so really the timelines we have to do together.ldquoWe want social housing because therersquos a housing crisis in East Lothian and we want to try and help people with that.The Tranent resident was also very complimentary of the work of youth group Recharge.He said: ldquoRecharge have been in this building a very long time and Alan [Bell] runs it very well.ldquoOne of the key things that I wanted to make sure of when my we and I bought this building was we wanted to keep them on site as they do a fantastic job.After phase one is complete, work will start on phase two of the project.The next phase will include two small shops, flats, a soft play area and a community hall which will, it is hoped, hold about  people, as well as a kitchen and bar.Alan Bell, Recharge manager, was pleased the charity will get a new home within the building ndash they currently use part of the ground floor.He told the Courier: ldquoI think certainly, from our point of view, having a purpose-built facility will be fantastic.ldquoIt will really be able to extend the work we can do and help us reach out to a lot of young people that we currently struggle to engage with, because of our space limitations.ldquoWith it being purpose-built as well it means wersquoll be able to do more work with young people, so there will be rooms designed for specic tasks, whereas in here, we just adapt the rooms as we can. That will make a massive dference.He also reassured those who use their facilities at the moment that they will not be going away any time soon.Mr Bell added: ldquoThe building is secure and we will have a base to operate from whilst the work is being done. Recharge are still operating while the building is developed.

title: decision-soon-on-the-quay-plans
story: Amanda Chisholm, the independent reporter appointed to determine the appeal on behalf of Scottish Ministers, carried out an inspection of the site at Fisherrow Harbour last month.Lodged by Simply Musselburgh Care Limited, the appeal followed East Lothian Councilrsquos refusal of a plan to convert the former leisure complex, restaurant andsuites into a -bed nursing home.Ms Chisholm is now preparing her decision, a copy of which will be sent to all parties involved and published on the Planning and Environmental Appeals Divisionrsquos website.A meeting of the local authorityrsquos planning committee in June regarding The Quay, owned by Dr Charan Gill, ended with a near-unanimous decision to reject the nursing home proposal.Only Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning committee convener, backed council officialsrsquo recommendation to approve the plan.Local groups including Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council, Musselburgh Area Partnership, and Musselburgh Conservation Society, among others, are calling for the appeal to be thrown out., Musselburgh Area Partnership, Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association, and the Musselburgh Business Partnership are calling for the appeal to be thrown out.

title: tims-tales-johnny-moat-forever
story: The legend tells us that so long as the stone sits on the rocks, the town will flourish.It fell in  but was put back in  after a hard time for the town.It sadly fell again a few years ago, but at the time of the film Johnny Moat was sitting proudly on his ldquothrone on the Girdle Rocks.Film maker Marjory Boyle Crooks had been keen to capture the tale on camera. It was a lovely calm and sunny day, perfect for filming,I was halfway through the story when a group of local teenage lads approached. It seemed they were drinking and I anticipated them disrupting the filming.But I continued telling the story as it had been a perfect take up until that moment.The lads paused for a moment then all sat on the concrete walkway watching me and the film makers. They said nothing and seemed to be listening.I was able to complete my story uninterrupted.And as I walked away in the final shot I made eye contact with the lads and they respectfully waited until the filming had stopped before shouting, ldquoJohnny Moat forever! Then they got up and walked away.It was an unexpected and powerful moment for me.My assumptions about the lads had been utterly challenged as well.This was more than six years ago but I was reminded of it when I visited Johnny Moat this week with my wee boy Lewis.We were having our weekly storytelling walk in the Pans, a three-hour period between his nursery pick up and when I have to pick up his sister Skye from the Infant School.We just walk together visiting dferent places, and I tell him stories and he does the same.Most of his stories this day involved a T Rex or Raptor, which in his imagination wander about Prestonpans.So our respective tales were a bit dferent in content and style, but what is vital at this age is that he hears stories and is allowed to tell them freely.I told him the story of Johnny Moat and he said it looks like a whale.As we wandered from Johnny Moat up to Preston Tower, we stopped at what we call the lsquoStory Stonesrsquo.Here a small circle of stones sit underneath a cherry tree, with the tower looming behind. It is a perfect place to tell stories.Lewis gave me a new version of his T Rex tale here. I couldnrsquot understand all his story, but I got most of it.Then he said it was my turn so I told him a child-friendly version of the tale of the Green Lady. It made him want to go and look in the windows of the tower, which we did.The final story began at the old doorsquocot in the gardens by the tower. I explained it was a house for pigeons, but Lewis was having none of that.ldquoNo daddy, he said with a serious face, ldquoa lion lives there.ldquoReally  Can you tell me the story of the lion  I asked. And so he obliged.It was a great story, and we tracked the lion to the ancient Mercat Cross, where the unicorn sits on top of the pole ldquolooking for the lion.Then he spotted the lion on the  bus coming from Tranent.ldquoWill it eat the people  I asked.ldquoNo, he said asIrsquod asked an inappropriate question, ldquoitrsquos a nice lion.And so with the lion having left town, we headed for the Infant School to pick up his sister, but still keeping a look out for the T Rex.On the surface this may all seem a bit unusual, wandering about telling random stories that often didnrsquot make huge sense.But I value this time with my son, and as a storyteller I know the importance of it.Storytelling in this way when our kids are young helps develop what is called oral narrative ability, which gives a child the skills to explain and describe things, and develop their understanding of words and language.It fires their imagination and research shows that this can help with the enjoyment of reading and writing later on, and of telling and hearing stories.That night my son unexpectedly ed to the story of Johnny Moat.I had earlier told him it had fallen down and is lying face down in the sand and itrsquos too heavy to put back, but hopefully one day there will be a way.Like all kids his age, he took a while to process his thoughts on this. And these thoughts came out at bedtime.ldquoThe T Rex can put the big stone back, he said. I admired his total faith in the abilities of the T Rex.ldquoYes, maybe, I said. He fell asleep holding his T Rex which, for him, symbolises so much more than just an extinct dinosaur.As I headed downstairs, I thought about the connection between this day and the day over six years ago when I unexpectedly told the story of Johnny Moat to some teenage lads.Stories weave through us and bind us in a shared identity. But it made me sad that Johnny Moat still lies forgotten with his face in the sand.So Irsquom going to start looking for the T Rex of the Pans, whoever that may be, who can help. He or she must be out there somewhere. Or perhaps there is a crowd of them.The hope is that once my son is a teenage lad himself, he will be able to sit on the Girdle Rocks with Johnny Moat and tell the legend.

title: group-objects-to-750-new-homes-at-windygoul-south
story: A planning application for the site was submitted last month by Walker Group Ltd.The site plan extends Windygoul South to the Charles River Research Institute and Carlaverock Farm.But at a TECC meeting, members voiced their concerns over the proposals.Robert McNeill, community councillor, told the meeting: ldquoIn all my years on the community council, I canrsquot recall us making a formal objection about any developments in Tranent.ldquoWe try to be very proactive to any problems and find a solution. However, I think we really need to take a stand on this one.Mr McNeill added: ldquoI think we need to be clear that it will have a major impact on our community. Not just on schools, or traffic, but GPs and our health, the environment, the cemetery.ldquoI just feel thatwe donrsquot object to this application now, I donrsquot think I can continually voice my concerns about traffic and the impact on the community. I think itrsquos time for us to take a stand.ldquoBy objecting, we are making our views known, and itrsquos a view shared by many in Tranent.ldquoMaybe a lot of people donrsquot want to be vocal about it, but I do think itrsquos an opportunity that we cannot miss.ldquoI do think as a community we need to be sending a clear message out. Enough is enough. The community canrsquot take it any longer.David Forrest, TECC chairman, shared these concerns, pointing out the lack of infrastructure as the main reason for objecting to the plans.He said: ldquoGrounds for an objection has to be that the infrastructure in Tranent couldnrsquot cope with another  houses on the south side of Tranent.ldquoAll that traffic would be travelling through the centre, whether itrsquos to get to Edinburgh or just to go shopping.ldquoTranent is unique, traffic-wise, in East Lothian. You have Ormiston which has doubled or trebled in size, yoursquore going to have all these houses on the south side, and theyrsquore all still going to go down Tranent High Street. Nobody drives into North Berwick or Dunbar through the main street. Tranent is totally dferent.ldquoAnother  houses will all go through the main street in Tranent and thatrsquos the point wersquove got to get across.Fellow TECC member David Thomson added: ldquoEast Lothian Council made a statement about April, that there was no need to improve the infrastructure. However, on the recent Kingslaw planning application, they actually said that the impact on traffic from  houses would be excessive and detrimental to the local community.ldquoIf they deem that that  houses is excessive, how can they possibly say that  houses is not going to be three, four times, worse than that.ldquoUntil the roads are built they shouldnrsquot be building the houses.

title: teachers-time-in-turkey-inspires-her-debut-novel
story: Set in the Turkish capital Istanbul, Dr Margaret Halliday chose the location for her book as she worked as a teacher in the country for seven years.She decided to take up writing seriously five years ago when she was unable to live the same lestyle because of multiple sclerosis .An avid writer of diaries throughout her le, during which she saw the world, she planned to expand them into short stories when she retired.Dr Halliday, , who lives near Fisherrow, said: ldquoIrsquom excited about my first novel being published.ldquoAfter writing three memoirs, I wanted to try fiction as I had completed an Open University creative writing course.ldquoTaking the advice, lsquoyou should write about what you know,rsquo I chose Turkey for the setting as I worked there for seven years.The Belly Dancer is a tragicomic romantic thriller set mainly in Istanbul in the early s.Gemma, a young English woman, finds herself involved in more than just teaching English soon after her arrival in Turkey. Her love of belly dancing leads her into a relationship with the beautul Fatima as well as plunging her into a sinister, Mafia-run drugs operation.Dr Halliday said: ldquoI did not, however, belly dance or get involved with the Turkish Mafia and drug dealing ndash these had to be researched!ldquoLike Gemma, the heroine, I did teach English and visited Termal regularly, wallowing in the sparsquos waters just like her, as well as indulging in the occasional massage.ldquoNow I am putting together a collection of short stories, working title, Stranger than Fiction, about some of my weirder travel experiences. I have a character who Irsquod like to write another novel about but need to work on the plotrsquos development.Dr Halliday has published three autobiographical books ndash Prana Soup, an Indian Odyssey, which describes her travels around India Good Vibrations, which tells the story of a single s mum in Scotland and WWOOFing North and South, which relates her experience as a worldwide worker on organic farms in Scotland and New Zealand.Born in England in  with ldquogreen fingers and itchy feet, Dr Halliday undertook a yearrsquos training in Hastings Alexandra Park, followed by a horticultural course at the West of Scotland Agricultural College. She fell in love with Scotland, married a Scotsman and raised two children while working in scientic research and studying up to doctorate level.She qualied as a teacher of biology and chemistry and taught in ious schools and colleges in Edinburgh.Dr Halliday said her marriage broke up in , partly because of her ldquoitchy feet, and she went to live in Istanbul in , where she taught biological sciences at Marmara University for five years.After that, she taught English in Budapest and Damascus, exploring the countries and their environs in her holidays. Then she ed to Turkey and taught biology at a school for gted children near Istanbul.Her books are available via Amazon.as ebook and paperbacks.

title: housing-bid-at-edenhall
story: Stewart Milne Homes Central Scotland Limited is seeking East Lothian Council approval for the housing within the walled garden of historic Pinkieburn House, which was designed by renowned Scottish architect John Dick Peddie.The site, which was associated with the estate of the Lindsay family in the early th century, became disused in  following NHS Lothianrsquos decision to relocate services to the newly developed Musselburgh Primary Care Centre.The residential development would include  new homes for private sale, which range from four to six-bedroom detached homes.The th century buildings on the site would be ldquosympathetically restored to provide  new luxury apartments and homes.There would be a further  new affordable homes, providing one-bed apartments to three-bed terraced houses, ldquoensuring a wide mix of new homes for Musselburgh.A statement from the company added: ldquoThis will help address the critical need for new high-quality housing in the town ndash with careful planning and contextual design leading to the creation of communities that are designed to reflect the sitersquos local heritage.ldquoStewart Milne Homes intend to deliver a high-quality development, based around the unique heritage assets of the restored and converted listed buildings at Edenhall, including Pinkieburn House, the stables and gardenerrsquos cottage.ldquoCareful consideration has been given to the look and feel of this development to provide a sense of community and legacy.ldquoThe proposed residential development will involve conversion of the listed buildings to form flatted apartments, and extended cottage and other linked villas, along with new build houses for sale where within the site.ldquoThis will be an exciting opportunity to prevent the buildings and wider estate falling into further disrepair, and ultimately bring the setting back into appropriate residential use. Restoration and repair work will be conducted on a like for like basis, using materials to match the existing historic fabrics.It added: ldquoTo allow for high quality flood management, road access and opening the area for better daylight, some tree management work will be required.The site is allocated for residential development in the Proposed East Lothian Local Development Plan.The proposed housing development would be served by the existing access from Edenhall Road, with the existing junction widened through relocation of the gate piers.Gerry More, managing director of Stewart Milne Homes Central Scotland, said: ldquoFollowing our initial public consultation and exhibition two years ago, our proposals have been welcomed by the local community.ldquoOur vision is to create new communities that are fit for st century living, whilst incorporating traditional values and features.Speaking at a meeting of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council last week, group chairwoman Irene Tait said the last time she was at the site it was ldquoall overgrown.She added: ldquoIt was horrible and dangerous, so it needs something done to it. They have got security measures but it becomes a danger for local children, although theyrsquore not supposed to be there.

title: schools-head-of-drama-sacked-following-disturbing-allegations
story: Daniel McLean-Steel, , was suspended by the headmaster of Loretto School in Musselburgh three weeks ago.Dr Graham Hawley contacted parents last week, the Courier has learnt, to inform them that Mr McLean-Steelrsquos employment had been ldquoterminated.Mr Hawley said: ldquoThe investigation has necessarily been a complex, detailed and thorough undertaking, and we have worked as expeditiously as we have been able.ldquoUnderstandably, during this period there have been a range of concerns and questions, and I hope that our personal responses to each have, wherever possible, served to inform and reassure you and others in so far as we have been able.ldquoThe investigation has now been completed, and the outcome of the process has been to terminate the employment of a member of staff, Mr Daniel McLean-Steel.The headmaster told parents he expected questions about the ldquonature of the complaint.But he said he was not revealing any details in his statement ldquofor legal reasons, despite also confirming that there was no active police investigation.In a previous statement, issued on September , the headmaster said that he had been ldquodeeply disturbed by these allegations" and took them "very seriously".Mr Hawley has now said: ldquoAs I have already indicated in my letter and statement of Wednesday  September , the allegations were in relation to behaviours which are unacceptable and have no place in our community, and the investigation has found this to be the case.ldquoI can confirm there is no active police case in association with this matter at this time, and I can also confirm the allegations presented did not relate to current pupils of the school."For legal reasons, it is not appropriate that I make further comment on this.The headmaster told parents he has begun a recruitment process to find a new head of drama. He also urged parents to contact himthey have any further concerns.When the allegations emerged Mr Hawley said he had alerted the Care Inspectorate.A spokesman for the Care Inspectorate said: ldquoWe are aware of an alleged incident at this school and are satisfied the school have responded appropriately.ldquoWe remain in close contact with the school. Anyone with a concern about a care service is encouraged to contact us.Mr McLean-Steel could not be reached for comment.

title: man-targeted-two-musselburgh-businesses
story: Peter Rodgers, of Edinburghrsquos Parkhead Avenue, forced open a locked office door at Musselburghrsquos Costa Coffee outlet and searched lockers within the staff office.
