title: community-to-have-its-say-on-how-70000-is-spent
story: Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell MSP visited The Brunton on Tuesday to announce the Scottish Governmentrsquos Community Choices Funding for  , with the Musselburgh Area Partnership to receive pound,.This will be supplemented by pound, from the area partnership, which allocates a budget from East Lothian Council to a iety of local priorities and initiatives in Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig, Carberry and Old Craighall.Ms Campbell said: ldquoThe Community Choices Fund puts decisions about how we invest in communities into the hands of the people who live and work in them. This way of directly involving people is going from strength to strength, establishing itself firmly in Scotland.ldquoTackling poverty and community empowerment are two key priorities for this government. We know that communities are best placed to address the inequalities in their own areas and therefore know what improvements can be made.And she added: ldquoIrsquom pleased that there are so many organisations that will benefit from this funding. Making this announcement during Challenge Poverty Week highlights how everyone in the community can play their part when it comes to tackling poverty.The area partnershiprsquos successful bid for funding follows on from its Your Voice, Your Choice enterprise last year.At that time, it received pound, inCommunity Choices Funding for an initiative aimed at young people.Representatives from local schools voted for the youth projects they wished to see receive the cash aid, which also included pound, from the area partnership.During Tuesdayrsquos visit to Musselburgh, Ms Campbell got the chance to hear from two of the successful recipients: the Plastics Police, a group of Stoneyhill Primary School youngsters who secured funding to buy promotional material to raise awareness of the risk to people, animals and aquatic le from dumping plastics which end up in the ocean and Musselburgh Grammar School pupil Esraa Al Dabbas, who was sponsored by the Syrian support officer at East Lothian Council to develop a Freedom Youth Club for those new to the community.The new tranche of Community Choices Funding saw  community groups across Scotland sharing more than pound, to host events and give people a direct voice in how funds should be invested on priorities in their areas.Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, said: ldquoI am delighted that Ms Campbell chose to visit the Musselburgh Area Partnership to announce the funding.ldquoIt was an amazing opportunity for some of the young people involved in the project to speak to the Cabinet Secretary, and for Ms Campbell to see first-hand the amazing work being done by young people in the Musselburgh area as a result of our Participatory Budgeting initiative Your Voice, Your Choice.Stuart Baxter, Musselburgh area manager, added: ldquoWe are now working on this yearrsquos Participatory Budgeting project that will tackle poverty and inequalities in the Musselburgh area and I am sure by continuing the hard work and commitment the community will help deliver another outstanding success.He said a working group and ldquostringent guidelines would have to be set up to progress the townrsquos second Your Voice Your Choice event.He added that other agencies, such as the Citizens Advice Bureau and Poverty Commission, would also be brought on-board.The Scottish Government has set aside pound. million to increase the numbers of people involved in making decisions about investment in their local areas.In  , the Community Choices Fund helped more than , people vote for the things that mattered to them in their title: woman-is-found-crying-for-help-in-tranent
story: Martin Ellard had been socialising and drinking with partner at his Carlaverock Avenue home when ldquoa prolonged argument was said to have broken out between the pair.Neighbours heard shouting and screaming coming from within the property, while they also heard a woman ldquoscreaming and crying.His partner was then forced to run into the street where she was found to be ldquocrying for help following the altercation with Ellard in July this year.A passer-by saw Ellard telling her to get back inside the property but the man intervened by askingshe needed help before calling the police.Police officers arrived at about .pm to find the woman still out in the street where she was described as being ldquoupset and distressed.Ellard, , was then traced and arrested by police at about .am the following day and soon admitted the altercation.The construction worker pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening and abusive manner by shouting, swearing and acting aggressively towards the woman at his home address on July  this year.He also admitted a second similar charge during Tuesdayrsquos appearance at Edinburgh Sherf Court when he pleaded guilty to behaving aggressively towards the same woman on February  this year.Fiscal depute Mark Keane said that on this occasion the pair were within Ellardrsquos car at Newbigging, Musselburgh, when ldquoa verbal altercation broke out and the woman felt she could not continue with the relationship.She made her way to Musselburgh Sports Centre to use the gym but when she left the facility later ldquothe accused followed her despite being told ldquoto leave her alone.Again a passer-by heard the woman in distress and called the police.Ellardrsquos solicitor told Sherf Peter McCormack she would reserve her mitigation to the sentencing diet.Sherf McCormack deferred sentence, for the preparation of background reports, to October .

title: jerba-campervans-becomes-one-of-scotlands-first-employee-owned-businesses
story: Jerba Campervans, of Halfland Barns, near North Berwick, was founded by husband-and-we Simon Poole and Cath Brookes in  and focuses in luxury conversions of the VW Transporter T.In January, it became  per owned by its staff.In the months following, the business has experienced an  per cent rise in productivity, with revenue on track to grow  per cent to pound.m for the year.Mr Poole said: ldquoWe employ people who love what they do. As a result, wersquove benefited from amazing loyalty from those who have been instrumental in building the business.ldquoBecoming employee-owned was simply the right thing to do both morally and practically.ldquoOur productivity and growth figures for the year demonstrate what can be achieved with employee ownership.In becoming employee-owned, the two owners transferred all shares into the Jerba Campervans Trust.The trust board is made up of one employee appointed by the directors an employee elected by staff and an external accountant.The co-directors report to the trust board, which ensures the business is being run for the benefit of the employees.Mr Poole said that the change was ldquobenefiting every aspect of the business.He added: ldquoOur staff are more invested in what we do ndash the wind in their sails is not letting up.

title: interim-asbo-issued-against-haddington-resident
story: Lee Rutherford, who is living care of an address in Langriggs, was the subject of a string of complaints stretching back two years, including smoking cannabis in and around the property, arguing, screaming, shouting and banging doors and acting in an aggressive manner ndash all of which caused alarm and distress to residents of the street.Despite repeated warnings, the anti-social behaviour continued and the interim Anti-Social Behaviour Orderwas applied for by East Lothian Council and later granted at Edinburgh Sherf Court on Wednesday .East Lothian Councilrsquos Safer Communities Team worked closely with Police Scotland to compile the dossier of evidence which was used to prepare the case against Mr Rutherford.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe take anti-social behaviour very seriously and it will not be tolerated in East Lothian as it causes a signicant level of disruption, fear and distress to our residents, which we deem unacceptable."Mr Rutherford has a long history of behaving in an anti-social manner which is why the council applied for this interim ASBO."We will take similar action against those who persist in behaving in an unacceptable way.The interim order will prevent Mr Rutherford from behaving in the manner described until November  when the case will call again.At that time, the council will ask the court to grant an ASBO in the same terms as the interim order but for a period of two years.

title: the-scotsman-and-i-newspaper-publisher-johnston-press-puts-itself-up-for-sale
story: The group- which has a stable of titles including the i newspaper ndash said it is seeking offers for a takeover.The decision comes as a result of a strategic review, which Johnston launched in  to assess options for refinancing pound million of bonds due for repayment next year.The company said it is not currently in discussions with any potential buyers.Speculation that the publisher would be sold has been growing since it announced the strategic review in March .In August , the companyrsquos share price spiked, surging by as much as % in afternoon trading amid rumours that a mystery buyer was quietly snapping up more stock.Bidders for the business could include activist shareholder Custos Group, which already owns more than % of Johnston Press.Custos Group, which is headed by Norwegian entrepreneur Christen Ager-Hanssen, reportedly said in August that it would bea prospective bidder for the businessit went into administration.At its most recent trading update, Johnston reported a hit to revenues, mostly due to changes in Google and Facebook algorithms.Total revenue fell % to pound million for the first half of , despite a boost from the i newspaper.In the same period, the companyswung out of the red with interim pre-tax profits of pound. million against losses of pound. million a year earlier, although the turnaround was largely thanks to a one-off pound. million accounting gain.

title: merkel-allies-brace-for-big-setback-in-german-state-election
story: Polls suggest Baiarsquos centre-right Christian Social Union party , which has run the region for  years, is heading for its worst performance since the s on Sunday.It appears to be losing voters on both the right and left despite enviable prosperity and unemployment at a rock bottom .%.The CSU, which is socially conservative and has taken a hard line on migration, exists only in Baia and is an important but often awkward sister to Mrs Merkelrsquos Christian Democratic Union .The two parties govern Germany in an infighting-prone coalition with the centre-left Social Democrats.Though the CSU is unlikely to lose power in Baia altogether, a result like the one pollsters are forecasting would be humiliating.Speculation is re that party leader Horst Seehofer, Germanyrsquos interior minister, could be forced out.ldquoThe CSU has lost its cohesive power in Baia mdash it was able to win over voters from the right to the centre-left, said Manfred Guellner, the head of the Forsa polling agency.ldquoNow, because of its confrontational course with its sister party, with the chancellor, it has driven away the liberal centre.On the other side, the far-right Alternative for Germany is appealing to voters looking for an uncompromising anti-migration and law-and-order stance.About . million people are eligible to vote in the election for the state legislature in Munich.For decades, the CSU attracted voters from across the spectrum, standing for a combination of modernity and tradition encapsulated by the slogan ldquoLaptops and Lederhosen.It has held an absolute majority in the state legislature for all but five of the last  years and prides itself on punching above its weight in national politics.Lately, that tradition has been evident largely in battles over migration between Mr Seehofer and Mrs Merkel.Mr Seehofer joined Mrs Merkelrsquos Cabinet in March after giving up his job as Baiarsquos governor to younger rival Markus Soeder following a long-running CSU power struggle.ldquoI can only say that voters donrsquot appreciate it, and we can see that in the polls, when we argue with each other and they donrsquot even understand what about, Mrs Merkel said last weekend as she reviewed the year since Germanyrsquos last national election.In that vote, all three governing parties lost signicant support and Alternative for Germany entered the national parliament.The CSU, with its eyes firmly on the Baian election, doubled down on tough talk about migration.That has ided Mrs Merkel and Mr Seehofer since , when he assailed her decision to leave Germanyrsquos borders open as refugees and others crossed the Balkans.Mr Seehofer triggered the most serious crisis yet in Mrs Merkelrsquos fourth-term government, when the pair sparred in June over whether to turn back small numbers of asylum-seekers at the German-Austrian border.The argument briefly threatened to bring down the administration and end his partyrsquos alliance with Mrs Merkelrsquos.He played a starring role in a second crisis last month, doggedly backing the head of Germanyrsquos domestic intelligence agency amid demands that he be removed for appearing to downplay recent far-right violence against migrants.Mrs Merkelrsquos governing coalition needed two attempts to reach a compromise.Mr Seehoferrsquos tactics have started annoying even conservatives who support his positions.Volker Bouffier, a conservative seeking re-election as governor of neighbouring Hesse state in an October  election, remarked recently the -year-old CSU leader has performed ldquooutstanding services, but he has a tendency to make lone, surprising decisions.Mr Soeder, the new governor, has switched from even tougher talk on migration than Mr Seehofer to trying to project an inclusive image as Baian leader.Polls suggest the switch has not been convincing.They put support for the CSU as low as % mdash down from .% in , in an election held at the height of Mrs Merkelrsquos popularity when Mr Seehofer regained the absolute majority it lost five years earlier.Alternative for Germany did not field candidates then, but looks set to win % or more this time.The Greens are running second, with support of up to %, and the Social Democrats mdash struggling badly in national polls mdash could lose nearly half of the .% they won five years ago.Such a result would leave the CSU seeking either an ideologically dficult coalition with the left-leaning Greens or an alliance with one or more of the pro-business Free Democrats, the centre-right Free Voters and the Social Democrats.A four-way coalition without the CSU might be mathematically possible, but is unlikely.Mr Soeder has blamed ldquopolitics in Berlin for poor ratings in Baia with Mr Seehofer already insisting he will stay in his job after the election.And Mrs Merkel, her authority already weakened by the government infighting and the ouster of a close ally as her partyrsquos parliamentary leader, will be hoping poor election results in Baia and Hesse do not create new problems before a party convention in December where her leadership is due for renewal.The government must ldquobetter present its actions, she said Saturday, adding: ldquoI want to make my contribution to that.

title: is-this-the-worlds-unhealthiest-pizza-glasgow-takeaway-launches-deep-fried-mars-bar-calzone
story: Described as a lsquoGlaswegian twistrsquo on the Italian food it is served with grated almonds on top of the pizza dough, caramel sauce and a scoop of chocolate ice cream.It is packed with Mars Bar chunks then cooked in batter and dubbed by locals as the Mars-gherita Pizza.With an estimated , calories packed into the snack, sold at Romans Pizzeria in Merchant City, Glaswegians have been flocking to try it.The takeaway is inspired by the notorious deep-fried Mars Bar treat invented in  at a Stonehaven, Aberdeenshire, chippy - Haven Chip Bar .Romanrsquos general manager, Fraser Walker, said the idea behind the deep fried Mars Bar calzone came from a simple conversation with the head chef.The -year-old, from Kelvindale, said: "Well the shop has been open here for about five and a half months and we wanted to bring out something dferent."This is because we are known for our Roman-style pizza, and after speaking to the chef about dferent ideas we came up with that."Weve seen restaurants adding Nutella in a calzone so we just thought the deep fried mars bar is a Scottish thing. So why not put it in a calzone "Its definitely not a dessert for someone who is on a diet."I would say people should share it because its very sweet unless you have a sweet tooth or are really hungry."Costing pound., the calzone has been a hit with punters, with one person even asking a relative to send a pizza to Germany.Head chef, Dawid Radzinski, said: "Ive been a chef for  years and what weve done is completely original."When I first made it, we all tried it together and we all loved it. The dessert has been here since Monday and people think its really tasty."I think this was a great idea"INGREDIENTS:" pizza dough   caloriesTwo deep fried mars bars  , caloriesCaramel sauce g   caloriesOne tablespoonof sugar   caloriesA handful of almonds   caloriesOne scoop of chocolate ice cream   caloriesTotal  , calories

title: sturgeons-message-of-hope-bids-to-heal-rift-on-indyref2
story: The First Minister will tell the SNP conference in Glasgow it is up to the party to offer hope in the midst of the unfolding calamity engulfing Westminster.Under pressure from the Yes movement to accelerate the push for independence, she said she might use her mandate to demand a new vote before the  Holyrood election.She told ITV: ldquoIrsquod like there to be a second independence referendum yesterday and failing yesterday, tomorrow ndash but itrsquos not just down to what I want.But critics insisted there was nothing optimistic about breaking up the UK and called on Ms Sturgeon to take a ldquoisive and unnecessary second referendum off the table.Ms Sturgeonrsquos dficulties in balancing the cautious and gung-ho factions in her party were highlighted by one of her senior MPs suggesting independence could be achieved without a repeat of rsquos referendum ndash flying in the face of party policy.Angus Brendan MacNeil, who has been the MP for the Western Isles since , said the SNP must not ldquodither and instead act on independence here and now.He told conference delegates that ldquoanother way would have to be foundthe UK Government refused to allow a legally binding vote through a so-called Section  order.Meanwhile, SNP Brexit Secretary Mike Russell told a fringe meeting that there would have to be discussions about what happened nextunionist parties blocked a fresh referendum.It comes after Joanna Cherry QC, the SNPrsquos justice spokeswoman at Westminster, said Scotland could break off from the UK without a second vote.She insisted a ldquodemocratic event such as a general election would be enough, but critics branded her comments dangerous and ill-judged. The SNPrsquos official position is that a referendum is necessary. Ms Sturgeon has argued a fresh independence push can only be made once the outcome of the Brexit negotiations becomes clear.But yesterday she said a second referendum before  was ldquostill possible, stressing the Scottish Parliament has a mandate to push ahead with a new vote.Deputy leader Keith Brown told SNP delegates the party was ldquostepping up the campaign for independence. But the cautious approach favoured by the leadership provoked unhappiness among some delegates. One told a Brexit fringe meeting that members were ldquovery frustrated with constantly being told to just wait and suggested time was ldquoslipping away.Addressing the SNP conference, Ms Sturgeon will insist an independent Scotland would offer an escape from the chaos engulfing Westminster. She will say: ldquoThe Westminster Government stumbles from day to day and disaster to disaster. Itrsquos hard to watch that unfolding calamity and feel anything other than despair.ldquoSo it is up to us ndash now more than ever ndash to offer optimism and hope.ldquoJust think how much more hope will be possible when we take Scotlandrsquos future into Scotlandrsquos hands and become an independent country.ldquoAn independent Scotland, just as Scotland is now, will be a beacon for progressive values ndash equality, opportunity, ersity and fairness.ldquoIndeed those values feel more important today than ever before in my letime.The First Minister will insist the SNP Government is working ldquoday in, day out, step by step, to change lives for the better.She will announce a new default position ndash dubbed ldquoFair Work First ndash which will see firms receiving Government contracts and grants required to pay the living wage, ditch zero-hours contracts and take action on gender pay gaps.Scottish Tory chief whip Maurice Golden said Ms Sturgeon had ldquoled the SNP troops half way into battle, and then called halt.He said: ldquoWhen it comes to Scotlandrsquos future, everyone in the SNP has an opinion but nobody has a plan.ldquoAll the while, Scotlandrsquos schools are going backwards, waiting times are being missed, and the economy is in the slow lane.ldquoNicola Sturgeon can show leadership today by doing the right thing: and taking a second referendum off the table. The SNP army might not like it, but at least theyrsquod know what was going on.Pamela Nash, chief executive of anti-independence group Scotland in Union, insisted there was ldquonothing optimistic about Scotland leaving the United Kingdom.It comes as a new poll found Scottish voters overwhelmingly back Holyrood having the final say on whether another independence referendum should be held.A total of  per cent said the Scottish Parliament should decide, while just % said it should be down to Westminster.

title: snp-minister-likens-brexit-to-the-highland-clearances
story: Christina McKelvie, minister for older people and equalities, said both involved wealthy elites telling people what to do.She told a fringe meeting at the SNPs conference in Glasgow:"Rich, privileged, entitled people, shting people to the clf edge  years ago,  years ago, now. Still doing the same thing."Scottish Tory MSPDonald Cameron labelled the "inflammatory comments" an "utter disgrace".He said: "This kind of extreme, prejudiced and ill-informed rhetoric is also incredibly insulting to those who voted for Brexit, and shows a wilful misunderstanding of the reasons they voted as they did.ldquoPeople want politicians to get on with delivering a good Brexit deal which works for Scotland and many will be aghast at such an appalling outburst from a government minister, as yet again the SNP attempt to stoke the fires of grievance.Hundreds of thousands of people left the Highlands during the Clearances, which lasted between roughly  and .The period has become synonymous with tales of cruelty at the hands of landlords seeking to cash in on sheep farming.Ms McKelvie was addressing an SNP conference meeting marking six months to go before the UK is due to leave the European Union.She said: "A few weeks ago I had the real privilege to be up at Helmsdale at the Helmsdale Games, and on my adventures up there I passed a place called Badbea and I stopped and I thought, Ive heard of this place."So I went in and it was a clearance village. And I thought it was a village where people were cleared from ndash it turned out it was a village where people were cleared to."Its on the clf edge, and the wee legend said, On the clf edge, on the edge of Europe. And it made me think about where we are now on that clf edge."Rich, privileged, entitled people, shting people to the clf edge  years ago,  years ago, now. Still doing the same thing."Rich, privileged, Rees-Moggs telling us what we can and cant do and pushing us to the clf edge, to the edge. And that analogy was very, very powerful."

title: scotland-less-prepared-for-brexit-than-rest-of-uk
story: Jamie Kerr, a lawyer who specialises in migration and immigration, warned that leaving the European Union would "cause us damage, socially, culturally, and economically as well".But he said iniduals and businesses in places such as Manchester and London were more prepared for this.He told a fringe event at the SNP annual conference in Glasgow that was because in part the high profile work of Holyrood ministers had created the impression "the Scottish Government will sort it all out".Mr Kerr warned party activists: "I dont think we are prepared for Brexit, and in the work I do I think iniduals and businesses in Scotland are less prepared than they are in the rest of the UK."I work across the UK, the approach in Manchester, in London, they are much more prepared than we are here."I think there is a complacency in Scotland and part of it I think is because the Scottish Government have been so active, we watch the ministers, the First Ministers, being very active and speaking to industry, speaking to businesses are affected."And in a way it makes us think actually it will all be fine, the Scottish Government will sort it all out."I dont think thats going to be the case and I sometimes wonderwe all realise ... how steep a slope we are actually about to face because I think Brexit as a process is going to cause us damage, socially, culturally, and economically as well."

title: scottish-brexit-minister-says-snp-must-wait-for-right-moment-to-call-indyref2
story: Speaking at the SNP conference, Mike Russell insisted that the party must wait for the "right moment" to call a second independence referendum.He said that a second vote should only take place when Scotland is "persuaded, ready and determined to win" and that theright time was not "the moment that best relieves our natural impatience".With the UK due to leave the European in less than six months time, Mr Russell hit out at Theresa Mays "destructive, dysal UK Government".But he dismissed the portion of the SNP calling for party leaders to push ahead with a date for a second vote in response to Brexit.Mr Russell said: "Deciding the when can only come after agreeing on the why. Because the why isnt just about grabbing a leboat in choppy and dangerous seas."The why is about a route to a better Scotland, in a better Europe influencing the creation of a better world ..."It can only happen when we find the right moment and the right arguments to make it happen."Our job as a party and as a government is to both make sure that Scotland flourishes, no matter the circumstances but also to ensure that - at the right moment - the choice of independence can be made."The right moment - not the most comfortable moment or the moment that best relieves our natural impatience. The moment at which our country is persuaded, ready and determined to win."These are dficult times. They may become more dficult still and that is why the Scottish Government is working so hard to try and ensure that even in the event of a disastrous no deal we will be able to offer some mitigation and some protection."Sturgeon has already warned the UK Prime Minister her partys MPs will vote against any Brexit deal at Westminster which takes the UK out of the single market and the customs union.Russell echoed this, stating the SNP "will not be the midwives of Brexit, willing dislocation and disaster upon our country".He told the conference: "Let me put it this unequivocal way,there is no offer and no possibility, at the very least, of a single market and customs union outcome, either for the UK as a whole or for Scotland as a dferentiated part of these islands, then there is no meaningful option being offered at all, and no option that can or will have SNP support."He saidScotland was "forced to leave" the EU "for no matter how short a period, the only sensible, evidence led, option is to stay in the single market and the customs union".

title: hes-not-the-messiah-hes-the-new-kirk-moderator
story: Reverend Colin Sinclair has taken on many roles throughout his le - including starring as an extra in a Monty Python film - but his new appointment leading the churchrsquos General Assembly for  will be his biggest one to date.The -year-old, who appeared as a soldier in Monty Python and the Holy Grail , admits his new job excites and terries him at the same time, but he is ldquohonoured to be given the opportunity.And while his acting career never took off, Mr Sinclair has had plenty of experience working with the church, including spending time in Zambia, working as a parish minister, and leading the Scripture Union to support him in his role as moderator.The father-of-four, who will take up the post next year, is currently the parish minister at Palmerston Place in Edinburgh.Mr Sinclair said: ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to the role, but Irsquom terried at the same time. Irsquom hoping that I can do it justice.He added: ldquoIt will be a pleasure to encourage church members in their faith and to see the impact of their faith in communities across our country.ldquoI have thoroughly enjoyed being a parish minister and despite the challenges we face I believe the Christian faith is still relevant to Scotland.ldquoOur message is still good news and it still changes lives.Mr Sinclair grew up in the south side of Glasgow and it was as a pupil at Glasgow Academy that he first became interested in Christianity after watching a Scripture Union camp video.He went on to study economics at Stirling University and it was during his time there that he performed one of his more unusual jobs as a movie extra.ldquoI was a student at Stirling University when they were filming at Doune Castle and it seemed like a better option than going to lectures, he said.ldquoIt was fascinating really, watching the crew. We all got dressed up as soldiers and had to run up and down a hill. We appeared in the scene towards the end of the film where lots of the soldiers were running down the hill.ldquoIt seemed like a long day but it was great fun - and later on it gave me great street cred with my children when I could say I was in the film.ldquoI actually left the country not long after I did it and kind of forgot all about it, I only actually watched the film about  years later and I can just about pick myself out, only because I know where I am.After his brief appearance on the big screen, Mr Sinclair, then aged , was approached by Scripture Union and askedhe would go to Zambia.The job, which lasted three years, involved travelling around the country, living out of his car and speaking at schools, churches, hospitals and colleges.He said: ldquoThose three years changed my le. Being away from everything familiar I was able to sort out which parts of my faith were mine, and which were not.ldquoI encountered people from many dferent countries and with many dferent beliefs. I met all the Church of Scotland missionaries there and everyone was very supportive. I learned to trust God.On hisfrom Zambia, Mr Sinclair completed his ministry studies and was appointed to his first solo parish at Newton on Ayr.In  he married Ruth Murray, a medical social worker and the couple went on to have four children, Joanna, , Timothy, , Rachel,  and Bethany, .He spent six years in Ayr before being appointed as Director General of the Scripture Union in Glasgow.From there, he went on to take on the role of International Chair of Scripture Union, working with  SU movements around the world and travelling widely to countries such as Ghana, Peru and the Philippines.He has also served on many Church of Scotland councils and committees at both local and national level, including as convener of the Mission and Discipleship Council and serving on the Kirkrsquos governing body, the Council of Assembly.Since , he has been the minister at Palmerston Place, where he and Ruth, now grandparents, have strong links with the local community.ldquoI love being the minister for Palmerston Place, he said. ldquoThe heart of everything we do is Jesus and thatrsquos what excites me.ldquoThe message of the Bible is still extraordinary, challenging and hopeful. I still teach the Bible and people want to hear it.

title: nicola-sturgeon-indyref2-must-wait-for-fog-of-brexit-to-clear
story: Closing an SNP conference at which tensions over the timing of a second referendum spilled over, the First Minister told activists the ldquofog of Brexit needed to clear before any new vote.She said two years of chaos and incompetence of the UK government since the EU referendum had shown why Scotland needed to be independent and made it more likely.ldquoA better future is within our grasp, and together we are going to make it happen, she said.However she also stressed that a large amount of work lay ahead, telling delegates they still had to build and sell a persuasive economic case for leaving the UK.She said the ldquopassion of the Yes movement was not in doubt, saying recent marches by tens of thousands of supporters for independence had gladdened her heart.But in a key passage, she said: ldquoOur job is to take that passion and blend it with pragmatism, perseverance and patience to persuade those not yet persuaded.She said the ldquofuture relationship between the UK and the EU, a highly elastic formula, would determine the context in which Scotland would become independent.She said: ldquoThe detail of that will shape some of the answers that people want. But as we wait - impatiently, at times, I know - for this phase of negotiations to conclude and for the fog of Brexit to clear, be in no doubt about this.ldquoThe last two years have shown why Scotland needs to be independent.ldquoAnd I am more confident than ever that Scotland will be independent.She said the mess over Brexit suggested an update to a famous Winston Churchill quote.ldquoWell when the history books tell the story of this Tory government, selfishly driving the UK towards a hard Brexit just to appease its own ideologues, the verdict will be damning.ldquoNever has so much been lost by so many to satisfy so few.The -minute speech at the SEC campus in Glasgow was designed to both energise her troops with talk of independence and instil a sense of realism about the need for patience.It followed tensions over the timing of another referendum spilling over in recent days.WIth Theresa May refusing to grant another referendum, two MPs suggested alternative routes, despite party policy being to demand a rerun of the legally binding vote of .On Sunday, SNP MP Joanna Cherry QC said a ldquodemocratic event such as a general election could deliver independence instead of a referendum, while the following day her Westminster colleague Angus MacNeil warned the SNP must not ldquodither on the issue.Ms Sturgeon said that it was unstainable for Westminster to deny a referendum indefinitelythat was will of the Scottish people.She said: ldquoNow we have Tory and Labour politicians queuing up to tell us that the decision about Scotlandrsquos future belongs, not to the people, but to Westminster.ldquoWell, let us send this message today. You can oppose independence - that is your democratic right. But you cannot - and you will not - deny Scotlandrsquos right to choose.Earlier, constitutional affairs secretary Michael Russell also urged caution on a referendum.He said those impatient for a new vote that they must wait for the ldquoright moment.Ms Sturgeon also made an extended attack on Labour, a sign she wants to avoid a repeat of last yearrsquos switch by many SNP supporters to Jeremy Corbynrsquos party in a snap election.She said Labour had sounded like an ldquoSNP policy tribute act at its recent conference, copying ideas on public utilities, prescription charges, industrial policy, and fairer taxesShe said: ldquoThe SNP it isnrsquot just rhetoric. We win public support, we get ourselves elected, we put our money where our mouth is and we improve lives each and every day. Just think how much more we could do free of the chaos and incompetence of Westminster.The SNP leader also announced a series of new policies on employment and the NHS.To attract more trainee nurses, bursaries will from pound to pound next year and then to pound, the year after that, compared to the abolition of bursaries in England.She said: ldquoWe know the value of our nurses. We know the value of our NHS. And to anyone across the UK attracted to a career in nursing, our message is simple: come to Scotland.She said the government would use make ldquofair work first a consideration in all government contracts and business grants.In effect, employers would miss out on public money unless they stopped zero-hour contracts, delivered on equal pay, worked with unions, and paid the real living wage.However there was only a fleeting nod to education, the governmentrsquos ldquotop priority.A collaboration with the Social Bite charity to give the homeless a permanent roof is also to be expanded from  to  people under the pound.m Housing First initiative.Tory MSP Annie Wells said: ldquoNicola Sturgeon asked her supporters to stay patient - the truth is that most people lost patience with the SNP a long time ago. This was a tired speech from a tired Government which has run out of ideas, apart from the only one theyrsquove ever had.ldquoIn a speech littered with references to independence, there was just a glancing reference to education. It was a staggering omission and it tells you all you need to know. Education isnrsquot her number one priority ndash the only priority the SNP has is separating our country in two.Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard added: ldquoNicola Sturgeon delivered plenty of rhetoric for the party faithful but dodged any detail on the new economic prospectus for separation.ldquoOn education, the supposed top priority barely merited a passing mention. Reacting to the Fair Work First plan, Andrew McRae of the Federation of Small Business Scotland, said: ldquoWe need to be careful that these well-intentioned policy proposals donrsquot become a barrier to local firms winning public work, or receiving the right help to get through Brexit-related disruption.

title: snp-finance-secretary-derek-mackay-accused-of-reheating-flagship-policy
story: Mr Mackay announced financial health checks for older people and those on low incomes will be brought in from next month.He said the pound. million two-year scheme would help an additional , people, adding:"It will cover things like access to free school meals, school clothing grants, benefit uptake, and cheaper deals on energy and other utilities to reduce household costs."But opponents accused him of indulging in "shameless soundbites and reheated announcements".Scottish Labours finance spokesman James Kelly said: "Labour welcomes the idea of financial health checks for older people and low income families."We welcomed it in the  Programme for Government, the  programme for government and when Nicola Sturgeon announced it in  as well."Scottish Tory shadow economy secretary Dean Lockhart said: "Its entirely in keeping with this tired SNP government that the only big things in this speech were a re-announced plan for financial health checks, and yet more commissions and action plans."After  years in government, it shows that the SNP has very little left in the tank."Nicola Sturgeon first announced the policy at the  SNP conference and also included it in her recent programme for government ndash the legislative blueprint for the coming year.Mr Mackay also pledged to launch an economic action plan by the end of October and announced a pound, grant for Clyde Gateway, a massive regeneration project in the east end of Glasgow and Rutherglen.He said this will go towards a new pound million headquarters for the STUC.Meanwhile, he wrote to ChancellorPhilip Hammond to outline key issues for Scotland ahead of the UK Budget on October  ndash including concerns over Brexit and welfare reform.

title: dominic-raab-rules-out-indefinite-uk-wide-customs-union-with-eu-to-resolve-irish-border-impasse
story: The Brexit Secretary began his Commons update post the acrimonious Salzburg summit facing Labour MPs shouting out ldquowhere is she  with Sir Keir Starmer, Mr Raabrsquos Shadow, suggesting Theresa May should have been at the despatch box given it was she who had failed to persuade the EU of her Chequers Plan last month.Noting how it was not customary for prime ministers to give statements on ldquoinformal summits, the Secretary of State told MPs it was time for Brussels to match the UKrsquos ambition and pragmatism and meet it ldquohalf-way.He explained how talks with the EU had "intensied" and the two sides were now "closing in on workable solutions" to all of the key outstanding issues.Mr Raab told MPsthe Government held its nerve, remained ldquoresolute and focused, he was confident a deal could be agreed this autumn.As UK ministers prepare to unveil new proposals on customs and regulations, Sir Keir askedan "indefinite UK-wide customs union" would be part of them.He also called on Mr Raab to rule out a "vague or blind Brexit", declaring: "No government has the right to plunge the country into chaos as a result of its own failure.The Secretary of State brushed aside the suggestion of an indefinite customs union, saying: "No, categorically that is not correct."Nigel Dodds for the Democratic Unionists repeated what has been dubbed the partyrsquos ldquoblood red line, telling the Brexit Secretary: "We will not tolerate anything that separates Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK in terms of customs or single market as we leave the EU. Weve been clear about that from day one."Its why we had the debacle in December. Lets not repeat that mistake," insisted the Belfast MP.Leading Brexiteer Steve Baker, the former Brexit Minister, argued a free trade agreement could be made to work across the Irish border using pragmatic arrangements."When will the Governmenthellipadmit we can leave into a Free Trade Agreement[FTA] basis, which will make this a proper independent country able to control its domestic regulations as well as its tarfs so that we can lead the world into a new era of free trade "But Mr Raab told his Conservative colleague his plan was untenable, saying: "The EU are not offering us Canada, super-Canada, an FTA without keeping to the commitment that we made when he was in Government in December to come up with a legally binding backstop.ldquoSo, that[Mr Bakerrsquos proposal] is a shortcut to no-dealhellipThe optimum aim here that were working towards is a good deal with the EU. We couldnt get thatwe pursued what hes suggesting."Peter Grant for the SNP pointed out with just over a week to the next European Council the public still did not know what the UK Government intended to propose to resolve the Northern Ireland issue."Were running out of time. We need answers very very quickly," he insisted.Meanwhile, Simon Coveney, Irelandrsquos Deputy PM, said the Brexit talks had reached a crucial stage and there had been an "intensication" this week.He warned: "If Britain crashes out of the EU without a deal on anything, then you are talking about carnage...particularly for Britain that is a very unlikely scenario."Certainly, I will work and have been working with the EU task force to make sure that does not materialise."In other developments:*David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary, urged Mrs May to ldquoreset her Brexit strategy, warning of "dire" consequences for the Conservatives at the next General Electionshe did not*Penny Mordaunt, the International Development Secretary, repeatedly failed to support the PMrsquos Chequers Plan when asked but insisted Mrs May had her ldquofull support and*DUP leader Arlene Foster, after talks with Michel Barnier, the EUrsquos chief negotiator, said any Brexit deal had to meet her partyrsquos ldquoblood red line on maintaining the integrity of the United Kingdom.

title: convicted-former-ubs-trader-on-his-way-to-scottish-home-after-being-freed-from-uk-immigration-centre
story: Adoboli, , who served four years of a seven-year sentence for a pound.bn fraud at Swiss bank UBS, was initially denied bail in September after being spared deportation by a legal intervention just hours before his scheduled flight to his birth country, Ghana.He was released from Harmondsworth Detention Centre on Tuesday nighafter being detained for  days and embraced by supporters.He was expected to take a train with his partner, Alice Gray after collecting him from the detention centre.ldquoIrsquom very tired and Irsquom really looking forward to going home, he said. ldquoBut I canrsquot feel elated because I know there are so many other men and women locked up in detention who should not be there. Being locked up for  days has really started to destroy my mental health.The Home Office wants to deport him under laws that require foreign nationals sentenced to more than four years in prison to be sent back to their country of birth.An application of bail was granted earlier today by a judge at Hatton Cross Tribunal Centre, near Heathrow Airport while his deportation is reviewed.His case will be the subject of a judicial review, which could take months, but the latest ruling means the former trader willhome pending the outcome.At a hearing on Tuesday, the judge Stephen Pedro noted that Adoboli had previously been on immigration bail for three years ldquowithout fault and said he could not see, substantialgrounds for risk of reoffending or absconding. Adobolirsquos friends provided surety for him of pound,.Matthew Williams, acting for the Home Office, said the home secretary wanted to keep Adoboli detained because his appeal rights were exhausted.A fund-raising campaign to continue his legal battle to remain in the UK raised over pound,. Adoboli who is Ghanaian, but has lived in the UK since the age of , does not hold British citizenship.He was detained at police station last month during a routine meeting at a local police station near his home in Livingston.Adoboli, who describes himself as British, has since his release from jail given many talks to students, financial traders and others in the banking industry about how to operate ethically and avoid making the mistakes he made.He had been reporting once a month to the Home Office and had feared that he may be arrested in preparation for deportation after he was denied permission to judicially review the deportation proceedings.Adoboli appealed, asking the home secretary, Sajid Javid, not to deport him because of his longstanding ties with the UK and the fact that he is working hard to educate people to avoid making the same mistakes he made at UBS.In June, he lost an appeals court bid to block his deportation, effectively putting an end to his legal challenge.Speaking after Tuesdayrsquos hearing, Adobolirsquos solicitor, Jacqueline McKenzie, said: ldquoWersquore very pleased with the outcome. Now Kweku canto his partner Alice Gray, his friends and his loved ones in Scotland and get on with the important job of fighting the legal battle against deportation.ldquoTodayrsquos decision is a clear vindication of Kwekursquos claim that hersquos not at risk of absconding. Itrsquos a shame that an earlier hearing found against him as it meant he has remained in detention for  days longer than necessary.During his trial at Southwark Crown Court in , he had denied the charges, which related to the period between October  and September .He argued at his trial nearly six years ago that managers at the bank pushed him to take too many risks. While he admitted causing the loss, he said it wasnrsquot done dishonestly.But the jury was told he lost the money in "unprotected, unhedged, incautious and reckless" trades.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Why pragmatism and patience have to be the order of the day for SNP
story: Nicola Sturgeon wants to keep hope alive, but shersquos not going to call any referendum she canrsquot be sure of winning. Activists have to content themselves with the thin gruel of ldquoperseverance, pragmatism and patience. Her conference speech was almost Presbyterian in its downbeat realism: you can wave all the flags you want, but therersquos no short cut to independence.Most of her troops get this. The SNP MP Angus MacNeill used precisely the wrong historical analogy when he urged Nicola Sturgeon not to ldquodither like the Jacobites at Derby . Modern Scottish nationalists, like Nicola Sturgeon, loathe comparisons with Bonnie Prince Charlie and heroic failures like the lsquo. Nor is she an enthusiast for the politics of naive optimism.She knows that, evenopinion polls started showing a majority in favour of independence, Theresa May is not going to allow another referendum in the foreseeable future. Westminster must pass a so-called Section  Order to legitimise a referendum on the constitution, and the PM made clear last year that shersquos not going to table one. MPs would probably reject itshe did. For her part, Ms Sturgeon has repeatedly made clear she will not entertain any illegal referendums, not least because Unionists would boycott them, as in Catalonia in .This is not going to change any time soon. In her ldquonow is not the time interview in March , Mrs May gave three reasons for refusing a Section . First, that voters are confused right now second, that a second independence referendum would interfere with negotiations over Brexit and third, that Scots need to know what the future relationship with the EU is going to be before making up their minds about relations with the UK. Ms Sturgeon agrees that the ldquofog of Brexit as she put it yesterday, has to clear before any sensible choice can be made about Scottish independence. That ldquotriple mandate for independence,she won last year is not enough.But will the fog clear  EvenMrs May s with an acceptable exit deal before Christmas, the confusion over Brexit will be far from over. Any deal with Brussels will be limited to the orce bill, EU citizensrsquo rights and the Irish backstopand this will not be the end of Brexit uncertainly. It wonrsquot even be the end of the beginning.The latest version of the Chequers deal,appears to involve the UK remaining in the Customs Union until a ldquofriction-free solution emerges to trade across the Irish border. This is the so-called ldquoblind Brexit under which Britain leaves the EU in March without any clarity about future trading relations. It suits hard Brexiters because once wersquore out, wersquore out.But this half-in-half-out arrangement is not just confined to the transition period, which is supposed to end in . Indeed, it will almost certainly continue after that. My reading of the negotiations is that Britain is heading towards a ldquoSwitzerland minus outcome. The Swiss are not members of the EU, or the EEA or formally the European Single Market. However, they accept all the rules of the ESM on a ldquobilateral basis, meaning that they accept changes as they come along, not en masse, as it were.Itrsquos a fine distinction, and most people agree that Switzerland is in the single market for all intents and purposes. It accepts the four freedoms, including freedom of movement, and largely rubber-stamps rulings of the European Court of Justice. However, it is not actually in the ESM, which makes it Brexit-compliant. Mrs May will try to get a Switzerland-type deal, minus any formal acceptance of freedom of movement. But this will likely be fudged over a y transition in which the destination will be clear, but neither side will openly admit it.Except for Ms Sturgeon, who will want to call a spade a spade. If there is a transition deal that explicitly confirms regulatory alignment for Northern Ireland with the single market ndash which is what the ldquohybrid backstop also seems to involve ndash she will rightly call for Scotland to get parity. The Northern Ireland back-stop is similar to the hybrid arrangement she proposed for Scotland in the Scottish Government White Paper, Scotlandrsquos Place in Europe, back in . .But the downside is that Brussels and the UK could end up with an open-ended transition period in which Britain is out of the European Union, but remains in an uncertain relationship to its institutions. This means Scottish voters could be no clearer on our long-term relations with Europe than they are now. This purgatory could easily last  years, during which no UK government will agree to an independence referendum for Scotland, on the grounds that nothing is clear until everything is clear.I suspect realisation that the fog of Brexit is going to linger helped persuade the First Minister, belatedly, to support a Peoplersquos Vote on Brexit. On the BBC Andrew Marr show she made clear SNP MPs will vote for a repeat referendum on Brexit, eventhere is no guarantee of indyref. The polls may indicate that support for independence would rise with a hard Brexit, but it is much better for the cause of Scottish independencethe UK doesnrsquot leave the EU at all. It would mean Scotland could seamlessly depart from the UK without there being any hard border with England, and without Scotland having to formally leave the EU.There is now a slim chance that a Peoplersquos Vote might happen. That Britain will wake up from the Brexit nightmare. But that would be a triumph of hope over experience.
